questions.text: A child was brought to the pediatric emergency with complaints of abdominal pain, vomiting, mild abdominal distention, and constipation. On physical examination, there was notable tenderness near the navel. The physician immediately orders some tests, but none of it turns out satisfactory. Hence, after giving initial medications to the child, the physician orders a Meckel's scan to check for Meckel’s diverticulum. Which of the following is true about Meckel’s diverticulum?

choices.text: Is found in about 4% of the population.
Is always found on the antimesenteric border of the ileum.
Is usually about 2 cm in length.
Is usually located about 20 cm from the ileocaecal junction.

questions.solution:
Option B: Is always found on the antimesenteric border of the ileum

  • This is the correct statement.
  • Meckel’s diverticulum is the proximal remnant of the embryonic yolk stalk.
  • It is found at the site of attachment of the yolk stalk at the border of the intestine opposite its mesenteric attachment.
  • It is a congenital ileal anomaly that is found in approximately 2% of the population,
  • It is the embryological remnant of the vitellointestinal duct.
  • A commonly quoted statement about Meckel's diverticulum is that it is present in 2% of the population, 2 ft from the ileocaecal junction, and is 2 inches in length.
  • It is usually found 40 cm from the ileocaecal junction in children and about 60 cm in adults.

 

 

Option A: Is found in about 4% of the population.

  •  Meckel’s diverticulum is found in about 2%-3% of the general population.

Option C: Is usually about 2 cm in length.

  •  Because Meckel’s diverticulum is usually about 2 inches long.

Option D: Is usually located about 20 cm from the ileocaecal junction.

  •  Meckel’s diverticulum is usually found 40 cm from the ileocaecal junction in children and 60 cm in adults.

questions.text: A 7-day-old male infant presents with worsening respiratory distress for 3 days. Examination reveals tachypnea, increased work of breathing, and decreased breath sounds on the left side of the chest. Chest X-ray shows left-sided herniation of abdominal organs. What statements are true regarding the involved structure?

choices.text: Spleen and intestines enter the thoracic cavity.

questions.solution:
Option B: Left crus is attaching to L1 and L2 only

  • This is a case of congenital diaphragmatic hernia.
  • Right crus is longer than left crus
    • Right crus attaching to L1, L2, and L3 anteriorly
    • Left crus is attaching to L1, L2 only
    • Right crus connected to Left crus by Median (midline) arcuate ligament.
    • Esophagus passes through muscular fibers of the Right crus of the diaphragm at T10.
  • Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is of the following 2 types:

Bochdalek hernia:

Morgagni hernia
  • Usually left sided
  • It is a congenital diaphragmatic hernia
  • Deficiency in the left pleuroperitoneal cavity
  • Left lung hypoplasia
  • The right lung is also compressed
  • Cyanosis at birth
  • NEONATAL EMERGENCY
  • Mostly on the right side
  • Antero-medial & Retrosternal
  • Transverse colon herniates in front of the heart.
  • Less common
  • than Bochdalek hernia

 

Option A: Right crus is attaching to L3, L4 and L5 anteriorly

  • Right crus is attached to L1, L2, and L3 anteriorly.

Option C: Esophagus passes through muscular fibers of the Left crus of the diaphragm at T10

  • Esophagus passes through muscular fibers of the Right crus of the diaphragm at T10.

Option D: Left crus is longer than right crus

  •  The right crus is normally longer than the left crus.

questions.text: A 2-day-old newborn baby presents to the physician with complaints of complete loss of breath and turning blue on several occasions. His breathing improves if the baby is placed in an upright or sitting position. Physical examination reveals an unusually flat stomach when the baby is lying down. On auscultation, there are no breath sounds on the left side of the thorax. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

  • Clinical history indicates congenital diaphragmatic hernia because physical examination reveals an unusually flat stomach when the newborn is lying down; auscultation demonstrates no breath sounds on the left side of the thorax.
  • A congenital diaphragmatic hernia is a congenital defect in the diaphragm.
  • An abnormally developed diaphragm results in an abnormal opening (hernia) that allows the intestine and stomach to move into the chest cavity and fill the heart and lungs.
  • This overcrowding can lead to underdevelopment of the lungs (pulmonary hypoplasia), which can lead to life-threatening breathing difficulties that are recognizable from birth.
  • Loss of breath and cyanosis result from pulmonary hypoplasia associated with congenital diaphragmatic hernia.
  • Placing the child in an upright position will reduce the hernia somewhat and ease the pressure on the lungs, thereby increasing the baby's comfort.
  • The baby’s stomach is flat (instead of the plump belly of a normal newborn) because the abdominal viscera have herniated into the thorax.
  • Auscultation reveals no breath sounds on the left side because of pulmonary hypoplasia.

Option A: Physiological umbilical herniation

  • A physiological umbilical herniation is a self-limiting condition not associated with cyanosis.

Option B: Esophageal hiatal hernia

  • Esophageal hiatal hernia doesn't present with abdominal defects.

Option C: Tetralogy of Fallot

  • Tetralogy of Fallot also presents with cyanosis, but the patient improves in a squatting position, not in an upright position.

questions.text:
A surgeon has exposed the operative field for a cardio-thoracic procedure for a case of apical lung cancer and identified a few nerves in the region.



Injury to which of the marked nerves in the diagram may affect respiratory movements?
questions.solution:
Option A: A

  • The given scenario is about respiratory movements. Hence, it is the phrenic nerve(marker A).
  • The phrenic nerve arises from C3 to C5 spinal segments and joins the cervical plexus of nerves in the neck.
  • The phrenic nerve courses anterior to the scalenus anterior muscle, as shown in the diagram, and then passes behind the belly of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. Then both the phrenic nerves, right and left, pass the thoracic inlet and enter the thorax to supply the diaphragm.
  • Injury to the phrenic nerve (marker ‘A’) compromises the diaphragm (and respiratory movements).
  • The labeling of the diagram in the question is shown below:

Option B: B

  • Arrow B points towards the Sympathetic chain.
  • The sympathetic chain is a ganglionated chain present bilaterally extending from the base of the skull to the coccyx.
  • It is the fundamental part of the sympathetic nervous system and a part of the autonomic nervous system.
  • It does not affect respiratory movements.

Option C: C

  • The Vagus nerve(arrow C) is the tenth cranial nerve (CN X).
  • The Vagus nerve is responsible for internal organ functions, such as digestion, heart rate, respiratory rate, vasomotor activity, and certain reflex actions, such as coughing, sneezing, swallowing, and vomiting.
  • It controls respiration rate by reflex mechanisms but does not play any role in the motor innervations responsible for respiratory movements.

Option D: D

  • The recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) is a branch of the vagus nerve(marker 'D')
  • It carries fibers of sensory innervation from the larynx below the level of vocal cords. 
  • It supplies motor innervation to all the intrinsic muscles of the larynx, except for the cricothyroid muscles, and has no association with regulating respiratory movements.

questions.text: A 31-year-old male presents with progressive weakness and dysfunction of his right arm following a previous radial bone fracture from a road traffic accident. X-ray shows healed fracture with decreased width and atrophy of the right arm. The symptoms are likely due to compression of neurovascular bundles passing through which structure?

choices.text: Both A and B are correct

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Both A and B:

  • Volkmann's canal: Volkmann's canals, also known as perforating canals, are small channels in bone that transmit blood vessels and nerves from the periosteum (the outer covering of bone) to the Haversian canals within the bone. These canals are involved in the blood supply of the bone.

  • Haversian canal: Haversian canals, also known as osteons, are microscopic channels within bone that contain blood vessels and nerves. They are responsible for supplying nutrients and oxygen to bone tissue and removing waste products.

In some cases, compression of neurovascular bundles can occur within both Volkmann's and Haversian canals, especially if there is a narrowing or other structural changes in the bone, as suggested by the decreased width of the healed fracture seen on the X-ray. This compression can lead to symptoms like progressive weakness and dysfunction of the arm and atrophy of the bone.

So, in this specific clinical scenario, it is reasonable to consider that both Volkmann's and Haversian canals could be involved in the compression of neurovascular bundles, making option c. both a and b options the correct choice.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is/are true about the brachial plexus?

A. Lower trunk is formed by root C8 and T1

B. Lateral cord is formed by the upper and middle trunk

C. Posterior cord is formed by posterior divisions of all three trunks

D. Anterior division of the lower trunk continuous as medial cord and give rise to the radial nerve.
questions.solution:
Option D:  A, B & C only

Brachial plexus:

  • It may also receive contributions from the fourth cervical and the second thoracic spinal nerves.
  • The upper limb's muscle, joints, and skin are innervated by the ventral primary rami of C5, C6, C7, and C8, and nearly all of the ventral primary ramus from T1, collectively forming the brachial plexus.
  • The proportion of motor fibers is greatest in C5 and C8; the sensory contribution is greatest in C7.
  • A complex interchange of branches before the main nerves of the upper limb has formed the trunks, divisions, and cords.
  • The C5 and C6 form the upper trunk. The middle trunk is the continuation of C7. C8 and T1 form the lower trunk.
  • The trunks divide into anterior and posterior divisions.
  • The cords are formed by the confluence of divisions: the lateral cord from the anterior divisions of the upper and middle trunk; the posterior cord by all three posterior divisions; and the medial cord by the anterior division of the lower trunk and sometimes by a branch from the anterior division of the middle trunks.
  • Contribution by C4 to the brachial plexus is pre-fixed brachial plexus, not post-fixed to plexus.
  • Post-fixed brachial plexus has a contribution by T2.

 Option A:B only

  • The brachial plexus lies in the posterior triangle of the neck, at the angle between the clavicle and the lower posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid.
  • It emerges between the scaleni anterior and medius, superior to the third part of the subclavian artery.
  • It is covered by platysma, deep the roots and trunks of the brachial plexus can be represented by a line passing between the middle of the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid and the middle of the clavicle.

 Option B: B & C

  • The brachial plexus is formed by the union of the ventral rami of the lower four cervical nerves and the greater part of the ventral ramus of the first thoracic spinal nerve.

 Option C:A, B & C only

  • The lower trunk is formed by roots C8 and T1
  • The lateral cord is formed by the upper and middle trunk
  • The posterior cord is formed by posterior divisions of all three trunks

questions.text: What's incorrect about the blood vessel causing left arm weakness, numbness, and low blood pressure compared to the right arm in a 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and previous myocardial infarction?

choices.text: On the left side arises from the arch of the aorta
On the right side arises from the brachiocephalic trunk
Vertebral artery arises from 2nd part of the subclavian artery
Divided by scalenus anterior muscle into three parts

questions.solution:
Option C: Vertebral artery arises from 2nd part of the subclavian artery.

  • The vertebral artery arises from 1st part of the subclavian artery.

Option A: On the left side arises from the arch of the aorta

  • On the left side, the subclavian artery comes directly off the aortic arch.

Option B: On the right side arises from the brachiocephalic trunk

  • The subclavian artery on the right side arises from the brachiocephalic trunk.

Option D: Divided by scalenus anterior muscle into three parts

  • Scalenus anterior muscle divides the subclavian artery into three parts. So, this is a correct statement.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male involved in a road accident undergoes a head CT, revealing an incidental tumor in the base of the skull, obscuring part of the jugular foramen. The Xth cranial nerve involvement is suspected. Which of the following muscles' actions cannot confirm this involvement through testing?
questions.solution:
Option B: Stylopharyngeus

  • All muscles of the pharynx are supplied by the Xth nerve, except the stylopharyngeus.
  • The Glossopharyngeal nerve supplies the stylopharyngeus.
  • Stylopharyngeal muscles are elevators of the pharynx.
  • Hence, testing the action of the stylopharyngeus cannot be used to test the vagus nerve.
  • Vagus nerve also supplies the heart, lungs, and upper gastrointestinal tract.

​​​​​​​Option A: Palatopharyngeus

  • Vagus nerve supplies palatopharyngeus
  • The Passavant’s ridge is also often termed as Passavant’s fold, formed by the palatopharyngeal muscle.
  • The ridge can be observed just inferior to the pharyngeal tonsils and posterior and inferior to the pharyngeal opening of the Eustachian tube.

Option C: Salpingopharyngeus

  • The vagus nerve supplies this muscle
  • This muscle elevates the pharynx

 Option D: Middle constrictor

  • It is a pharyngeal constrictor muscle and is supplied by the vagus nerve.

questions.text: Mr. Johnson, a 65-year-old male, presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset dyspnea, chest pain, and lower limb swelling. He has a history of recent hip replacement surgery and immobilization. CT angiography reveals a filling defect in the right pulmonary artery. Which tributary of the IVC is most likely associated with the formation of pulmonary embolism?

choices.text: Femoral vein of the operated side

questions.solution:
Option C

  • The most likely tributary of the inferior vena cava (IVC) associated with the formation of pulmonary embolism in this case is the common iliac vein. This is because the patient has a history of recent hip replacement surgery and immobilization, which are risk factors for the development of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the lower extremities. The clot that formed in the common iliac vein could have traveled to the pulmonary artery and caused a pulmonary embolism (PE).

Why Others are Wrong

  • Option A: Renal vein - The renal veins drain the kidneys and are not directly involved in the pathway of clots from the lower extremities to the pulmonary artery, making it an unlikely site for the formation of PE.
  • Option B: Deep femoral vein - The deep femoral vein, also known as the profunda femoris vein, drains the muscles of the thigh and is not directly associated with the formation of PE in this case.
  • Option D: Femoral vein of the operated side - While the femoral vein of the operated side may be at increased risk for DVT due to recent hip replacement surgery, it is not directly associated with the formation of PE. The clot would need to travel from the femoral vein to the common iliac vein and then to the pulmonary artery to cause PE.

questions.text: During embryonic development, the ventral mesogastrium gives rise to which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Option A

  • The lesser omentum is a double-layered fold of the peritoneum that connects the liver and stomach. It is derived from the ventral mesogastrium.

Why Others are Incorrect

Option B: The greater omentum is derived from the dorsal mesogastrium

Option C: The transverse mesocolon is derived from the dorsal mesogastrium

Option D: The splenorenal ligament is formed by the fusion of the dorsal mesentery and the ventral mesentery.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with severe burning pain, tingling, and numbness in her right hand and fingers. The pain is aggravated by movement and has been persistent for the past 2 weeks. Examination reveals decreased sensation in the affected hand. Which of the following structures is most likely involved?

choices.text: Gray matter of C6 spinal cord segment

questions.solution:
Option A: Dorsal root ganglion of C6 
The symptoms described in the question suggest a sensory deficit in the right hand, indicating involvement of the dorsal root ganglion. The dorsal root ganglia contain cell bodies of sensory neurons that transmit sensory information from the periphery to the spinal cord.

Why Others are Incorrect

  • Option B) Ventral root of C6 is incorrect as ventral roots carry motor information and are not directly related to the sensory deficits described in the question.
  • Option C) (Sympathetic ganglion of C6 is incorrect as sympathetic ganglia are part of the sympathetic nervous system and are not directly related to the sensory deficits described in the question.
  • Option D) Gray matter of C6 spinal cord segment is incorrect as gray matter of the spinal cord contains cell bodies of motor neurons and is not directly related to the sensory deficits described in the question.

questions.text: According to Couinaud's classification, which hepatic segment is located between the middle hepatic vein and the left hepatic vein?
questions.solution:
Option B

  • Couinaud's classification divides the liver into eight segments based on the distribution of hepatic vessels. Segment III is located between the middle hepatic vein and the left hepatic vein, making option B the correct answer.

Why Others are Wrong

Option A (Segment II): is incorrect as it is located between the middle hepatic vein and the falciform ligament.

Option C (Segment IV): is incorrect as it is located between the left hepatic vein and the middle hepatic vein.

Option D (Segment V): is incorrect as it is located between the left hepatic vein and the falciform ligament.

questions.text: A 3-month-old male infant has been brought by his parents to the pediatrician's office concerning his dysmorphic features. He has a flat facial appearance, a small head, prominent epicanthic folds, a flat nasal bridge, a protruding tongue with an open mouth, hypotonia, and a pansystolic murmur. He was born to a 36-year-old mother after a normal gestation and delivery. His parents' karyotypes are normal. Which of the following is the most likely syndrome according to this karyotype?
questions.solution:
Option C: Down syndrome

  • The karyotype above reveals trisomy 21 (abnormal 3rd copy on chromosome 21), suggesting Down syndrome.
  • It is a genetic disorder due to the abnormal separation of chromosome 21, forming an extra copy in all the cells.
  • It can also occur due to Robertsonian translocation and ring chromosomes.
  • The classic presentation is retarded growth, intellectual disability, and characteristic facial features.
  • The patient may also present with neurological disorders and congenital heart diseases.

Option A: Turner syndrome

  • It is a congenital ovarian hypoplasia syndrome
  • It is a sex chromosomal abnormality usually found in females.
  • It is characterized by an X chromosome that is missing, partially or completely.
  • It is due to the contribution of an atypical reproductive cell resulting in the formation of cells with a single X chromosome.
  • The physical appearance includes short stature with a webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, and a low hairline at the neck.

Option B: Edward syndrome

  • It is an autosomal chromosomal disorder resulting from an extra copy of chromosome 18.
  • It may be diagnosed antenatally during the second trimester.
  • There would be intrauterine growth restriction, brachycephaly, cardiac defects, clenched hands with overriding index fingers, and a single umbilical artery.
  • It may result in still in miscarriage or stillbirth.

Option D: Patau syndrome

  • It is a clinical syndrome that results from an extra copy of chromosome 13.
  • Typical features are cleft lip with cleft palate, sloping forehead, cerebral defects, simian creases, and polydactyly.
  • It may be diagnosed prenatally by amniocentesis.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old boy presents with decreased urinary output, brown colour urine, decreased appetite, nausea, and fatigue for the last 3 days. On examination, significant findings are anaemia, mild pedal oedema and mild facial puffiness. His blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg, while the other vitals are normal. On his urine analysis, the following lab findings are found:


	
		
			
			Urine Output
			
			
			Less than 300mls/day
			
		
		
			
			Blood 
			
			
			+++
			
		
		
			
			Red cell casts
			
			
			100/hpf
			
		
		
			
			Protein
			
			
			Less than 3.5g/L/day
			
		
	


What is the most probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Acute nephritic syndrome

  • Nephritic syndrome is characterized by hematuria, mild to moderate proteinuria (usually less than 3.5g/L/day), hypertension, oliguria, and red cell casts in the urine
  • Typical findings on urinalysis in the context of nephritic syndrome include:
  1. Haematuria (blood +++)
  2. Proteinuria (mild – protein ++)
  3. Red cell casts
  • Diagnosis is made by urine reports and blood reports
  • Treatment is mainly by blood pressure medication, diuretics, and immune system-suppressing medications

 

Option A: Mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis

  • It is a type of nephrotic syndrome characterized by the loss of significant amounts of protein via the kidneys (proteinuria), resulting in hypoalbuminaemia. The definition of the nephrotic syndrome includes both massive proteinuria (≥3.5 g/day) and hypoalbuminaemia (serum albumin ≤30 g/L) 
  • It is not typically associated with blood and red cell casts in urine compared to this patient's lab findings.
  • Nephrotic syndrome is associated with oedema (due to reduced oncotic pressure), hyperlipidaemia and hypercoagulability.

Option B: Minimal change of disease

  • It is not typically associated with blood and red cell casts in urine compared to this patient's lab findings.
  • Nephrotic syndrome is associated with oedema (due to reduced oncotic pressure), hyperlipidaemia and hypercoagulability.

Option D: Membranous nephropathy

  • It is not typically associated with blood and red cell casts in urine compared to this patient's lab findings.
  • Nephrotic syndrome is associated with oedema (due to reduced oncotic pressure), hyperlipidaemia and hypercoagulability.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with an unstable gait. His mother complains that the boy staggers while walking, and it is difficult for him to climb stairs. He also has droopy eyelids.  When asked to release his hand after making a handgrip, he has difficulty opening his grip. The image of the child is given below. Identify the disease this child is suffering from:
questions.solution:
Option B: Myotonic dystrophy

  • Facial weakness, inverted V-shaped upper lip (Hatchet face appearance) due to facial muscle weakness, and loss of muscle mass in the temporal fossa is characteristic of myotonic muscular dystrophy.

  • Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder

  • It has two forms. Myotonic dystrophy type 1 Is severe with decreased life expectancy, while type two is mild.

  • It causes difficult muscular relaxation leading to progressive muscle weakness.

  • Weakness of neck musculature leads to difficulty in holding the head.

  • The progressive disease leads to unstable gait.

Option A: Duchenne muscular dystrophy

  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder due to non-frame shift mutation.

  • Commonly causes calf muscle weakness leading to Calf pseudohypertrophy.

  • Patients stand with the help of placing their hands on the shins, knees and thighs. This is called the Growers sign.

  • Most patients die in their 20s from respiratory or heart failure.

Option C: Facioscapulohumeral dystrophy

  • It is also a genetic disorder. It is the third most common type of disorder after Duchenne and Becker and myotonic dystrophy

  • It commonly involves the face, scapular and upper arm muscles(humerus).

  • Winging of the scapula, weakness of facial muscles, atrophy of the biceps, triceps and deltoid are seen.

Option D: Spinal muscular atrophy

  • A genetic disorder involving Lower motor neuron involvement

  • Due to mutation in the SMN gene

  • Fasciculations, generalised weakness, and absent  Deep tendon reflexes (DTRs) are common symptoms.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents in the emergency department with complaints of blood in urine, lower abdominal pain, and diarrhoea for 2 days. There is no history of decreased urine output. On examination, the patient's vitals are normal except for having tachycardia (102 beats/minute). He is mildly dehydrated and has evidence of dermatitis herpetiformis. Urine analysis shows evidence of gross haematuria. C3 levels are normal, and peripheral smear examination also shows no remarkable findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Berger’s disease

  • Gross haematuria within 1-2 days of onset of an upper respiratory or gastrointestinal infection in young children suggests Berger's disease. (Skin infection causes post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) and not Berger’s disease).
  • It is also called IgA nephropathy.
  • IgA Nephropathy is strongly associated with celiac disease, which has the cutaneous manifestation of dermatitis herpetiformis.
  • Mild to moderate hypertension can be seen in this disease, which may present with loin pain.
  • Normal serum levels of C3 in IgA nephropathy help to differentiate this disorder from PSGN, where serum C3 levels are low.
  • Serum IgA levels are elevated in only 15% of paediatric patients.

Option B: Post Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis

  • PSGN can present with gross haematuria after an upper respiratory tract infection or a skin infection. 
  • The time interval between the preceding illness and the development of haematuria is usually longer in PSGN (more than 10 days)

Option C: Microangiopathic haemolytic anaemia

  • Microangiopathic haemolytic anaemia results from damage to red blood cells while passing through the damaged/thrombotic capillary.
  • Microangiopathic haemolytic anaemia is diagnosed by morphologically abnormal RBCs, with schistocytes, spherocytes, helmet cells, and an elevated reticulocyte count. So normal peripheral smear examination in the above question rules out microangiopathic haemolytic anaemia.

Option D: Alport syndrome

  • The diagnosis of Alport syndrome can only be made by kidney biopsy.
  • There is a family history of kidney failure, and the patient may present with deafness.

questions.text: A 4-year-old female presents with a history of developmental delay, loss of previously acquired milestones, and hand wringing. On examination, she has microcephaly and a wide-based gait. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Rett Syndrome is a neurodevelopmental disorder that primarily affects females. It is characterized by loss of previously acquired skills, hand wringing, and microcephaly. A wide-based gait is also a common feature. 

Why others are Incorrect:

Option A: Autism spectrum disorder: Autism spectrum disorder may present with developmental delay, but it typically does not have the characteristic hand wringing or microcephaly seen in Rett Syndrome.

Option B: Angelman Syndrome: Angelman Syndrome may have some overlap in clinical features, including developmental delay and microcephaly, but it is typically associated with a happy demeanor and inappropriate laughter.

Option D: Fragile X Syndrome: Fragile X Syndrome may present with developmental delay and behavioral issues, but it typically does not have the characteristic hand wringing or microcephaly seen in Rett Syndrome. Additionally, Fragile X Syndrome is caused by a mutation in the FMR1 gene, whereas Rett Syndrome is caused by mutations in the MECP2 gene.

questions.text: A 6-month-old male infant presents with recurrent infections and failure to thrive. Laboratory evaluation reveals low levels of all immunoglobulins. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• SCID is referred to as Severe Combined Immunodeficiency. The clinical presentation of recurrent infections and failure to thrive along with low levels of all immunoglobulins suggests SCID. 

Why Other Answers Are Incorrect

Option B: X-linked hyper-IgM syndrome presents with recurrent bacterial infections and high levels of IgM. 

Option C: Hyper-IgE syndrome presents with eczema, recurrent staphylococcal infections, and high levels of IgE. 

Option D: Chronic granulomatous disease presents with recurrent bacterial and fungal infections and absent respiratory burst.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with recurrent infections and easy bruising. On examination, he has partial albinism and nystagmus. Laboratory tests show neutropenia and impaired phagocytosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Chediak-Higashi syndrome is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by partial albinism, recurrent infections, and impaired phagocytosis due to abnormal lysosomal function in neutrophils and monocytes. Easy bruising and nystagmus are also common features.

Why are the other answers incorrect:

Option A: Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is characterized by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infections. 

Option C: X-linked agammaglobulinemia presents with recurrent bacterial infections, 

Option D: Hyper-IgM syndrome presents with recurrent bacterial infections and normal or elevated levels of IgM.

questions.text: A newborn presents with a non-blanching rash and bleeding from the gums and nose. The mother has a history of lupus and positive antiphospholipid antibodies. Which complication of neonatal lupus should be suspected?
questions.solution:
• Thrombocytopenia is a rare complication of neonatal lupus that can cause a non-blanching rash and bleeding from the gums and nose. It is caused by the transfer of antiphospholipid antibodies from the mother to the fetus, which can destroy platelets in the baby's blood.

Why the other answers are incorrect:

Option A: Neonatal lupus erythematosus is a different complication that causes a photosensitive rash, hepatosplenomegaly, and thrombocytopenia. 

Option C & D: Congenital heart block and pulmonary hypertension are not associated with bleeding symptoms.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a complaint of fever and cough. He is vitally stable. On examination, left lower lobe crepitation is heard. A diagnosis of pneumonia is made. Pneumonia is an acute lung parenchymal infection. The protective response is the invasion of neutrophils at the area of infection. A process known as NETosis is involved during the whole event of inflammation. Which of the following is least likely associated with the process of "NETosis"?

choices.text: Detected in blood in patients with sepsis
Plays a role in the pathogenesis of SLE

questions.solution:
Option B: Chromatin condensation

  • During NETosis, chromatin decondensation occurs.

Neutrophils extracellular traps:

  • Neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs) are characterised as extracellular DNA fibres comprised of histone and cytoplasmic granule proteins.
  • NETs were first described as an innate response against pathogen invasion, which can capture pathogens, degrade toxic bacterial factors, and kill bacteria. Additionally, NETs also provide a scaffold for protein and cell binding.
  • Protein binding to NETs activates the coagulation system, which participates in thrombosis.
  • In addition, NETs also can damage the tissues due to the proteins they carry.
  • Many studies have suggested that the excessive formation of NETs may contribute to various diseases, including thrombosis, atherosclerosis, autoimmune diseases, and sepsis.

Formation of NETs:

  • NETs are released by neutrophils in different forms depending on the specific assay employed and the stimuli used.
  • Presently, three NET formation pathways have been identified: vesicle-mediated, cell-lytic, and mitochondrial release.
  • The analysis of NET formation in vitro is complicated because neutrophils respond uniformly to strong NET instigators like PMA and ionomycin. Still, only a limited amount of neutrophils undergo NET formation in response to bacteria, fungi and LPS, leading to the presence of both unstimulated neutrophils and NETs in the same well.

The following hypotheses of NET formation have been proposed:

  • (1) Vesicle-mediated NET releases: under external stimulation with Staphylococcus aureus, the lobular nucleus of the neutrophil becomes round, and chromatin is uniformly concentrated in the nucleus. The nuclear membrane is then ruptured, and the vesicles wrapped with DNA move to the cell membrane. These vesicles subsequently fuse with the cell membrane and release the DNA in the vesicles, i.e., release NETs. Generally, NETs can be released within 30–60 min via vesicles
  • (2) Cell lytic: prototypical formation of NETs in response to PMA leads to cell lysis and requires more time (3–4 h). The nuclear membrane is enzymatically degraded upon external stimulation. The study reported that NE and MPO reportedly cooperate in nuclear lysis and chromatin decondensation in PMA-induced NET formation
  • (3) Mitochondrial DNA: Currently, few studies have reported that neutrophils release mitochondrial DNA to form NETs in a reactive oxygen species- (ROS-) dependent manner, while the detailed molecular mechanisms of mitochondrial DNA release are still unclear

Option A: Causes death of neutrophils

  • During NETosis, the nuclei of the neutrophils are lost, leading to the death of the cells.

Option C: Detected in blood in patients with sepsis

  • The process of NETosis has been found in patients with sepsis.

Option D: Plays a role in the pathogenesis of SLE

  • The nuclear chromatin in the NETs, which includes histones and associated DNA, has been postulated to be a source of nuclear antigens in systemic autoimmune diseases, particularly lupus, in which individuals react against their DNA and nucleoproteins

questions.text: A 37-years-old female is admitted to the emergency department with difficulty in breathing. Examination reveals significant laryngeal edema. Past medical history indicates that she suffers from recurrent episodes of angioneurotic edema with the release of histamine and other mediators. Which of the following statement related to the given mediator of acute inflammation is correct?

choices.text: Antibodies and complement products bind to specific mast cell receptors and trigger signalling pathways that induce degranulation to release histamine
It decreases the permeability of venules
Histamine H2 receptor antagonists are used to treat allergies

questions.solution:
Option A: Antibodies and complement products bind to specific mast cell receptors and trigger signalling pathways that induce degranulation to release histamine.

  • Histamine is a principal mediator of immediate transient response during acute inflammation.
  •  It is stored as a preformed molecule in the mast cells, normally in the connective tissue adjacent to blood vessels. It is thus among the first mediators released during inflammation.
  • It is present in mast cell granules and is released by degranulation in response to a variety of stimuli:
  • Physical injury such as cold, trauma, and heat.
  • Binding of antibodies to mast cells- that mediate immediate hypersensitivity reactions.
  • Anaphylatoxins C3a and C5a
  • Neuropeptides (substance P) and cytokines (IL-1, IL-8) also stimulate histamine release.

Option B: It causes constriction of arterioles.

  • It causes dilation of arterioles by relaxation of vascular smooth muscles that increases blood flow to the site of injury leading to erythema, one of the cardinal signs of inflammation.
  • It can cause contraction of some smooth muscles, such as in the lungs leading to bronchospasm.

Option C: It increases the permeability of venules

  • Histamine increases the permeability of venules, producing interendothelial gaps in postcapillary venules.

Option D: Histamine receptor antagonists are used to treat allergies.

  • Pharmacological significance -H1 receptor antagonists that bind to and block these histamine receptors are used to treat inflammatory reactions (allergies).
  • H2 receptor antagonists are used for the treatment of duodenal ulcers.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman who is 42 weeks pregnant is admitted to the labor and delivery ward for labor induction. A fetal heart monitor shows that the fetus is in no acute distress. Sterile examination shows the patient to be minimally dilated without significant effacement. She is given carboprost to induce uterine contraction. Which of the following eicosanoid will the medication represent?
questions.solution:
Option D: Prostaglandin F2a

  • Most tissues of the body produce prostaglandin F2a.
  • It is responsible for vasoconstriction and bronchoconstriction.
  • It helps to stimulate uterine contraction to induce labour.
  • PGF2a acts to cause the contraction of smooth muscles.

Option A: Prostaglandin I2

  • Prostaglandin I2 (prostacyclin) is produced in the endothelium of vessels from arachidonic acid under the action of the cyclooxygenase-2 enzyme.
  • It has the following functions:
  • Vasodilation
  • Inhibits platelet aggregation

Option B: Lipoxins

  • Lipoxins are generated from arachidonic acid by the lipoxygenase pathway, but they suppress inflammation by inhibiting the recruitment of leukocytes.
  • They inhibit the chemotaxis of neutrophils and adhesion to endothelium.
  • Leukocytes produce intermediates during the synthesis of lipoxins, which are converted to lipoxins by platelet interacting with leukocytes.

 

Option C: Leukotriene C4

  • Leukotriene C4 and its metabolites, LTD4 and LTE4, are produced mainly in mast cells.
  • It has the following functions that promote inflammation:
  • Contraction of smooth muscles
  • Bronchoconstriction
  • Intense Vasoconstriction
  • Increased permeability of venules
  • Cysteinyl leukotrienes make up a slow-reacting substance of anaphylaxis.
  • Involved in the pathophysiology of asthma and seasonal allergies.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presented in the medical outpatient department with a complaint of brief and abrupt unintentional, chaotic movements of hands and legs for the last 5 months. There is also a history of sustained and prolonged abnormal neck posture, declining cognitive function, and thinking ability. Her father was also diagnosed with a condition based on similar symptoms. She is vitally stable, and physical examination shows choreiform movements of all limbs and nystagmus. A plain MRI of the brain shows atrophy of the caudate nucleus. She is diagnosed with a genetic disorder that does not follow Mendelian inheritance. Which of the following is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Huntington's disease

  • Huntington's disease, also known as Huntington's chorea, is a neurodegenerative disease which is mostly inherited. 
  • The initial symptoms include a general lack of coordination followed by an unsteady gait. It affects the basal ganglia and results in hyperkinetic movement disorder and chorea. 
  • Huntington’s disease is classically inherited from an affected parent carrying a mutant Huntington gene. The Huntington gene codes for a specific protein known as the Huntington protein. Expansion of CAG (cytosine-adenine-guanine) repeats, known as a trinucleotide repeat expansion in the gene coding for the Huntington protein, produces an abnormal mutant protein, which steadily damages neurons.
  • This disease follows Non-Mendelian inheritance because it is a trinucleotide repeat disorder.
  • Non-Mendelian inheritance is a pattern of inheritance in which traits do not segregate according to Mendel's law of inheritance. These laws define the inheritance of traits linked to single genes on chromosomes.
  • According to Mendelian inheritance law, each parent contributes one of two possible alleles for a particular trait.
  • Suppose the genotypes of both parents in a genetic cross are known. In that case, Mendel's laws can be applied to determine the distribution of phenotypes expected in the offspring if the genotypes of both parents in a genetic cross are known.
  • Other types of Non-Mendelian inheritance are incomplete dominance, Co-dominance, Extranuclear inheritance, polygenic traits, gene conversion, genomic imprinting and mosaicism.

Option B: Myotonic dystrophy

  • Although myotonic dystrophy is a trinucleotide repeat disorder that follows non-Mendelian inheritance, the given clinical picture and neuroimaging do not suggest this disorder.
  • It is characterised by progressive muscle weakness and wasting.
  • Individuals with myotonic dystrophy experience prolonged muscle contraction and cannot relax certain muscles after contraction.

Option C: Fragile X syndrome

  • Although Fragile X syndrome is also a trinucleotide repeat disorder that follows non-Mendelian inheritance, the given clinical picture and neuroimaging are not suggestive of this disorder.
  • This disorder usually affects younger individuals, particularly during adolescence.
  • Clinical findings include intellectual disability, abnormal facial features and hypotonia. Recurrent otitis media and sinusitis are common in childhood.

Option D: Friedrich’s ataxia

  • Although Friedrich’s ataxia is also a trinucleotide repeat disorder that follows non-Mendelian inheritance, the given clinical picture and neuroimaging do not suggest this disorder.
  • This disorder usually affects younger individuals, particularly during adolescence.
  • Clinical findings include difficulty walking, impaired speech and a loss of sensation in the arms and legs; many individuals develop hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presented to the physician's office complaining of sore throat, fever and fatigue for the past few days. On physical examination, the tonsils have erythema and white exudate and are bilaterally enlarged. After further testing, the virus was identified. This virus also uses the LMP-1 gene for inducing oncogenesis. Which of the following virus is responsible for the disease?
questions.solution:
Option C:  Epstein Barr virus

Epstein-Barr virus

  • Oncogenic viruses causing tumours are Human papillomavirus (HPV), Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), Kaposi sarcoma (HHV-8), Polyomavirus, and Hepatitis B virus (HBV).
  • Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is a herpes virus linked to human cancers. Associated cancers include Burkitt lymphoma, Nasopharyngeal carcinoma and T-cell lymphoma.
  • The EBV uses the complement receptor CD21 to attach to and infect the B-cells. As a result, such infection leads to polyclonal B-cell proliferation and the generation of immortal B-lymphoblastoid cell lines.
  • One EBV-encoded gene, LMP-1 (latent membrane protein 1), acts as an oncogene that induces B-cell lymphomas by promoting B-cell proliferation. LMP-1 signalling leads to the up-regulation of antiapoptotic proteins and provides growth signals in latently infected cells.
  • Therefore, it mimics the effect of CD-40 (which is normally activated by interaction with CD-40 ligands on the T-cells). Therefore, LMP-1 stimulates signalling through the NF-κB and JAK-STAT pathways using the cell's own replication pathway to expand the infected pool of cells. Another protein EBNA-2 transactivates several host genes, including cyclin D and the SRC family of proto-oncogenes.

 

Option A: Human T-cell leukaemia virus type-1

  • HTLV-1 causes adult T-cell leukaemia/lymphoma as it has a tropism for CD4+ T-cells and promotes neoplastic transformation. The tax gene produces the tax protein, essential for viral replication as it stimulates transcription of viral RNA from the 5' long terminal repeat. Also, Tax alters the transcription of several host cell genes and interacts with cell signalling proteins. As a result, there is increased survival and growth of infected cells.

Option B: Hepatitis B virus

  • The Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is responsible for hepatocellular carcinomas.
  • The Hepatitis B virus encodes proteins which promote cancer development. The HBV genome contains gene HBx and can activate transcription factors and signal transduction pathways interfering with p53 function.
  • Also, the viral DNA/RNA is integrated within the human genome, causing the deletion of genes and leading to the formation of mutations.
  • The chronic inflammation promotes tumorigenesis due to the hepatocellular injury, which generates the regenerative process by growth factors, cytokines and chemokines as well as reactive oxygen species that are genotoxic and mutagenic, e.g. NFκB pathway activation, which blocks apoptosis and accumulates mutations leading to hepatocellular carcinoma.

Option D: Human papilloma virus (HPV)

  • HPV high-risk viruses encode oncogenic proteins E6 and E7 that inactivate RB and p53 genes, activate cyclin/CDK complexes and combat cellular senescence. Therefore, HPV proteins promote cancer.

questions.text: You are an intern in the obstetrics & gynaecology department; you receive a case of term teenage pregnancy in labor with cephalopelvic disproportion. Your resident doctor instructs you to get the blood investigations done ready as the patient is to be taken for an emergency lower segment cesarian section (LSCS) procedure, especially since the resident asked u to get the blood grouping and Rh typing done first. Which of the following potentially represents the most dangerous situation?
questions.solution:
Option B: Rh-ve mother with 2nd Rh+ve child

  • Rh-ve mother with 2nd Rh+ve child can result in the development of hemolytic disease in a newborn or erythroblastosis fetalis. Therefore, it is a dangerous condition.
  • In hemolytic disease of the fetus and newborn (erythroblastosis fetalis), there is an antigenic difference between the mother and the fetus, and IgG anti-erythrocyte antibodies from the mother cross the placenta cause destruction of fetal red cells.
  • This condition is a type II hypersensitivity reaction.
  • This is Not to be confused with Hemorrhagic disease of the newborn, which is a coagulation disturbance in newborns due to vitamin K deficiency. As a consequence of vitamin K deficiency, there is impaired production of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, X, C, and S by the liver.

Option A: Rh+ve mother with 2nd Rh-ve child

  • The foetus of Rh+ve mothers is not at risk of developing erythroblastosis fetalis.
  • Maternal-sensitized antibodies are not formed because the foetus has no Rh antigen.

Option C: Rh+ve mother with 1st Rh-ve child

  • Foetus of Rh+ve mothers is not at risk of developing erythroblastosis fetalis.
  • Maternal-sensitized antibodies are not formed because the foetus has no Rh antigen.

Option D: Rh-ve mother with 1st Rh+ve child

  • First Rh +ve child of an Rh –ve mother is at very low risk of developing erythroblastosis fetalis because foetal Rh+ cells pass to the maternal circulation and trigger anti- Rh+ antibodies.
  • These sensitized anti-Rh+ antibodies accumulate in the maternal circulation.
  • In a subsequent pregnancy, if the foetus is Rh+, the anti-Rh+ antibodies pass through the placenta and trigger hemolytic disease of the newborn.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a complaint of increased hunger, increased thirst, and increased urination. Blood and urine glucose tests are suggestive of diabetes. The physician suspects type I diabetes in this patient, which is caused by T-cell mediated destruction of Islets of Langerhans cells. Which of the following is/are an example of type IV hypersensitivity?
questions.solution:
Option D: Contact dermatitis

  • Contact dermatitis is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Common triggers are poison ivy/oak, nickel dyes, topical medication, and skin care products.
  • Patients with pruritic, erythematous plaque, vesicles, and bullae developed a few days after contact, which triggers develop allergic contact dermatitis.
  • In sensitized individuals, the rash develops within 4-96 hours of exposure. 
  • In previously unexposed individuals, it may not be seen for 3 weeks.
  • The typical rash, as seen in this patient, is usually limited to exposed skin, frequently forming linear streaks where the skin has brushed against plant leaves.

Option A: Anaphylaxis

  • Anaphylaxis is a type I hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Type I is mediated by IgE, and it flares up within minutes.
  • The symptoms range from rashes to anaphylactic shock with vasodilation hypotension and bronchiolar spasm.
  • Foreign proteins (e.g., antisera), hormones, enzymes, polysaccharides, drugs (e.g., the antibiotic penicillin), food allergens (e.g., peanuts, shell), or insect toxins can trigger in sensitized individuals.

Option B: Rheumatic fever

  • It is an immune-mediated type II hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Antibodies to M protein cross-react with self-antigens, often myosin, due to molecular mimicry.

Option C: Myasthenia gravis

  • Myasthenia gravis is an example of a type II hypersensitivity reaction
  • Caused by antibodies against the acetylcholine receptor.

questions.text: A pure protein derivative obtained from Mycobacterium tuberculosis is injected into the skin during the physical examination of a 22-year-old male. The injection site seems elevated and indurated three days later. In this patient's delayed hypersensitive initiation phase, which of the following glycoproteins was directly engaged in antigen presentation?
questions.solution:
Option D: Class II HLA molecules

  • The prototype of T cell-mediated inflammation is delayed-type hypersensitivity.
  • The classic example of delayed-type hypersensitivity is the tuberculin reaction, which is produced by the intracutaneous injection of purified protein derivative (PPD, also called tuberculin), a protein-containing antigen of the tubercle bacillus. 
  • In previously sensitized individuals, reddening and induration of the site appear in the 8 to 12 hours, reach a peak in the 24 to 72 hours, and thereafter slowly subside.
  • Delayed-type hypersensitivity is defined as a tissue reaction involving lymphocytes and mononuclear phagocytes, which occurs in response to a soluble protein antigen and reaches the greatest intensity 24 to 48 hours after the initiation phase.
  • In the initial phase, foreign protein antigens or chemical ligands interact with accessory cells bearing class II HLA molecules.
  • Protein antigens are actively processed into the short peptides within phagolysosomes and are presented on the cell surface in conjunction with the class II HLA molecules.

Option A: Class III HLA molecules

  • HLA/MHC class III genes produce proteins that play a part in inflammatory reactions, such as complement system components and tumor necrosis factors, not HLA proteins. 

Option B: Non-HLA-dependent antigen presentation

  • All exogenous antigens (e.g., bacterial proteins) are presented to CD4+ helper T cells via MHC-II.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option C: Class I HLA molecules

  • Class I MHC molecules display peptides that are derived from proteins, such as viral and tumor antigens, that are located in the cytoplasm and usually produced in the cell, and class I associated peptides are recognized by CD8+ T lymphocytes. 
  • Cytoplasmic proteins are degraded in proteasomes, and peptides are transported into the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) where the peptides bind to newly synthesized class I molecules. 
  • Peptide-loaded MHC molecules associate with β2-microglobulin to form a stable trimer that is transported to the cell surface.

questions.text: A 1-year-old infant is being evaluated in the clinic for failure to thrive. On examination, an abdominal mass with an irregular border crossing the midline is palpated. Imaging reveals an abdominal mass crossing midline encasing the aorta and inferior vena cava, along with calcifications and lytic bone metastasis. Image-guided needle aspiration of the mass shows small round blue cells and Homer Wright rosettes. Which of the following is not a poor prognostic factor of the most probable diagnosis described here?
questions.solution:
Option C: Evidence of gangliocytic differentiation

  • The infant has presented with an abdominal mass that has irregular borders and crosses the midline, along with a history of failure to thrive. These features are suggestive of neuroblastoma. Furthermore, the pathological findings of small round blue cells and Homer-Wright rosettes also indicate neuroblastoma.
  • Homer-Wright rosettes are structures in which the tumour cells are concentrically arranged around a central space filled with neuropil, as shown below:

  • All the risk factors described in the option are indicators of poor prognosis except Gangliocytic differentiation. Gangliocytic differentiation is a good prognostic factor for neuroblastomas.
  • The list of unfavourable prognostic factors in neuroblastoma is given below:
    • Stages 3, 4
    • Age >18 months
    • Absence of evidence of schwannian stroma and gangliocytic differentiation
    • High Mitosis-karyorrhexis index (>200/5000 cells)
    • Near-diploid (segmental chromosome losses; chromothripsis)
    • MYCN Amplified
    • Chromosome 1p loss
    • Chromosome 11q loss
    • Absent TRKA expression
    • Presence of TRKB expression
    • Mutations of neuritogenesis genes

Option A: MYCN amplification

  • MYCN is a proto-oncogene, and its amplification is a poor prognostic factor for neuroblastoma.
  • The presence of MYCN amplification shifts the tumour into a high-risk category, irrespective of age, stage, or histology.

Option B: High mitosis-karyorrhexis index

  • The mitotic karyorrhexis index is described as the number of mitotic or karyorrhectic cells per 5000 tumour cells in random foci.
  • A mitosis-karyorrhexis index of >200/5000 cells is a marker of a bad prognosis.

Option D: Mutations of neuritogenesis genes

  • Neuritogenesis is a process characterized by the formation and extension of the neurites. The mutations in the genes regulating this process are an unfavourable prognostic marker for neuroblastoma.

questions.text: A 48-Year-old male, a chronic alcoholic, presents to the hospital with sudden onset fever, chills, and rigour. He underwent a liver transplant 2 weeks ago after developing liver cirrhosis and fulminant hepatic failure. His heart rate is 110/min, respirations are 25/min, and SpO2 is 87%. All of the following regarding the condition described above is true, except?

choices.text: CD8+ T-cells directly destroy the graft
It is the principal cause of early graft failure
Preformed antibodies against graft are the main causative factor
Cytokines secreted by CD4+ T-cells cause inflammation which destroys the graft

questions.solution:
Option C: Preformed antibodies against graft are the main causative factor

  • This patient’s presentation with fever, chills and rigour 2 weeks after the hepatic transplant is most likely due to Acute graft rejection.
  • Acute graft rejection does not occur due to preformed antibodies.
  • Preformed antibodies play a role in hyperacute graft rejection, which occurs within minutes to hours, not days to weeks.
  • Graft rejection that is severe: It happens days or weeks after transplantation and is the leading cause of graft failure.
  • There are two types of divisions: CD8+ CTLs may directly destroy graft cells in acute cellular rejection, or CD4+ cells produce cytokines and cause inflammation, damaging the graft.
  • Antibodies attach to vascular endothelium and activate complement via the classical pathway in acute antibody-mediated (vascular or humoral)

 

Option A: CD8+ T-cells directly destroy the graft

  • Acute graft rejection is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Acute graft rejection can occur when CD8+ Cytotoxic T-Lymphocytes directly destroy graft cells in acute cellular rejection.

Option B: It is the principal cause of early graft failure

  • Early graft rejection is mainly due to acute graft rejection.
  • It commonly occurs in weeks to months.

Option D: Cytokines secreted by CD4+ T-cells cause inflammation which destroys the graft

  • Cytokines by CD4+ T-cells cause inflammation.
  • It results in acute graft rejection.
  • Biopsy shows vasculitis of the graft vessels.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presented to an outpatient clinic with a six-month history of shortness of breath. His blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg, and his pulse is 85/minute. On the X-ray of the chest, there is evidence of hilar lymphadenopathy. The biopsy revealed the presence of non-caseating granulomas. Lab results show hypercalcemia. Which of the following pathogenic mechanisms is involved in sarcoidosis development?

choices.text: Intra-alveolar and interstitial accumulation of CD8+ T cells
Increased levels of T cell-derived TH1 cytokines such as IL-2 and IFN-γ
Decreased levels of cytokines in the local environment IL-8, TNF
Decreased the level of ACE enzyme

questions.solution:
Option B: Increased levels of T cell-derived TH1 cytokines such as IL-2 and IFN-γ

  • Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disease that affects multiple organs throughout the body. 
  • Multiple immune abnormalities are involved in the pathogenesis of sarcoidosis.
  • CD4+ T cell accumulation in intra-alveolar and interstitial spaces
    • Increase the CD4/CD8 T cell ratio to 15:1 from 5:1. 
    • The antigen-driven proliferation of T -cell subsets 
  • Increased levels of TH1 cytokines derived from T cells, such as IL-2 and IFN- γ
    • T cells proliferation 
    • Activation of macrophage
  • Increased cytokine production (IL-8, TNF, and macrophage inflammatory protein) 
    • Activated macrophages release TNF
    • Recruitment of T cells and macrophages 
    • Formation of granulomas
  • Dendritic cell dysfunction
    • It acts as antigen-presenting cells. 
  • Sarcoidosis is also linked to family history, and certain HLA genotypes (HLA-A1 and HLA-B8) are more susceptible. 
  • Sarcoidosis is characterized by a TH1-type immune response, with increased levels of cytokines such as IL-2 and IFN-γ. These cytokines contribute to the formation of granulomas in affected tissues.

Option A: Intra-alveolar and interstitial accumulation of CD8+ T cells

  • Sarcoidosis causes the development of non-caseating granulomas. 
  • The pathogenesis of this disease is mediated by CD4+ T cells. 
  • While T cells are involved in sarcoidosis, it is primarily CD4+ T cells that accumulate in the granulomas seen in sarcoidosis, not CD8+ T cells.

Option C: Decreased levels of cytokines in the local environment IL-8, TNF

  • The pathogenesis of sarcoidosis involves an increase in cytokine production. 
  • An increase in IL-8 and TNF promotes the formation of granulomas. 
  • In sarcoidosis, there is often an increase in pro-inflammatory cytokines, including TNF (tumor necrosis factor). Decreased levels of these cytokines are not characteristic of sarcoidosis

Option D: Decreased the level of ACE enzyme 

  • ACE enzyme levels are increased in sarcoidosis. 
  • ACE converts angiotension I to angiotensin II. 
  • Sarcoidosis can lead to an increased level of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) in the blood, not decreased levels. Measuring ACE levels is sometimes used as a diagnostic marker for sarcoidosis.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency room with progressive atrophy and weakness in his hands. On further examination, he is found to have brisk jaw jerk, fasciculations, spasticity of the lower leg and bulbar palsy. He is diagnosed with a case of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, which is caused by which of the following?

choices.text: Loss of upper motor neurons in the cerebral cortex and lower motor neurons in the spinal cord and brainstem.
Loss of dopaminergic neurons from the substantia nigra

questions.solution:
Option A: Loss of upper motor neurons in the cerebral cortex and lower motor neurons in the spinal cord and brainstem.

  • Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis/Lou Gehrig's disease
  • Progressive nervous system disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and the spinal cord results in loss of muscle control.
  • Loss of upper motor neurons in the cerebral cortex and lower motor neurons in the spinal cord and brainstem.
  • The diagnosis is based on clinical criteria in which there are both Upper and lower motor neuron signs with progressive disease.

Option B: Atrophy of the caudate nucleus

  • Degeneration & atrophy of the caudate nucleus is associated with Huntington's disease. 
  • It is an autosomal dominant disorder
  • It is a fatal, progressive degeneration and atrophy of the Striatum (Caudate nucleus and Putamen).
  • Characterised by an increased number of trinucleotide repeats (CAG) in the Huntington gene on the short arm of chromosome 4.

Option C: Loss of dopaminergic neurons from the substantia nigra

  • Parkinson's disease is characterised by a degenerative loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra of the basal ganglia.
  • In Parkinson's disease, histology reveals loss of pigmented neurons in the substantia nigra and round, eosinophilic inclusions of an α-synuclein protein (Lewy bodies) in affected neurons.
  • Clinical features are tremors, rigidity, akinesia/bradykinesia and postural instability.
  • Dementia is a common feature of the late disease.
  • Early onset dementia is suggestive of “Lewy body dementia.”

Option D: Deposition of Tau protein

  • Tau is a microtubule-associated protein
  • Neurofibrillary tangles are intracellular aggregates of fibres composed of hyperphosphorylated tau protein
  • These are seen in Alzheimer's disease.
  • Alzheimer’s disease is the most common cause of dementia.
  • Morphological features include cerebral atrophy with narrowing of the gyri, widening of sulci, and dilation of the ventricles.
  • Neuritic plaques are extracellular core comprised of Aβ amyloid with entangled neuritic processes.
  • Aβ amyloid is derived from amyloid precursor protein (APP) which normally undergoes alpha cleavage; beta cleavage results in Aβ amyloid.
  • Neurofibrillary tangles are intracellular aggregates of fibres composed of hyperphosphorylated tau protein.
  • Loss of cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman has hypertension with headache, diaphoresis, and palpitation. She does not complain of any weight gain. She further states that his symptoms are episodic. Which diagnostic procedures would be most useful in evaluating the possibility that pheochromocytoma might cause these findings?
questions.solution:
Option C: Urinary vanillylmandelic acid

  • Urinary vanillylmandelic acid & metanephrines are metabolites of epinephrine & norepinephrine: Markedly elevated in pheochromocytoma.

Pheochromocytoma:

  • A pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumour that typically develops in the adrenal medulla.
  • Pheochromocytomas are usually benign (∼ 90% of cases) but may also be malignant.
  • Classic clinical features are due to excess sympathetic nervous system stimulation and involve episodic blood pressure crises with paroxysmal headaches, diaphoresis, heart palpitations, and pallor.
  • However, pheochromocytomas may also be asymptomatic or manifest with persistent hypertension.
  • Elevated catecholamine metabolites in the plasma or urine confirm the diagnosis, while imaging studies in patients with positive biochemistry are used to determine the tumour's location.
  • Surgical resection is the treatment of choice but is only carried out once alpha-adrenergic blockade with phenoxybenzamine has become effective.

Option A: Serum C-peptide

  • Serum C peptide is used to evaluate insulin production from the pancreas in diabetic patients.
  • It is released along with insulin in equal quantity from the pancreas
  • A low level indicates insufficient production of insulin

Option B: Serum calcitonin

  • Used to evaluate hypocalcemia causes.
  • Calcitonin is produced by the thyroid gland, which lowers calcium levels.

Option D: Serum aldosterone

  • Serum aldosterone is high in conn syndrome.
  • However, it is not used; there is persistent, not episodic, hypertension in conn syndrome

questions.text: A patient on ATT missed his doses continuously & he presents to the medicine OPD, with high-grade fever and cough. He also mentioned night sweats. The physician asked for a biopsy to be done from the apical part of the lung. Microscopical findings revealed, necrosed focus, eosinophilic material & The surrounding tissue shows characteristic granulomatous inflammatory reaction consisting of epithelioid cells. What is suggestive of these findings?
questions.solution:
Option C

  • Caseous necrosis is the correct answer to the question as it refers to the specific type of necrosis characterized by the formation of a cheese-like material. Caseous necrosis is commonly seen in tuberculosis infections(which can be ruled out by the ATT & other symptoms), where the body's immune system forms a granuloma around the bacteria, forming caseous necrosis. In caseous necrosis, the affected tissue becomes friable and resembles cheese or cottage cheese. 
  • Grossly, foci of caseous necrosis resemble dry cheese and are soft, granular and yellowish. This appearance is partly attributed to the histotoxic effects of lipopolysaccharides present in the capsule of the tubercle bacilli, Mycobacterium tuberculosis. 
  • Microscopically, centre of the necrosed focus contain structureless, eosinophilic material having scattered granular debris of disintegrated nuclei (Fig. 2.23). The surrounding tissue shows characteristic granulomatous inflammatory reaction consisting of epithelioid cells (modified macro phages having slipper-shaped vesicular nuclei), interspersed giant cells of Langhans and foreign body type and peripheral mantle of lymphocytes.

Why Others Are Incorrect

Option A: Coagulative necrosis is not the correct answer to the question because the formation of a cheese-like material does not characterize it. Coagulative necrosis is where the affected tissue architecture is preserved, but the cells undergo denaturation due to ischemia (lack of blood supply). 

Option B: Liquefactive necrosis is not the correct answer to the question because it does not refer to the specific type of necrosis characterized by the formation of a cheese-like material. Liquefactive necrosis occurs in tissues with a high concentration of hydrolytic enzymes, such as the brain, where the affected tissue becomes liquefied due to these enzymes' breakdown of cells and tissues. 

Option D: Fat necrosis is not the correct answer to the question because it does not refer to the specific type of necrosis characterized by the formation of a cheese-like material. Fat necrosis occurs in adipose (fat) tissue due to trauma or injury, such as in breast tissue after a breast biopsy or abdominal trauma.

questions.text: On reviewing a slide, a first-year pathology resident finds out these histopathology findings: necrotizing inflammation of the tissues & vessels, with or without granulomas with lymphocytes, epithelioid cells, and giant cells. Which rare autoimmune disorder does she write as the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Wegener granulomatosis, or granulomatosis with polyangiitis, is a rare autoimmune disorder that causes inflammation in blood vessels and organs. The condition can affect various organs, including the lungs, kidneys, and upper respiratory tract, and if left untreated, it can be life-threatening. 

Why Others are incorrect 

Option A Rheumatoid arthritis: Although rheumatoid arthritis is also an autoimmune disorder, it does not cause the same type of inflammation in blood vessels and organs as Wegener granulomatosis. Rheumatoid arthritis primarily affects the joints, causing pain, stiffness, and swelling, and it can lead to joint damage and disability if left untreated. 

Option B Lupus: Lupus is also an autoimmune disorder that primarily affects the skin, joints, and organs such as the kidneys and heart. While lupus can cause inflammation in blood vessels, it does not typically cause the same inflammation in the upper respiratory tract and lungs as Wegener granulomatosis. 

Option D Multiple sclerosis: Multiple sclerosis is a chronic autoimmune disorder that affects the central nervous system, causing a wide range of symptoms such as vision problems, muscle weakness, and difficulty with coordination and balance. While multiple sclerosis can cause inflammation in the blood vessels, it does not typically cause the same inflammation in the upper respiratory tract and lungs as Wegener granulomatosis.

questions.text: A women, 32 years old, presented in the OPD after 2 weeks of fever, malaise & weight loss. She had her reports from the pathologists which showed panarteritis characterized by mononuclear cells and occasionally giant cells, with marked intimal hyperplasia, medial and adventitial thickening, and, in the chronic form, fibrotic occlusion. This was the 3rd time in 1.5 months of her symptoms. What would be the primary cause of such presentation?
questions.solution:
Option C: Takayasu's arteritis is a rare autoimmune disease that mainly affects young women, causing inflammation of the large blood vessels, leading to narrowing, blockage, or weakening of the vessels. Depending on which arteries are affected, this condition can result in various symptoms, such as fatigue, fever, muscle pain, high blood pressure, and stroke. 

Why Others are incorrect

Option A: Temporal arteritis

  • Multiple sclerosis - It is an autoimmune disease that affects the central nervous system and damages the myelin sheath surrounding nerve fibers, causing a range of symptoms such as muscle weakness, difficulty with coordination and balance, and vision problems. However, Multiple sclerosis does not primarily cause inflammation of the large blood vessels, which is a hallmark feature of Takayasu's arteritis. 

Option B: Systemic lupus erythematosus: It is an autoimmune disease affecting multiple organs and tissues, including the skin, joints, kidneys, and blood vessels. It can cause inflammation of the small blood vessels but not the large ones, a distinguishing feature of Takayasu's arteritis. While Systemic lupus erythematosus affects more women than men, it is not primarily a disease of young women, as Takayasu's arteritis is. 

Option D: Rheumatoid arthritis: It is an autoimmune disease that primarily affects the joints, causing inflammation, pain, and stiffness. It can also affect other body parts, such as the lungs and blood vessels. However, Rheumatoid arthritis does not cause inflammation of the large blood vessels, which is a characteristic feature of Takayasu's arteritis. Also, Rheumatoid arthritis affects people of all ages, whereas Takayasu's arteritis primarily affects young women.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male visits his dentist regarding loosening teeth. A more detailed check-up reveals his gums are swollen, purple, and spongy. Physical examination reveals multiple splinter hemorrhages near the distal ends of the nail on the patient’s fingers, and wound healing is improper in this patient. Which of the following vitamins is this patient deficient in?
questions.solution:
Vitamin C acts as a cofactor for the enzyme lysyl and prolyl hydroxylase which is necessary for post translation modification of collagen by hydroxylating the proline and lysine residue.

These hydroxylated residues are necessary for hydrogen bonding between different collagen chains and hence provide strength to collagen fibers.

Vitamin C deficiency leads to defective post-translational modification of collagen → loss of tensile strength of blood vessels leading to:

  • Bleeding gums
  • Ecchymoses
  • Easy bruisability
  • Poor wound healing (Features of scurvy).

questions.text: All of the following processes require vitamin B7 as a cofactor except:

choices.text: Propionyl CoA to Methyl Malonyl CoA

questions.solution:
Biotin (Vitamin B7) is required mainly in carboxylation reactions

  • Acetyl CoA to Malonyl CoA is done by enzyme Acetyl CoA carboxylase.
  • Pyruvate to Oxaloacetate is done by enzyme Pyruvate carboxylase.
  • Propionyl CoA to Methyl Malonyl CoA is done by enzyme Propionyl CoA carboxylase.

→ Glutamate to GABA conversion is a simple decarboxylation reaction, which requires vitamin B6 i.e. Pyridoxine.

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION ON BIOTIN:

  • Biotin is a prosthetic group for all carboxylases.
  • But there are few carboxylation reactions which do not require Biotin. They are :
  1. CPS-I and II (Carbamoyl Phosphate Synthetase ).
  2. CO2 addition in C6 of purines.
  3. Pyruvate (3C) to Malate (4C) conversion by Malic enzyme Gamma Carboxylation of Glutamate (Vitamin K required, not Biotin).

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with his wife, complaining that her husband has not "been himself lately." He sees visuals and hears voices, makes up scenarios that never happened, and has lost weight. On gross examination, the physician can appreciate the muscle wasting. The physician diagnoses him as having a deficiency of a particular vitamin. The physician can trace the origin of his symptoms to all of the following conditions except:
questions.solution:
Option B: Homocystinuria

  • This patient with audio-visual hallucinations, psychosis, confabulations, and muscle wasting; most likely suffers from Beriberi, which occurs secondary to a deficiency of vitamin B1 (thiamine).
  • In comparison, Homocystinuria most commonly occurs secondary to the deficiency of enzyme cystathionine synthase.
  • It is characterized by individuals having:
    • Marfanoid features
    • Fair complexion
    • Ectopia lentis
    • Progressive intellectual disability
    • Behavioral disorders
    • Thromboembolism and osteoporosis can occur as complications.
  • Symptom improvement in these patients has been documented on supplementation with vitamin B6, vitamin B9, and vitamin B12.

Option A: Food faddism

  • It is generally used to describe a particular food or group eaten excessively in the routine diet or eliminated to cure one specific disease.
  • A person believing this may exclude thiamine-containing food in their diet and consequently may get thiamine deficiency.

Option C: Chronic alcoholism

  • It can cause thiamine deficiency as alcohol interferes with the absorption of thiamine.
  • Wernicke encephalopathy is caused by thiamine deficiency presenting as ataxia, ophthalmoplegia, and confusion. Symptoms are due to atrophy of the mammillary bodies.
  • It is advised to administer thiamine before dextrose in patients with alcohol overuse disorder or malnutrition to reduce the risk of Wernicke encephalopathy.

Option D: Chronic loop diuretics use

  • Thiamine deficiency in patients with chronic loop diuretic use is due to increased urine volume and urinary flow rate.
  • Furosemide may directly interfere with thiamine reuptake at the cellular level.
  • Heart failure patients on chronic loop diuretic therapy may be advised to take thiamine supplementation.

questions.text:
Assertion: FIGLU excretion test is done to determine the folic acid deficiency.

Reason: FIGLU is the intermediate of histidine metabolism and needs tetrahydrofolic acid (THF).

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion
Assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the reason is independently a false/incorrect statement
Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the reason is independently a true/correct statement.

questions.solution:
• Folate is required for the conversion of FIGLU (Form Imino Glutamate) to Glutamate.
  • FIGLU is accumulated in folic acid deficiency
  • This is the basis of FIGLU excretion test (aka Histidine load test)

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the clinic when his mother notices orange crystals in his diaper. He is behind on his motor and verbal milestones. Examination shows increased muscle tone, joint swelling, and healing wounds on his lips. Excretion of which of the following products is increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: a

  • Figure ‘a’ shows the double-ringed structure of uric acid, the end product of purine metabolism in humans.
  • This patient’s presentation with orange crystals in his diaper, mental retardation, dystonia, self-mutilation, and joint swelling is consistent with Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.
  • Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is caused by a complete absence of the HGPRT enzyme which is required by the cells to salvage IMP and GMP from hypoxanthine and xanthine, respectively.
  • Due to the impaired salvage pathway, the purines are shunted to the excretion pathway and converted to uric acid.
  • Decreased salvage of purines also increases the de novo synthesis of purines which are further shunted to the excretion pathway, increasing the uric acid excretion.

Option B: b

  • Figure ‘b’ shows the structure of urea, the end product of amino acid metabolism in humans. It has two amino groups bonded to a ketone group.
  • Urea is produced to excrete nitrogenous waste in a less toxic form than ammonia. Uric acid, not urea, is excreted in increased amounts in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.
  • Increased urea excretion is observed in pregnancy.

Option C: c

  • Figure ‘c’ shows the structure of thymine. It has a pyrimidine ring with a carbon and nitrogen skeleton and a methyl side group.
  • Urine thymine excretion is increased in increased gut motility.

Option D: d

  • Figure ‘d’ shows the structure of beta-alanine or 3-amino propionic acid.
  • It is a byproduct of dihydrouracil and carnosine metabolism. It is not excreted in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.
  • Urine excretion of beta-alanine is increased in the defect of malonic semialdehyde metabolism.

questions.text: A person came to the laboratory for testing FBS. His fasting blood sugar was 126 mg/dL. He gave a history of intake of heavy meals the previous night. Which of the following changes have occurred in the body of the person once he has tea and snack right after giving blood for the investigation?

choices.text: The body enters fed state after 1 hour of having food
The GLUT 1 transporter binds to the plasma membrane and transports glucose in an insulin dependent fashion in the skeletal muscles.
