The beta cells of pancreas gets activated and secrete insulin
Gluconeogenesis sets in to produce enough glucose to the brain

questions.solution:
When we have food, the body enters right away into the fed state. The level of glucose in the blood rises. The beta cells of pancreas get stimulated thus in response to raised blood sugar level and secrete insulin. 

Why the others are incorrect 

Option  A: The body enters the fed state right away when you have food. 
The fed state can last for about 4 hours of having food. 

Option B: the glucose transporters are GLUT1 to GLUT4. GLUT 4 is the insulin dependent glucose transporter present in the skeletal muscle. 
It binds to the plasma membrane in response to insulin and transports glucose into the skeletal muscle. So, insulin has to be secreted first in order for GLUT transporters to work. They can be stored as glycogen in the muscle. 

Option D: Gluconeogenesis sets in the state of fasting to provide enough glucose to the brain. 
It occurs in the fasting state and not in the fed state.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true for fatty acid oxidation

choices.text: Beta oxidation takes place in peroxisomes
Alpha oxidation occurs in every cell of the body
Peroxisomal oxidation is for small chain fatty acids
Omega oxidation is minor type of fatty acid oxidation taking place in absence of beta oxidation

questions.solution:
Fatty acid oxidation are mainly mitochondrial (beta) and Peroxisomal. Omega oxidation is minor type of fatty acid oxidation taking place in absence of beta oxidation 

Why the others are incorrect 
Option A: Beta oxidation takes place in mitochondria 
Option B: Alpha oxidation occurs in brain and liver 
Option C: Peroxisomal oxidation is mainly for long chain fatty acids

questions.text: A person was traveling by ship on a world tour. There were only a few staple foods kept in the ship. He consumed polished rice for one month. After one month he developed mental confusions and peripheral neuritis. Which of the following vitamin deficiency is attributed to the symptoms presented ?
questions.solution:
Polishing of rice removes vitamin B1 or thiamine. The deficiency leads to beri beri. Dry beri beri presents mainly with CNS manifestations like mental confusion, ataxia and peripheral neuritis. 

Why the others are incorrect 
Option A: Vitamin C deficiency leads to scurvy with bleeding of gums 
Option B: Vitamin K deficiency leads to bleeding manifestations 
Option C: Vitamin B 12 deficiency leads to muscle weakness, peripheral neuropathy

questions.text: PFK2 is a tandem enzyme with opposite enzymatic activities. It is a regulator of glycolysis and gluconeogenesis. Which of the following is true about fructose 2,6 bisphosphate, which is a product of PFK2 ?
questions.solution:
Glycolysis and gluconeogenesis are regulated by a common allosteric regulator - fructose 2,6 bisphosphate. It activates glycolysis - PFK1 and inhibits gluconeogenesis. 

Why the others are incorrect:

Option A: fructose 2,6 bisphosphate activate glycolysis by activating PFK 1- phosphofructokinase

Option B: It inhibits gluconeogenesis by inhibiting fructose 1,6 bisphosphate 

Option D: Upregulation of both pathways are a result of dysregulation. In a starving person if glycolysis sets in it leads to futile or vas cycle

questions.text:
A 35 y old male came with recurrent history of fever. On examination there was generalized lymphadenopathy. His CD4 count was low. 
PCR was done for identification of HIV. 
The first step in the polymerase chain reaction requires a temperature of
questions.solution:
The first step in polymerase chain reaction is denaturation. It requires a temperature of 92-94 C 

Why the others are incorrect 

Option B: PCR cannot function at such high temperatures as 100 C 
Option C: The third step in PCR - extension requires a temperature of 72 C 
Option D: PCR requires a high temperature for all its steps. It functions efficiently at about a temperature of 50-90 depending on the step and the enzyme used.

questions.text:
A researcher is asked to investigate the truth about an idea proposed by one of her peers. The research topic is the absolute refractory period. His peer has proposed a strong assertion and has given reason to support it. 

Assertion A. A second action potential cannot be elicited during the absolute refractory period, even with a strong stimulus.

Reason B. Activation gate of the sodium channel will not reopen until the membrane potential returns to or near the original resting membrane potential level.

The researcher investigates the claim and makes a statement regarding assertion and reason based on previous research on the subject. 

What could be the correct option?

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are independently true/correct statements, and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion.
Both assertion and reason are independently true/correct statements, but the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion.
The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the reason is independently a false/incorrect statement.
The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the reason is independently a true/correct statement.

questions.solution:
Option C: Assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the reason is independently a false/incorrect statement

Assertion A. During the absolute refractory period, a second action potential cannot be elicited, even with a strong stimulus

  • As long as the membrane is in the refractory period from the preceding action potential, a new action potential cannot be elicited because Na+ ions cannot move through the closed Na+ channels.

Reason B. Activation gate of the sodium channel will not reopen until the membrane potential returns to or near the original resting membrane potential level.

  • Shortly after the action potential is initiated, the sodium channels become inactivated. The activation gate remains open while the inactivation gate is closed, and no amount of excitatory signal applied to these channels at this point will open the inactivation gates (not the activation gate).
  • The only condition that will allow the inactivation gates to reopen is for the membrane potential to return to or near the original resting membrane potential level.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents in the outpatient department with a complaint of chest pain, palpitation, and shortness of breath for five hours. The patient is diaphoretic. His pulse is 210 bpm, BP 120/85 mmHg, and saturation is 95% at room air. There is no sign of clubbing or oedema on physical examination. The histopathologic examination of the heart on autopsy reveals the accessory atrioventricular conduction pathway. Which among the following fibres are the most rapidly depolarising fibres in the ventricles of the heart?

choices.text: Fibers in the middle of the ventricle
All fibers from apex to base (depolarize equally rapidly)

questions.solution:
Option C: Fibres at the base

  • Fibres at the base depolarise most rapidly.
    • It immediately repolarises as well.
    • Then, the repolarisation spreads in the reverse direction.
    • When repolarisation reaches the apex, the apical fibre has just now finished its depolarisation; it now begins to repolarise.
  • Fibres at the apex depolarise relatively slowly.
  • As one move towards the base, the rate of depolarisation becomes more and more rapid.
  • Purkinje fibres and ventricular fibres are basically rapidly depolarising fibres.
  • Yet, the rates of their depolarisation are different.

Option A: Fibres at the apex

  • Fibres at the apex depolarise relatively slowly.
  • The rate of depolarisation becomes more and more rapid as one move towards the base.

Option B: Fibres in the middle of the ventricle

  • Depolarisation occurs from the endocardium to the epicardium.
  • So, the base of the epicardium is the last part of the ventricles to depolarise.
  • The left ventricle takes more time for depolarisation due to its thicker wall.

Option D: All fibres from apex to base (depolarise equally rapidly)

  • The rapidly depolarising fibres are the Purkinje fibres.
  • The rate of depolarising is different at different parts of the heart.
  • The fibres at the apex depolarise relatively slowly.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male was brought to the emergency day after a road traffic accident 20 minutes ago. He has multiple lacerations to his upper extremities and sustained an open fracture to his lower extremity. Initial CBC reveals white blood cells count at 22 x 103 /µl, and subsequent complete blood count analysis after 5 hours reveals the white blood cells count at 7 x 103 /µl. Which of the following is the reason for the increase in white blood cell count on the initial blood report?

choices.text: Increased production of WBCs by the bone marrow
Release of pre-formed, mature WBCs into the circulation

questions.solution:
Option B: Release pre-formed, mature WBCs into the circulation

  • A traumatic physical event can result in the release of WBCs into circulation.
  • The increase in the given case may not be due to any inflammatory response, but instead, the increase is due to mechanical trauma and associated stress responses.
  • Stress causes an overproduction of white blood cells, which defend the body against diseases but can cause problems when produced in excess.
  • These extra cells can stick to artery walls, causing restrictions in blood flow and aiding the formation of clots that can cause blood-vessel blockages throughout the body.
  • When stimulation, like an increased level of cytokines, these stored WBCs are released into circulation.
  • But still, a physically traumatic event can result in the release of WBCs into circulation.

Option A: Increased production of WBCs by the bone marrow

  • Increased production of WBCs by the bone marrow defends your body against infections and disease. But, when too many white blood cells, it usually means you have an infection or inflammation in your body. Less commonly, a high white blood cell count could indicate certain blood cancers or bone marrow disorders.

Option C: Decreased destruction of WBCs

  • Decreased destruction of WBCs is usually caused by: Viral infections that temporarily disrupt the work of bone marrow.

Option D: Increased production of selectins

  • The selectins are physiologically important in inflammation, lymphocyte homing, immunological responses, and homing of bone marrow stem cells. They play a role in atherosclerosis, ischemia-reperfusion injury, inflammatory diseases, and the metastatic spreading of some cancers.

questions.text: You are posted in the delivery room in the Obstetric department, and you have a chance to deliver your sister’s child. Your sister, who is of blood type A positive, gives birth to a healthy boy of blood type O negative. This is her second child, and the blood type of your brother-in-law is O negative. Now, what do you expect to find in your nephew?

choices.text: Erythroblastosis fetalis due to rhesus incompatibility
Erythroblastosis fetalis due to ABO blood group incompatibility
The child would not be expected to have Hemolytic disease of newborn.

questions.solution:
Erythroblastosis fetalis (Hemolytic disease of the newborn)

  • It is a disease occurring in a fetus/newborn baby.
  • HDN (Hemolytic Disease Of New Born) occurs when the mother is Rh negative and the father is Rh positive resulting in an Rh-positive child.
  • It occurs due to “Rh incompatibility between mother and fetus”. (That is, Rh blood group of mother and fetus not compatible)
  • C/F: Anemia, Jaundice
  • Preventive measure: Anti D Serum given to mother after delivery of 1st baby.
  • Treatment: Exchange transfusion for anemia.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to the clinic for a follow-up visit. He has a medical history of hypertension which is under control with medications. He smokes two packs of cigarettes daily, and his BMI is 31 kg/m2. He is advised to perform regular aerobic and muscle strength exercises along with a reduction in smoking. Regarding exercise, which of the following statement is false?

choices.text: The oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve moves to the left.

questions.solution:
Option D: The oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve moves to the left

  • The response to exercise depends upon its intensity and duration.
  • During aerobic and strength training exercises, the requirements for oxygen increase.
  • During exercise, numerous alterations in the chemical and mechanical cardiovascular and ventilator functions exist to meet the metabolic demands of the skeletal muscles.
  • During exercise, the increase in ventilation is proportional to the rise in carbon dioxide production and oxygen consumption.
  • PCO2 increases with exercise because during exercise, the muscle work harder, resulting in increased consumption of oxygen which produces more oxygen.
  • Haemoglobin is fully saturated throughout exercise in individuals with normal respiratory function.
  • Similarly, the respiratory exchange ratio, i.e. the CO2 production/O2 uptake, increases as the intensity of exercise increases.
  • The value of this ratio gives us an indication of whether the body is performing aerobically or anaerobically.
  • In the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve, exercise causes a right shift due to increased body temperature, carbon dioxide and decreased pH due to a rise in lactic acid production.

Option A: PCO2 increases with exercise

  • During exercise, the requirement for energy increases which causes the tissues to utilize more oxygen.
  • This increased utilization of oxygen results in increased production of CO2.

Option B: Oxygen consumption increases

  • During exercise, the requirement for energy increases which causes the tissues to utilize more oxygen.

Option C: Respiration exchange ratio increases

  • It is the ratio of the volume of carbon dioxide produced and the proportion of oxygen used.
  • It increases with the intensity of exercise.

questions.text: An experiment is conducted in which ADH is administered at an hour interval to three to four subjects (A to D). In the following figure, which lines most likely reflect the response to ADH administration in a normal patient and a patient with central diabetes insipidus?
questions.solution:
Option D: DB

Central diabetes insipidus:

  • Diabetes insipidus is the syndrome that results from either deficiency of antidiuretic hormone (ADH), also known as vasopressin (causes central type), or failure of the kidneys to respond to the hormone (which causes nephrogenic type).
  • Patients with central diabetes insipidus have an inappropriately low secretion rate of ADH in response to changes in plasma osmolality, but their renal response to ADH is not impaired. Because plasma levels of ADH are depressed, the ability to concentrate urine is impaired, and a large volume of dilute urine is excreted.
  • The distal tubular segments cannot reabsorb water without ADH, resulting in a large volume of dilute urine with urine volumes exceeding 15L/day. Loss of water tends to increase plasma osmolality, which stimulates the thirst center and leads to a very high rate of water turnover.
  • The symptoms are the passage of large amounts of dilute urine (polyuria) and the drinking of large amounts of fluid (polydipsia).
  • Therefore, according to the diagram, "D" represents the normal patient after ADH is given; it shows a lower urine output than "B" in the absence of ADH, which restricts further giving ADH. As opposed to this, the "B" represents the patient with central diabetes insipidus due to the high urine output in the absence of ADH that decreases sharply on giving ADH, clearly showing the absence of ADH.

Option A: BA

  • “B” represents a patient with central diabetes insipidus.
  • "A" represents a patient with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. This is because the urine output is high despite introducing ADH, which is due to the failure of the kidneys to respond to the action of the ADH.

Option B: BD

  • “B” represents a patient with central diabetes insipidus.
  • "D" represents a normal patient after ADH is given.

Option C: DA

  • "D" represents a normal patient after ADH is given.
  • “A” represents a patient with nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. This is because the urine output is high despite introducing ADH, which is due to the failure of the kidneys to respond to the action of the ADH.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the structure of the cytoskeleton is correct?

choices.text: The cytoskeleton is composed of three types of fibers: microfilaments, intermediate filaments, and microtubules.
Microfilaments are the largest type of cytoskeletal fibers and provide support for the cell.
Intermediate filaments are responsible for cell motility and contraction.
Microtubules are made up of the protein actin and are important in the formation of cell-cell junctions.

questions.solution:
Option A

  • The cytoskeleton is a network of fibers that support and structure cells, consisting of microfilaments, intermediate filaments, and microtubules. Microfilaments are the smallest and made up of actin, contributing to cell movement and mechanical support. Intermediate filaments are of intermediate size and offer mechanical support, particularly under stress. Microtubules are the largest and composed of tubulin.

Why are the other choices incorrect

Option B: Microfilaments are the largest type of cytoskeletal fibers and provide support for the cell, which is incorrect because microfilaments are the smallest type of cytoskeletal fibers, not the largest.

Option C: Intermediate filaments are responsible for cell motility and contraction, which is incorrect because intermediate filaments provide mechanical support for the cell, not cell motility and contraction.

Option D: Microtubules are made up of the protein actin and are important in the formation of cell-cell junctions, is incorrect because microtubules are composed of the protein tubulin, not actin, and are involved in cell division, intracellular transport, and the maintenance of cell shape, not the formation of cell-cell junctions.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence of events in hemoglobin synthesis?

choices.text: Transcription of globin genes, translation of globin mRNA, formation of heme, synthesis of alpha and beta chains
Synthesis of alpha and beta chains, transcription of globin genes, translation of globin mRNA, formation of heme
Formation of heme, synthesis of alpha and beta chains, transcription of globin genes, translation of globin mRNA
Translation of globin mRNA, transcription of globin genes, synthesis of alpha and beta chains, formation of heme

questions.solution:
Option A

  • Hemoglobin synthesis begins with the transcription of globin genes, which produce messenger RNA (mRNA) molecules. These mRNA molecules are then translated into polypeptide chains, which fold into alpha and beta globin chains. Meanwhile, heme is synthesized from precursor molecules and binds to the globin chains to form the heme-globin complex. Finally, the heme-globin complexes come together to form hemoglobin molecules. 

Why are the other choices incorrect

Options B, C, and D have incorrect sequences of events in hemoglobin synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding gastrointestinal reflexes?

choices.text: Gastrointestinal reflexes are controlled solely by the central nervous system.
Gastrointestinal reflexes are limited to the myenteric plexus.
Gastrointestinal reflexes can be influenced by hormones and neurotransmitters.
Gastrointestinal reflexes are only involved in the regulation of peristalsis.

questions.solution:
Option C: Gastrointestinal reflexes can be influenced by a variety of factors, including hormones and neurotransmitters. For example, the hormone gastrin can stimulate the secretion of gastric acid, while the neurotransmitter acetylcholine can increase intestinal motility.

Why other options are incorrect:

Option A: While the central nervous system does play a role in controlling gastrointestinal reflexes, it is not the sole controller. The enteric nervous system (ENS), which is a collection of neurons located in the walls of the gastrointestinal tract, also plays a significant role in controlling gastrointestinal reflexes.

Option B: Gastrointestinal reflexes involve both the myenteric plexus and the submucosal plexus. The myenteric plexus controls muscle contractions, while the submucosal plexus controls glandular secretion and blood flow.

Option D: Gastrointestinal reflexes are involved in a variety of functions beyond the regulation of peristalsis. For example, they can regulate the secretion of digestive enzymes and hormones, control blood flow to the gastrointestinal tract, and coordinate the movement of food through the digestive system.

questions.text: Which enzyme is most commonly responsible for causing acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Trypsin is a digestive enzyme that can become activated within the pancreas, leading to autodigestion and inflammation of the pancreas. 

Why other Choices are incorrect

Option A,C: Lipase and amylase are also commonly elevated in acute pancreatitis, but they are not the primary cause of the condition.

Option D: Protease is a general term for enzymes that break down proteins, and can include trypsin as well as other enzymes.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the function of Migrating Motor Complexes (MMCs)?

choices.text: MMCs help mix and propel chyme through the small intestine
MMCs are responsible for the release of digestive enzymes in the duodenum.
MMCs aid in the absorption of nutrients in the ileum.
MMCs regulate the movement of fecal matter through the large intestine.

questions.solution:
Option A: MMCs are wave-like contractions of the smooth muscle in the small intestine that help to mix and propel chyme through the small intestine. MMCs are important for preventing bacterial overgrowth in the small intestine and ensuring that undigested food and waste products are efficiently moved through the digestive system.

Why other answers are incorrect

Option B: is incorrect because MMCs are not responsible for the release of digestive enzymes, but rather for the movement of chyme through the small intestine.

Option C: is incorrect because while MMCs aid in the mixing and propulsion of chyme, absorption of nutrients primarily occurs in the jejunum, not the ileum.

Option D: is incorrect because MMCs primarily function in the small intestine, not the large intestine.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female, undergoes a renal clearance test to determine her renal plasma flow. The test involves measuring the clearance of a substance that is filtered by the glomerulus and actively secreted by the renal tubules. Which of the following substances is most suitable for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Option D: PAH is a substance that is freely filtered by the glomerulus and actively secreted by the renal tubules. Therefore, its clearance can be used to estimate the renal plasma flow, as it represents the rate at which plasma is cleared of PAH by the kidneys. PAH is an ideal substance for estimating renal plasma flow as it is filtered by the glomerulus and actively secreted by the renal tubules, allowing for an accurate estimation of renal plasma flow.

Why Others are Incorrect

Option A: (Glucose) is not suitable for estimating renal plasma flow as it is filtered by the glomerulus but also actively reabsorbed by the renal tubules, leading to an underestimation of renal plasma flow.

Option B: (Creatinine) is a commonly used marker for estimating glomerular filtration rate (GFR), but it is not actively secreted by the renal tubules, making it unsuitable for estimating renal plasma flow.

Option C: (Urea) is filtered by the glomerulus and partially reabsorbed by the renal tubules, leading to an underestimation of renal plasma flow if used for this purpose.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs undergoes biliary elimination?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ceftriaxone

  • Ceftriaxone is the drug among the options that is excreted via bile through the biliary route, so it is the one that can form the biliary sludge in this patient
  • BILE secreted antimicrobial agents
  • CEF  → Cefoperazone, Ceftriaxone
  • Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside and is excreted via the renal route.
  • Renal excreted antimicrobial drugs
    • R → Rifampicin
    • E → Erythromycin
    • N → Nafcillin
    • A → Ampicillin
    • L → Lincosamides (Clindamycin)
    • DISEASE → Doxycycline
  • Ceftriaxone can precipitate with calcium, like what occurs with bilirubin, and so ceftriaxone-associated biliary sludge is mainly composed of a calcium-ceftriaxone complex.​​​​​​​

Option A: Ceftazidime

  • Ceftazidime is also excreted through the renal route, so t cannot form the biliary sludge in this patient

Option B: Ampicillin

  • Ampicillin is excreted through the renal route

Option C: Rifampicin

  • The kidneys excrete rifampicin through tubular secretion

questions.text: Baricitinib is used for treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. Which of the following is true about this drug?

choices.text: Also approved for use in moderate to severe Crohn’s disease
Dose reduction is not required in renal and hepatic impairment.

questions.solution:
Option A: Oral JAK inhibitor

  • All these are symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis, and baricitinib is used to treat RA. Baricitinib is an oral JAK inhinitor.
  • Rheumatoid arthritis, or RA, is an autoimmune and inflammatory disease.
  • In which your immune system attacks healthy cells in your body by mistake, causing inflammation (painful swelling) in the affected parts of the body.
  • RA mainly attacks the joints, usually many joints at once.
  • Signs and symptoms of RA include:
  • Pain or aching in more than one joint
  • Stiffness in more than one joint
  • Tenderness and swelling in more than one joint
  • The same symptoms on both sides of the body (such as in both hands or both knees)
  • Weight loss
  • Fever
  • Fatigue or tiredness
  • Weakness
  • Baricitinib and tofacitinib are oral JANUS kinase inhibitors (JAK).
  • These drugs are used in rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Tofacitinib is also used in ulcerative colitis.
  • Major side-effects of these drugs are:
  • Increased risk of infection: TB, herpes zoster
  • Increased risk of malignancy like lymphoma
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • They require dose reduction in kidney and liver failure.
  • So, they are avoided in lymphopenia and anaemia.

Option B: Approved for use in moderate to severe Crohn’s disease

  • Baricitinib is not used in Crohn's disease
  • Tofacitinib is also used in ulcerative colitis.
  • Crohn's disease is a type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
  • It causes swelling of the tissues (inflammation) in your digestive tract, which can lead to abdominal pain, severe diarrhoea, fatigue, weight loss and malnutrition.

Option C: Decreases triglycerides

  • Baricitinib inhibits the JAK proteins.
  • So it prevents phosphorylation and activation of STATs and modulates the signalling pathway of various interleukins, interferons, and growth factors.
  • Baricitinib also decreases the proliferation of JAK1/JAK2 expression in mutated cells and induces cell apoptosis.
  • It increases triglycerides.

Option D: Dose reduction is not required in renal and hepatic impairment

  • As baricitinib is mainly excreted via the kidneys.
  • In patients with moderate renal impairment with glomerular filtration rate (GFR) between 30 to 60 mL/minute /1.73 m2, the dose should be reduced to 1 mg daily.
  • The drug is not recommended for patients with GFR less than 30 mL/minute /1.73 m2.
  • Dose reduction is required for renal and hepatic impairment.

questions.text: A 34-year-old female patient is a known case of epilepsy. She has been prescribed phenytoin to control her seizures. After getting into a fight with her husband, she takes the whole bottle of pills. High plasma drug concentrations of phenytoin can cause which of the following adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Option A: Ataxia

  • Phenytoin is an anti-epileptic drug which functions by blocking Na+ channels.

  • It is mainly used in the treatment of focal (partial) seizures.

  • It is also used as the 1st line drug for prophylaxis of recurrent status epilepticus.

  • Cerebellar dysfunction, i.e., ataxia, nystagmus, vertigo, diplopia, and sedation, is seen at toxic plasma concentrations.

Option B: Gum hyperplasia

  • The major side effects of phenytoin that occurs at therapeutic doses but with prolonged use include;

    • Gingival hyperplasia

    • Hirsutism

    • Pseudolymphoma

    • Fetal hydantoin syndrome

    • Cytochrome P-450 induction

    • Yellow-brown discolouration of the skin

    • Osteopenia

    • Inhibited folate absorption

    • Neuropathy

Option C: Steven-Johnson syndrome

  • Steven-Johnson syndrome, DRESS syndrome, and drug-induced lupus occur at therapeutic doses of phenytoin but with prolonged use but occur very rarely.

  • Steven-Johnson syndrome is commonly caused as a side effect of lamotrigine.

Option D: All of the above

  • Although all of the mentioned options are side effects of phenytoin, only cerebellar dysfunction occurs due to phenytoin toxicity. All others occur at therapeutic doses but with prolonged use

questions.text: A 60-year-old male diabetic and hypertensive was found collapsed at home on the floor of his bedroom. On arrival at ER, he is confused and combative with a GCS of 13. Initial observations reveal BP 78/60; Pulse 74, RR 32, SPO2 91% (NRB 15L), pH of 7.23 and a Blood Glucose Level of 27mmol. He is taking enalapril for hypertension, spironolactone & metoprolol for his CCF, and celebrex for his osteoarthritis. His diabetes is diet controlled. An ECG is performed on his arrival to the resuscitation, which shows tall tented T waves. Which of the following drug will be least likely to be used for his ECG findings?
questions.solution:
Option D: Intravenous Magnesium Sulphate

  • Magnesium sulfate is most commonly used for the treatment of eclampsia and prevention of eclampsia in patients with severe pre-eclampsia
  • It has no role in the treatment of hyperkalemia
  • The patient is probably in DKA should be confirmed by blood and urinary ketones, and here only focussed on hyperkalemia

Option A: Calcium Gluconate

  • Calcium gluconate is given intravenously to stabilise the cardiac membrane and to antagonise the myocardial toxic effect of hyperkalemia

Option B: Salbutamol

  • Salbutamol is a beta receptors agonist which reduces serum potassium levels by increasing the shift of extracellular potassium into the intracellular space.

Option C: Glucose-Insulin

  • Insulin causes a shift of extracellular potassium intracellularly
  • If given alone, it can cause hypoglycemia because it also shifts glucose and increases its utilisation
  • So it is given with glucose to prevent hypoglycemia

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presented in the outpatient department with complaints of fatigue, weakness, shortness of breath and chest pain. He has a history of chronic bleeding. On general physical examination, he was tachycardic. He has pale skin. His body weight is 60 kilograms. His blood report showed hemoglobin of 5.0 g/dl. Red blood cells were hypochromic and microcytic on peripheral film. The physician prescribed him parenteral iron therapy with a target hemoglobin of 13 g/dl. What is the iron requirement to attain this target?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A

 

  • Iron requirement (mg) = 4.4 × body weight (kg) × Hb deficit (g/dl)
  • 4.4 × 60 × (13-5) = 2112 mg

Incorrect answer

B,C,D

questions.text: Case: A 45-year-old male with metastatic colorectal cancer is being treated with a monoclonal antibody that targets the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR). Which of the following is the most likely adverse effect associated with this medication?
questions.solution:
• Skin rash is a common adverse effect of monoclonal antibodies targeting EGFR, such as cetuximab and panitumumab.

Why others are incorrect

  • Hypertension, cardiotoxicity, and hepatotoxicity are not commonly associated with these medications and are therefore incorrect options.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with a history of multiple fractures due to osteogenesis imperfecta requires a bone biopsy for diagnosis. The child is anxious and uncooperative for the procedure. What would be the most appropriate indication for the use of ketamine in this case?
questions.solution:
Option D 

  • Ketamine is commonly used for procedural sedation in children due to its dissociative properties, which can induce sedation and analgesia while maintaining airway reflexes and cardiovascular stability. It can be an effective option for managing anxiety and uncooperative behavior during diagnostic procedures, such as bone biopsy in this case.

Why Others are Incorrect:

Option A: Induction of anesthesia for surgery: Ketamine may not be suitable for a bone biopsy procedure due to its dissociative properties.

Option B: Relief of acute pain: Other medications may be more appropriate for acute pain relief during a bone biopsy procedure.

Option C: Treatment of neuropathic pain: Ketamine is not the most suitable option for acute pain during a bone biopsy.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female with a history of renal impairment is prescribed probenecid for the treatment of gout. Which of the following precautions should be taken while administering probenecid in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Probenecid is primarily eliminated by the kidneys, and renal impairment can affect its pharmacokinetics. Therefore, it is important to monitor renal function regularly in patients with renal impairment who are prescribed probenecid to avoid potential drug accumulation and adverse effects.

Why Others are Incorrect

Option B: Avoid concurrent use of NSAIDs) is not directly related to probenecid, but it is a general precaution in patients with renal impairment due to the increased risk of nephrotoxicity associated with NSAIDs.

Option C: Administered with a high-fat meal) is not necessary for probenecid administration.

Option D: Discontinue other medications for gout) is not recommended without proper medical guidance, as other medications may be necessary for gout management in some cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a severe allergic reaction, including rash, swelling, and difficulty breathing, after receiving amoxicillin for a suspected respiratory infection. His medical history is significant for a previous episode of an allergic reaction to penicillin. What is the most appropriate immediate management for this patient?

choices.text: Discontinue amoxicillin and provide supportive care

questions.solution:
• The patient is experiencing a severe allergic reaction to amoxicillin, likely due to a known allergy to penicillin. Immediate management for severe allergic reactions is administration of epinephrine, which helps to alleviate symptoms by constricting blood vessels, relaxing airway muscles, and reducing swelling.

Why Others are Wrong

Option B: Diphenhydramine may be used for milder allergic reactions, but in this case, due to the severity of symptoms, epinephrine is the most appropriate choice.

Option C: Discontinuing amoxicillin, providing supportive care, and Option D administering corticosteroids may be necessary, but epinephrine is the initial priority for managing the acute allergic reaction.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of diabetes and a methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection is started on Linezolid for treatment. After 3 days of therapy, the patient develops a sudden onset of weakness and dark-colored urine. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated creatine phosphokinase (CPK) levels. What is the most likely side effect of Linezolid in this case?
questions.solution:
• Linezolid is associated with the side effect of rhabdomyolysis, which is a breakdown of muscle tissue that can lead to elevated CPK levels, dark-colored urine, and weakness.

Why Others are incorrect:

Option A: Myelosuppression is a potential side effect of Linezolid, but it typically presents with symptoms such as fever, sore throat, and easy bruising, rather than sudden onset weakness and dark-colored urine.

Option B: Serotonin syndrome is a potential side effect of Linezolid when used concomitantly with other serotonergic drugs, but it typically presents with symptoms such as agitation, tremors, hyperreflexia, and dilated pupils, rather than sudden onset weakness and dark-colored urine.

Option C: Lactic acidosis is a potential side effect of Linezolid, but it typically presents with symptoms such as rapid breathing, nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain, rather than sudden onset weakness and dark-colored urine.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with high-grade fever, chills, and confusion. He has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and was recently started on oral Chloramphenicol for a respiratory tract infection. On examination, he has a temperature of 103.5°F, decreased level of consciousness, and signs of respiratory distress. Blood cultures are positive for Streptococcus pneumoniae. What is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Bone marrow suppression due to Chloramphenicol
Drug-drug interaction between Chloramphenicol and his COPD medications

questions.solution:
• Chloramphenicol is associated with a serious adverse effect of dose-dependent bone marrow suppression, which can manifest as fever, chills, confusion, and signs of respiratory distress. Blood dyscrasias, including aplastic anemia, can occur as a result of Chloramphenicol-induced bone marrow suppression.

Why Others are Incorrect

Option A: is incorrect because an allergic reaction to Chloramphenicol typically presents with symptoms such as rash, itching, and swelling, not fever, chills, and confusion.

Option C: is incorrect because anaphylactic shock from Chloramphenicol is a rare and severe adverse reaction that presents with symptoms such as hypotension, tachycardia, and respiratory distress, not fever, chills, and confusion.

Option D: is incorrect because there is no known drug-drug interaction between Chloramphenicol and COPD medications that would cause the symptoms described in the case.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) presents with symptoms of urinary frequency, urgency, and difficulty in urination. He is taking multiple medications for his BPH, including tamsulosin and finasteride. Which of the following second-generation antihistamines should be used with caution in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Cetirizine is a second-generation antihistamine that is known to have some anticholinergic properties, which can exacerbate urinary symptoms in patients with BPH. Therefore, it should be used with caution in patients with BPH or other urinary conditions.

Why Others are Incorrect

  • Fexofenadine, loratadine, and desloratadine are considered to have minimal anticholinergic effects and may be preferred in patients with urinary symptoms.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of fatigue, tiredness, low energy, lack of sleep, and weight loss for the last 2 months. He is having suicidal ideas but does not plan to act on them. On further questioning, he reveals that he sees a devil telling him he is a failure. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

choices.text: Major depressive disorder with psychotic features
Major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern

questions.solution:
Option A: Major depressive disorder with psychotic features

This patient has symptoms of major depressive disorder, and he is having hallucinations, so the most likely diagnosis in this patient is MDD with psychotic features.

MDD with psychotic features:

  • A patient has symptoms of major depressive disorder.
  • In addition to MDD symptoms, they also have either delusions or hallucinations.
  • Psychotic features are typically congruent to the mood.

Treatment:

  • Antidepressants + antipsychotics.
  • Refractory to the treatment: Electroconvulsive therapy.

Option B: Major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern

Major depressive disorder with seasonal pattern:

  • Previously called a seasonal affective disorder.
  • MDD episodes only occur during a particular season, especially winter, for 2 or more consecutive years.
  • Atypical symptoms of depression are common in it.

Option C: Dysthymia

  • Persistent depressive disorder is also called dysthymia.
  • It has 2 or more symptoms of MDD lasting for 2 or more years.
  • The remission of symptoms is less than 2 months.

Option D: Schizophrenia

  • This patient does not meet the criteria for schizophrenia.

Criteria for Schizophrenia

  • Two or more of these symptoms must be present for at least one month (can be less if being successfully treated) And at least one symptom must be either (1), (2), or (3)
  1. Hallucinations
  2. Delusions (can be either bizarre or non-bizarre)
  3. Disorganized speech (e.g., frequent derailment or incoherence)
  4. Grossly disorganized or catatonic behavior
  5. Negative symptoms (e g., affective flattening, alogia or avolition).
  • Continuous disturbance for 6 months (attenuated symptoms, residual symptoms)
  • Social or occupational dysfunction (or both) for significant portion of the time
  • Notes: Catatonia can also be used as a specifier for any other diagnosis

questions.text: Tara, a 50-year-old T.V star allegedly hit a man with her car, was brought to the emergency department by ambulance ; she had dilated pupils, hypertension, hyperthermia, and runny nose with nose bleed. On arrival she was agitated. Vital signs were as follows: temperature 41.8°.,13 (107 ° F) rectally, blood pressure 140/90 mm Hg, heart rate 140 beats/min, respirations 28 per minute; She was threatening hospital staff if toxic screen is done on her. However, she was restless and talking to herself and complaining of hospital maintenance saying that she can feel small insects crawling under her skin. Which of the following suggest a psychotic rather than an organic disorder?
questions.solution:
• The complex delusions are frequently seen in psychotic disorder.
  • In organic mental disorders, the delusions are usually transient and fragmented. Presence of complex delusions in organic mental disorder is very rare.
  • The lack of insight is a feature of both whereas confusion and impairment of consciousness is seen in organic mental disorders.

HOW TO REMEMBER: Organic disorders have objective evidence. So, they can be explained better than Psychotic disorders. Psychotic disorders are complex to understand. Complex delusions are seen in Psychotic disorders.

questions.text: A 54-year-old lady with cirrhosis and an alcohol use disorder goes to the emergency room with a change in mental status. She moves slowly during the assessment, is disoriented to time and place, and has asterixis. The ammonia level is high. On an electroencephalogram (EEG), which of the following findings can be seen?
questions.solution:
• ·This woman’s presentation is suggestive of hepatic encephalopathy
  • .Triphasic waves are a characteristic finding on EEG in this disorder.
  • These waves are of low frequency and high amplitude

questions.text: Which gene is most strongly associated with Tourette's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Option B 

  • The SLITRK1 gene has been most strongly associated with Tourette's syndrome. It is involved in neural development and synaptic plasticity, which are thought to play a role in the development of Tourette's syndrome.

Why the other options are incorrect

  • Option A. CACNA1C is associated with other psychiatric disorders such as bipolar disorder and schizophrenia.
  • Option C. NRXN1 is associated with autism spectrum disorder and schizophrenia.
  • Option D. FOXP2 is associated with speech and language disorders, but not specifically with Tourette's syndrome

questions.text: Forensic ballistics involves the examination of evidence from firearms that may have been used in a crime. When a bullet is fired from a gun, the gun leaves microscopic marks on the bullet and cartridge case. These marks are like ballistic fingerprints. As part of the evidence, a particular finding was documented as FG, FFG, FFFG. Which component of the firearm is the doctor documenting?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Black powder size

  • The documentation of "FG," "FFG," or "FFFG" likely refers to the size of the black powder or gunpowder grains found in the cartridge case. Black powder size helps to determine the type of ammunition, its performance characteristics, and potentially link it to a specific firearm or batch of ammunition. 

Incorrect choices :

Option A: Cartridge

  • The notation "FG," "FFG," or "FFFG" does not directly refer to the cartridge itself but rather to the size of the black powder grains within it.

Option C: Base of gun

  • The critical forensic analysis typically focuses on the bullet, cartridge case, and the marks left on them, rather than the base of the gun.

Option D: Wadding of cartridge

  • The notation "FG," "FFG," or "FFFG" does not directly relate to the wadding.

questions.text: What shall be the Gustafson’s ranking of structural changes in age determination, if attrition is reaching the dentin, periodontosis along first 1/3rd of root, cementum apposition is a heavy layer, more cementum and dentin affected, transparency over apical 1/3rd of root?
questions.solution:
Option B: A2, P2, C3, R3, T2

  • A-2 Attrition reaching the dentin.
  • P-2 Periodontosis along the first 1/3rd of root.
  • C-3 A heavy layer.
  • T-2 Transparency over apical 1/3rd of root.

questions.text: After 5 days, the search team recovered the body of the 10-year-old boy who had gone missing while swimming in the lake. The skin of the boy showed signs of cutis anserina and the hands were seen clenched with weed and gravel in it. Which of the following findings would also be seen in a case of antemortem drowning?
questions.solution:
Option D: All of the above

  • All the mentioned signs suggest signs of antemortem drowning.

Option A: Water in the small intestine

  • The presence of water in the stomach & small intestine is included in the internal finding of antemortem drowning.

Option B: Emphysema aquosum

  • When the person is unconscious at the time of drowning, edema aquosum develops.
  • It is a state of mere flooding of lungs with airless water and no formation of froth.
  • Emphysema aquosum develops only when the conscious victim of drowning struggles for survival.

Option C: Hemorrhage in the middle ear

  • The presence of water and hemorrhage in the middle ear also be seen in the case of antemortem drowning.

questions.text: Mark the false statement about magic mushroom poisoning :
questions.solution:
Hallucinogenic mushrooms /Magic mushrooms"

  • Contain Psilocybin and Psilocin and are taken orally, raw or cooked.
  • Fatal Dose : 2 to 3 mushrooms.
  • Fatal Period: Usually 24 hours.
  • DOC:Atropine sulphate
  • Treatment:
    • (1) Stomach wash with potassium permanganate.
    • (2) Activated charcoal.
    • (3) Forced diuresis.
    • (4) Benzyl penicillin 3 lakhs to one million units daily.
    • (5) Atropine sulphate.
    • (6) Antiphalloidien serum.
    • (7) Thioctic acid is obsolete
    • (8) Haemodialysis.

questions.text: A woman comes to your OPD with allegations that her husband assaulted her and shows you bruises over her right arm, left cheek and around her neck. On examination, you find that she is malingering. Which toxin is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Option C: Semecarpus Anacardium contains the toxins: Semicarpol and Bhilawanol, which are used to create artificial bruising. 

Why the others are incorrect

Option A: Abrin is similar to viper venom. These crushed seeds are used to make needles, or Sui, which are thrown at livestock. It is regarded as the ideal livestock toxin.

Option B: It causes painful contact dermatitis and is used for torture and robbery

Option D: It is derived from the Croton tiglium seed. It causes burning pain, abdominal pain, and bloody and intense diarrhoea

questions.text: What is the IPC Section for punishment of whoever revealed the identity of the victim of rape?
questions.solution:
Option A: IPC 228A: Punishment for whoever revealed the identity of the victim of rape 

Why the other options are wrong

Option B: IPC 354: criminalises any act by a person that assaults or uses criminal force against a woman with the intention or knowledge that it will outrage her modesty.

Option C: IPC 90: Intoxication/Insane

Option D: IPC 375: A man is said to commit rape if he penetrates his penis or penis like object/ body part in vagina, oral cavity, anal canal, urethra

questions.text: In a 55-year-old male with symptoms suggestive of a hemorrhagic cerebrovascular accident (CVA) and irritability, an ultra-short-acting intravenous sedative is administered. What is an example of an ultra-short-acting benzodiazepine in this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: Remimazolam

  • Benzodiazepines are indirect agonists at GABAA receptors and increase the affinity of GABA to bind at the receptors. 
  • This enhances GABA action, increasing the frequency of chloride channel opening. 
  • This more frequent opening of chloride channels hyperpolarises the post-synaptic neuronal membrane and decreases neuronal excitability producing anaesthesia.
  • Remimazolam is known for its ultra-short activity among benzodiazepines and is therefore utilised for induction and maintenance of sedation for short procedures. 
  • Remimazolam, like other benzodiazepines, modifies the effects of GABAA receptors to enhance the effects of GABA. It is regarded as an "ultra-short-acting" benzodiazepine because it achieves peak sedation within 3-3.5 minutes after intravenous administration. This property makes it desirable to be used for short procedures.
  • The half-life of remimazolam is 0.5 to 2 minutes following IV administration, with a 37 to 53 minutes terminal elimination half-life. Serum levels and half-life are elevated in patients with hepatic impairment; therefore, doses should be carefully titrated. 
  • It is quickly metabolised to an inactive metabolite CNS7054 by tissue esterases and is not metabolised by cytochrome-dependent hepatic pathways.
  • It should be used cautiously in patients having a previous history of drug abuse or drug dependence as it has the potential to produce drug dependence and drug abuse itself. 
  • It is faster-acting and shorter-lasting when compared to midazolam.

Option A: Midazolam

  • Midazolam is one of the short-acting injectable benzodiazepines with a rapid onset and is generally used in anaesthesia, seizures, and anxiety disorders.
  • The onset of sedation in adults is achieved within 15 minutes following IM injection.
  • With the intravenous injection, sedation is achieved within 3 to 3.5 minutes. 
  • Half-life is also more than midazolam (1.8 to 6.4 hours).

Option C: Diazepam

  • Diazepam is classified as a long-acting benzodiazepine with a rapid onset but a prolonged sedative effect and is therefore used in panic disorders, severe anxiety, seizures, and alcohol withdrawal. 
  • It has a biphasic half-life, i.e. an initial rapid distribution phase followed by an extended terminal elimination phase comprising 1 or 2 days. 
  • When converted to an active metabolite, desmethyldiazepam, which has a half-life of 2 to 5 days, its action is more prolonged.

Option D: Lorazepam

  • Lorazepam is included in short-acting benzodiazepines and is usually used to treat severe anxiety, panic disorders, and seizures.
  • Its half-life is 14 hours when administered parentally.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. The patient has an open wound on the frontal region of the head. The wound was washed and stitched, and the patient was sent for a CT brain. The CT brain revealed a crescent-shaped lesion which doesn’t cross the midline. The patient was shifted to the emergency operation theatre for surgery under general anaesthesia. During general anaesthesia, adequate muscle relaxation is necessary before induction. Depolarizing and non-depolarizing neuromuscular junction blockers, e.g. suxamethonium, are used to attain the required effect. Which of the following nerve is tested for the adequacy of anaesthesia?
questions.solution:
Option B: Ulnar nerve

  • This is a case of subdural hematoma in which the patient presents to the emergency department after a road traffic accident with a head injury.

  • The CT brain reveals a crescent-shaped lesion that doesn’t cross the mid-line, which is suggestive of subdural hematoma.

  • Certain depolarizing and non-depolarizing neuromuscular junction blockers, i.e. suxamethonium, atracurium, and cis-atracurium, are used for this purpose.

  • The most common nerve used for neuromuscular monitoring is the ulnar nerve.

  • The Adductor pollicis muscle is the most commonly monitored muscle for determining the onset and duration of neuromuscular blocking agents. This muscle is sensitive to non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers, and during recovery, it is blocked more than some respiratory muscles, such as the diaphragm and laryngeal adductors.

  • The diaphragm recovers earlier than upper airway muscles that recover in parallel with the adductor pollicis muscle.

Option A: Median nerve

  • The median nerve is tested in carpal tunnel syndrome. It is known as the carpal compression test.

  • In this test, pressure is applied with thumbs over the median nerve in the carpal tunnel. If a patient responds with numbness in 30 seconds, the test is positive.

Option C: Radial nerve

  • The radial nerve originates from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus.

  • Its injury results in wrist drop, pain, and paraesthesia of the dorsum of the hand, index finger, middle finger, and thumb.

Option D: Mandibular nerve

  • The mandibular nerve is a branch of the trigeminal nerve.

  • It has a sensory supply to the lower third of the face and anterior 2/3 of the tongue.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient is scheduled for an elective surgery under general anesthesia. The anesthesiologist is preparing the anesthesia workstation and checking the medical gas pipeline system. While checking the oxygen supply, the anesthesiologist notices that the oxygen pressure gauge shows a reading of 50 psi. What should be the appropriate action in this situation?

choices.text: Continue using the oxygen supply as the pressure is within the acceptable range.
Immediately replace the oxygen cylinder as the pressure is too low for safe use.
Inform the operating room staff and wait for the maintenance team to fix the issue.
Switch to the backup oxygen cylinder and inform the surgeon about the delay in starting the surgery.

questions.solution:
Option B: In a medical gas pipeline system, the oxygen supply should be maintained within the acceptable pressure range, typically between 50-55 psi. A reading of 50 psi indicates that the oxygen cylinder is almost empty and may not provide adequate oxygen supply for the surgery. It is essential to replace the cylinder immediately to ensure uninterrupted oxygen supply during the surgery.

Why Others are Wrong

Option A: is incorrect as continuing to use the oxygen supply with a low pressure reading can lead to inadequate oxygen supply during the surgery, posing a risk to the patient's safety.

Option C: is incorrect as waiting for the maintenance team to fix the issue may cause unnecessary delays in starting the surgery and compromise patient safety.

Option D: is incorrect as switching to the backup oxygen cylinder is not necessary in this case, as the oxygen supply can be immediately replaced with a new cylinder.

questions.text: Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation (CPR) is a lifesaving procedure that artificially maintains circulation and ventilation until the cardiac function is hopefully restored. Immediate initiation of high-quality chest compressions is the most important factor for survival after cardiac arrest. Which of the following is the acceptable compression rate during CPR?
questions.solution:
Option A: 100/min

  • Chest compression:
    • Key targets for high-quality chest compressions
    • Compression rate: 100–120 per minute
    • Compression depth for adults: 5–6 cm (2–2.5 inches)
    • Allow full chest recoil between compressions.
  • Provider positioning and technique (adults and children; excluding infants)
    • Kneel or stand next to the patient, depending on whether they are on the ground or in a bed.
    • Centre the hands (one on top of the other, fingers interlaced) over the sternum.
    • Keep the arms straight (do not bend the elbows); the shoulders should be directly above the hands.
    • Use full body weight to deliver rapid, firm compressions.
  • Patient positioning:
    • Supine on a firm surface
  • Minimizing interruptions
    • Restart CPR between rhythm analysis and shock delivery (while the defibrillator is charging).
    • Resume CPR immediately after shock delivery.

Option B: 500/min

  • Excessive compressions per minute should be avoided
  • Compression rate: 100–120 per minute

Option C: 20/min

  • The recommended chest compressions are 100-200 per minute

Option D: 50/min

  • The recommended compression during CPR is 100-200 per minute

questions.text: A 2-month-old child was brought to the physician’s office with cyanosis since birth. On physical examination, he had central cyanosis with a harsh ejection systolic murmur at the left mid to upper sternal border. Furthermore, a chest x-ray is done, as shown in the following image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tetrology of Fallot:

  • It is the most common congenital heart disorder, caused by the malalignment of the muscular outlet septum.
  • It leads to right ventricular outflow obstruction, a subaortic VSD with aortic override, and right ventricular hypertrophy.
  • This produces the physiological pattern of low pulmonary blood flow and right-to-left shunt.
  • The patient presents with right ventricular outflow tract obstruction with a certain degree of cyanosis.
  • The auscultation of the chest shows normal heart sound with a single loud second heart sound and a harsh ejection systolic murmur at the left mid to upper sternal border with posterior radiation.
  • Diagnosis is made by fetal echocardiography, which is the gold standard.
  • It is used for addressing the anatomical severity of the right ventricular outflow obstruction, location, and a number of ventricular septal defects, and to assess the associated anomalies and variants of the coronary vessels and the arch of the aorta.
  • The chest radiographs usually show a normal-sized heart silhouette with an upturned apex and a concave main pulmonary artery segment commonly known as the boot-shaped heart. The major limitation of echocardiography is the inability to visualize the distal pulmonary arteries.
  • Cardiac MRI is useful in adults.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection:

  • Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
  • In a baby with TAPVR, oxygen-rich blood does not return from the lungs to the left atrium. Instead, the oxygen-rich blood returns to the right side of the heart.
  • On the chest x-ray, there is a Snowman appearance/figure of eight

 

Option C - Transposition of great arteries:

  • Egg on a string, also known as the egg on the side, describes the cardiomediastinal silhouette that is found in the transposition of the great arteries (TGA)
  • This is due to the globular convexity of the right atrial border and left atrial enlargement making it appear like an egg.

 

Option D - Ebstein’s anomaly:

  • A combination of the following causes Ebstein anomaly appearance:
    • Huge right atrium filling the entire right hemithorax
    • The shelved appearance of the left cardiac contour due to the dilated right ventricular outflow tract or elevated residual right ventricle
    • Small aorta and main pulmonary artery
  • Imaging shows a Box-shaped heart - Ebstein's anomaly

questions.text: A newborn is brought to the nursery to keep under observation for the assessment of any congenital disorder. She has not passed meconium for 48 hrs since birth. Her mother had gestational diabetes in her last 2 pregnancies. Her mother has had a history of hypertension for the last 6 years. The baby has vomiting and distension of the abdomen. What would be the most appropriate investigation for further evaluation?
questions.solution:
Option C: Rectal Biopsy

  • The baby discussed above has Hirschsprung's disease.
  • Hirschsprung's disease is characterised by the absence of ganglionic cells in the distal colon and rectum.
  • It occurs due to the failure to migrate neural crest cells to distal bowel segments.
  • It affects cells in both - myenteric and submucosal plexuses.
  • Functional obstruction develops in the affected part.
  • It can be anatomically divided into four types according to the length of the aganglionic segment:
    • Short segment disease: Rectal and distal sigmoid colonic involvement only.
    • Long segment: Typically extends to splenic flexure/transverse colon.
    • Total colonic aganglionosis: (range 2-13%). Also known as Zuezler-Wilson syndrome. Occasional extension of aganglionosis into the small bowel.
    • Ultrashort segment disease. 3-4 cm of internal anal sphincter only.
  • Controversial entity:
    • A definitive diagnosis is done by rectal biopsy.

Option A: Rectal Manometry

  • The definite diagnosis of Hirschsprung's disease is done by rectal biopsy.

Option B: Barium enema

  • Barium enema demonstrates cone shape transition zone and reversal of rectosigmoid ratio.
  • The most important sign of barium enema is a sudden change of calibre from the narrow aganglionic segment and dilated proximal bowel.

Option D: Enteroclysis

  • It is done for examination of the small bowel. X-rays are done, and single pictures are taken along with a special form of x-ray called fluoroscopy.
  • The definite diagnosis of Hirschsprung's disease is done by rectal biopsy.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with dizziness and light-headedness when he stood up for the last 3 days. He also has blurred vision for the last 24 hours. On examination, his skin is pale and clammy. He has a significant history of 10 pack years of smoking from the last 2 years. His breathing is rapid and shallow. Considering the above symptoms, what does the following barium swallow image demonstrate in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Esophageal Varices

  • The barium swallow image demonstrates oesophagal varices in this patient.
  • Oesophageal varices are enlarged or swollen veins (varices) in the lower oesophagus.
  • The veins in your lower oesophagus near the stomach can become swollen when blood flow to the liver is reduced.
  • When liver blood flow is obstructed, blood builds up in other blood vessels, including those in your lower oesophagal veins. However, these veins are small and incapable of carrying large amounts of blood. They dilate and swell as a result of the increased blood flow.
  • On barium swallow, they appear as serpentine/worm-like filling defects.

Option A: Esophageal web

  • Seen associated with Patterson Kelly Syndrome / Plummer-Vinson.
  • Webs are present in the upper part of the oesophagus.
  • Show proximal pooling of barium on barium swallow.

                                  

Option C: Esophageal leiomyoma

  • The most common benign tumour of the oesophagus is seen in the middle and distal parts of the oesophagus.
  • It may be seen as a discrete ovoid mass well outlined by barium.
  • Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the oesophagal wall.

Option D: Achalasia cardia

  • In the case of achalasia, the radiological findings are bird beak or rat tail appearance on barium swallow.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents to the emergency department with right lower quadrant abdominal pain. An ultrasound of the abdomen is performed. The imaging findings show a blind-ended tubular structure with an inner diameter of 8 mm, located in the right lower quadrant and surrounded by inflammatory changes. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The imaging findings of a blind-ended tubular structure with inflammatory changes and an inner diameter of 6-10 mm, located in the right lower quadrant, are suggestive of an inflamed appendix, which is characteristic of acute appendicitis.

Why the Others are Incorrect:

Option A: Ovarian cysts typically appear as cystic masses in the ovary with thin walls and clear fluid content.
Option B: Meckel's diverticulum is a congenital anomaly of the gastrointestinal tract that appears as a blind-ended tubular structure arising from the ileum.
Option C: Hydrosalpinx is a condition in which the fallopian tube is dilated with fluid.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male with a history of herpes simplex virus infection presents with fever, uneasiness, and joint pain for the past 2 days. On examination, his pulse is 110/min, blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg, respiratory rate is 17/min, and temperature is 38.2°C (100.7°F). On examination of the skin, lesions are noted on the palms and back of his hands and feet, as shown below:



Which of the following is likely a diagnosis of this patient’s skin lesions?
questions.solution:
Option D: Erythema multiforme

  • This patient with a target-like skin lesion most likely has erythema multiforme.
  • Erythema multiforme (EM) is an acute, immune-mediated condition characterized by the appearance of distinctive target-like lesions on the skin. These lesions are often accompanied by erosions or bullae involving the oral, genital, and ocular mucosae.
  • "Erythema multiforme major" is the term used to describe EM with severe mucosal involvement (and may have associated systemic symptoms, such as fever and arthralgias). Erythema multiforme minor refers to EM without (or with only mild) mucosal disease (without associated systemic symptoms).
  • A variety of factors have been implicated in the pathogenesis of EM. The disorder is most commonly induced by infection, with the herpes simplex virus being the most frequent precipitator. The clinical course of EM is usually self-limited, resolving within weeks without significant sequelae. However, in a minority of cases, the disease recurs frequently over the years.

Option A: Pemphigus Vulgaris is the most common type of pemphigus. The defect in desmoglein-3 and bullae is Deep. Bulla spread sign, and Nikolsky’s sign is seen in Pemphigus Vulgaris.

Option B Psoriasis is a skin disease that causes a rash with itchy, scaly patches, most commonly on the knees, elbows, trunk, and scalp. Auspitz sign is seen in Plaque Psoriasis.

Option C Urticaria pigmentosa is a rash that appears most often in children and young adults. It consists of reddish-brown lesions that may form hives or blisters when stroked. This reaction is called Darier's sign. Urticaria pigmentosa is a type of mastocytosis.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old male presents to the clinic due to discoloration of the right toenail for the past few months. He has a history of foot injury 6-months ago, which led to the separation of the right toenail from its nail bed. Medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus, for which he takes metformin daily. Examination reveals thickening and darkening of the right toenail as shown in the image below:



Which of the following is the most effective treatment in the management of this patient’s nail condition?

choices.text: Debridement of the nail followed by systemic itraconazole
Removal of the nail followed by systemic amphotericin B

questions.solution:
Option C: Debridement of the nail followed by systemic itraconazole

  • This patient with thickening and discoloration of the nail most likely has onychomycosis. Debridement of nails followed by systemic itraconazole is the first-line therapy in the management of onychomycosis.
  • Onychomycosis is the infection of fingernails or toenails, most commonly caused by dermatophyte fungi. Species that are commonly involved include Microsporum, Epidermophyton, and Trichophyton. The incidence of onychomycosis is increased in patients with a history of prior nail trauma, immunosuppression, or certain rheumatological disorders (such as psoriasis, etc.).
  • Clinical manifestation includes discoloration of the affected nail, thickening, scaling, and eventual separation from the nail bed. Initial diagnosis is usually made by examining toe clippings and subungual debris in the KOH mount.
  • PAS staining is sometimes used to confirm the findings of KOH preparation.
  • System antifungals are the most effective treatment for onychomycosis. Concomitant debridement of the affected nail increases the cure rate.

Following drugs are recommended for the treatment of onychomycosis.

Drugs Recommended Dosages
Terbinafine 250 mg/day for 6 and 12 weeks in fingernail and toenail onychomycosis, respectively.
Itraconazole

Pulse therapy:

200 mg twice daily for 1 week/month for 2 and 3 consecutive months for finger and toenail onychomycosis, respectively.

Continuous regimen:

200 mg/day for 6 weeks.
Fluconazole 150 mg weekly for a maximum period of 12 months

Option A: Topical application of steroids

  • Topical steroids are mostly used in certain allergic skin conditions such as atopic dermatitis. They have no role in the management of onychomycosis.

Option B: Topical application of terbinafine

  • Topical terbinafine is used in the management of tinea corporis.
  • Dermatophyte infections involving nails and scalp require systemic therapy due to poor penetration of topical antifungal agents.
  • The only topical therapy approved for the management of onychomycosis is ciclopirox olamine nail lacquer applied daily for a year.

Option D: Removal of the nail followed by systemic amphotericin B

  • Amphotericin B is mostly used in the management of disseminated fungal infections. Removal of the nail is unwarranted at this point.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents to the outpatient department with the complaint of a nodule under the nail of her index finger. She states that the nodule is painful, and exposure to cold increases her pain. On examination, a small, round bluish nodule on her index nail bed is noted. Increased pinprick sensitivity is noted. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Glomus tumor

  • This patient with a painful nodule under the nail of her index finger with increased severity of pain upon cold exposure and increased pinprick sensitivity most likely has a glomus tumor.

Glomus tumors

  • Benign, vascular neoplasms arising from the glomus body.
  • Occur in the upper extremities, most frequently in subungual areas.
  • Present as a small, round, bluish nodule visible through the nail plate with a classic triad of symptoms:
    • Hypersensitivity to cold
    • Heightened pinprick sensitivity
    • Paroxysmal pain
  • Diagnosis: X-ray, MRI, and ultrasonography.
  • However, only histology can confirm the diagnosis.
  • Complete surgical excision of the tumor is the only effective treatment to achieve pain relief and a low recurrence rate.

Option A: Herpetic whitlow

  • Local tenderness, erythema, and edema with the initial crop of vesicles - along the pulp and lateral aspect of the finger are diagnostic features of herpetic whitlow. Vesicles usually coalesce into large, honeycomb-like bullae.

Option C: Osteoma

  • Osteoma usually causes a dull, aching pain that is moderate in intensity but can worsen and become severe, especially at night. The bluish lesion under the nail is characteristic of a glomus tumor.

Option D: Subungual hematoma

  • Patients with subungual melanoma may complain of pain and discoloration of the nail and appear reddish, purple, brown, black, or a combination of these colors. The color variation is related to the duration and stage of healing. The bluish lesion under the nail is characteristic of a glomus tumor.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant has the following vascular lesion on her left cheek. The parents state it was not present at birth but had been growing rapidly for the first few weeks of life. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Superficial infantile hemangioma

  • Infantile or strawberry hemangioma is a benign capillary vascular tumor of infancy (mostly girls), which occurs in 3–10% of infants.
  • Pathophysiology: Abnormal development of vascular endothelial cells.
  • Prognosis: Rapid proliferation followed by subsequent spontaneous slow involution (occurring at the age of 5–8 years).
  • Complications include ulceration and disfigurement.
  • Visual impairment if the periorbital hemangioma is left untreated.

Option B: Milia neonatorum

  • Milia neonatorum is tiny epidermal papules caused by the buildup of keratin and sebaceous secretions.
  • Clinical features: pinhead-sized lesions located on the face/trunk
  • Treatment: not necessary

Option C: Deep infantile hemangioma

  • A deep infantile hemangioma can be compressed and quickly regain its original dimensions on the release of pressure.
  • It becomes larger and darker when the child screams or cries.
  • Virtually 100% of infantile haemangiomas undergo spontaneous regression, which is complete or almost complete in about 95%.

Option D: Pyogenic granuloma

Pyogenic granulomas are benign vascular tumors characterized by rapid growth and a tendency to bleed easily.

  • It is associated with trauma and pregnancy.
  • A soft, round, bright red tumor that bleeds easily.
  • Localization: usually develops at the site of skin injury on the face or hands.

questions.text: A 2-month child is brought to the hospital with noisy breathing since two weeks old. It gets worse when he is lying supine and gets relieved when the mother turns him to the prone position. The condition also aggravates on crying. Examination reveals inspiratory stridor. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. This increase in severity of inspiratory stridor in the supine position is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Option B: Laryngomalacia

  • Newborn develops intermittent, low-pitched inspiratory stridor within 1st 2 weeks of life ( presents at birth)
  • The severity of stridor increases on crying but reduces in the prone position as the epiglottis falls forward in the prone position and opens the airway.
  • Stridor usually starts resolving after 9 months and disappears by 2 years of age.
  • Cry itself as such is normal, but the stridor increases during the inspiratory phase while the child is crying.

Diagnosis of laryngomalacia is confirmed on direct laryngoscopy, which shows the following four important signs:

  • Elongated and large omega-shaped (Ω) epiglottis curled upon itself.
  • Floppy aryepiglottic folds.
  • Prominent arytenoids.
  • Excessive redundant tissue in the supraglottis.

Option A: Congenital subglottic stenosis

  • It presents with stridor. However, it is also associated with cyanotic episodes (blue spells)
  • An increase in stridor in the supine position and resolution in the prone position is typically associated with laryngomalacia.

Option C: Congenital subglottic hemangioma

  • Subglottic hemangiomas present with hoarseness, barking cough, and recurrent croup.

Option D: Laryngeal web

  • The laryngeal web is associated with a weak cry.
  • Increased stridor in the supine position and resolution in the prone position are typically associated with laryngomalacia.

questions.text: A 43-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a nosebleed for the past 20 minutes. His medical history is consistent with hypertension. On examination, his blood pressure is 170/110 mmHg. After a series of treatments, the bleeding does not stop. An endoscopy is ordered. Endoscopy shows bleeding in Kiesselbach's plexus. Which of the following is TRUE regarding anterior epistaxis?

choices.text: Patient is kept in a sitting and slightly leaning forward position while compressing the nares
Topical phenylephrine is contraindicated as it increases blood pressure
Commonly from Kiesselbach's venous plexus in the anteroinferior part of the septum
Foley's nasal tamponade is a treatment option

questions.solution:
Option A: Patient is kept in a sitting and slightly leaning forward position while compressing the nares

  • For patients without life-threatening bleeding, the first step in management is Trotter's or Hippocratic method, in which the patient is made to sit with his head forward over a bowl/sink and pinch the nares firmly, closing the nostrils.
  • He is also advised to spit out any blood in the mouth as it is emetogenic.

Option B: Topical phenylephrine is contraindicated as it increases blood pressure

  • Phenylephrine being a decongestant is used to decongest the nose before cauterization.

Option C: Commonly from Kiesselbach's venous plexus in the anterio-inferior part of the septum

  • Kiesselbach's plexus is an arterial plexus.

Option D: Foley's nasal tamponade is a treatment option

  • Foley's nasal tamponade is done in the posterior epistaxis.

questions.text: A 9-year-old male presents to the ENT outpatient department due to a sore throat for 4 days. Physical examination reveals enlarged and congested tonsils. It is the 5
questions.solution:
Option A: Epidemic of Polio

  • Contraindications of tonsillectomy include:
    • Haemoglobin level less than 10 g%.
    • Presence of acute upper respiratory tract infection and acute tonsillitis. Acute infection leads to more bleeding.
    • Children under 3 years of age. They are poor surgical risks.
    • Overt or submucous cleft palate.
    • Von Willebrand disease. Bleeding disorders, e.g., leukaemia, purpura, aplastic anaemia, haemophilia, or sickle cell disease.
    • At the time of the epidemic of polio.
    • Uncontrolled systemic disease, e.g., diabetes, coronary artery disease, hypertension, or asthma.
    • Tonsillectomy is avoided during menstruation.

Option B: Tonsillar tumor

  • It is not a contraindication for tonsillectomy.
  • It is an absolute indication.
  • Unilateral enlarged tonsils may be lymphoma in children.

Option C: Recent peritonsillar abscess

  • It is not a contraindication for tonsillectomy.
  • It is an absolute indication.
  • In children, tonsillectomy is carried out 4–6 weeks after an abscess has been treated.
  • In adults, the second attack of peritonsillar abscess forms the absolute indication.

Option D: Hemoglobin level less than 12g%

  • A haemoglobin level of less than 10g% is a contraindication for tonsillectomy.
  • A haemoglobin level between 10-12g% is not a contraindication for tonsillectomy.
