questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents with a weak, breathy voice and difficulty in swallowing. On examination, there is unilateral vocal cord paralysis with the vocal cord in the intermediate position. Which nerve is most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The superior laryngeal nerve is a branch of the vagus nerve (CN X) that innervates the cricothyroid muscle, which is responsible for tensing the vocal cords. Unilateral vocal cord paralysis with the vocal cord in the intermediate position, where it is neither fully adducted nor fully abducted, is a classic sign of damage to the superior laryngeal nerve. This can result in a weak, breathy voice and difficulty in swallowing.

Why Others are Incorrect

Option A: Vagus nerve CN X is incorrect as it is the main nerve responsible for innervating the intrinsic muscles of the larynx, but damage to the superior laryngeal nerve, which is a branch of the vagus nerve, would result in unilateral vocal cord paralysis with the vocal cord in the intermediate position.

Option B: Glossopharyngeal nerve CN IX is incorrect as it is responsible for innervating the sensation of the posterior third of the tongue and the oropharynx, and not the larynx.

Option C: Recurrent laryngeal nerve is incorrect as it is a branch of the vagus nerve that innervates the intrinsic muscles of the larynx, but damage to the recurrent laryngeal nerve would typically result in vocal cord paralysis with the vocal cord in the abducted position, not in the intermediate position.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with a history of recurrent episodes of acute laryngitis, with hoarseness of voice, cough, and throat discomfort. On laryngoscopy, bilateral redness and swelling of the vocal cords are seen, with no evidence of any mass lesions. Biopsy reveals no significant abnormalities. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Laryngopharyngeal reflux - The history of recurrent episodes of acute laryngitis, bilateral redness and swelling of the vocal cords, and absence of any mass lesions on laryngoscopy are suggestive of laryngopharyngeal reflux. Laryngopharyngeal reflux is a condition where stomach acid refluxes into the laryngopharynx, leading to irritation and inflammation of the vocal cords. 

Why Others are Incorrect:
Vocal cord nodules (option A) and Reinke's edema (option D) are benign lesions, and laryngeal papilloma (option B) is a viral-induced lesion, which is not typically present with recurrent episodes of acute laryngitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is an expected response in a Normal Cold Spatula Test?

choices.text: Blinking in response to the spatula.

questions.solution:
In a normal Cold Spatula Test, a patient with intact corneal sensation should blink in response to the cold spatula touching the cornea. Blinking is a protective reflex that helps to moisten and protect the cornea. Absence or decreased response of blinking to the cold spatula may indicate impaired corneal sensation, which can be further evaluated for underlying ocular conditions.

Why Others are Wrong

Option B: Pupillary constriction: Pupillary constriction is not expected in a normal Cold Spatula Test, as the test is specifically evaluating corneal sensation, not pupillary response.

Option C: No response: No response to the Cold Spatula Test would indicate impaired corneal sensation, which is not considered a normal response. A normal response should include blinking in response to the spatula.

Option D: Tearing of the eyes: Tearing of the eyes may occur because of blinking, but it is not the expected response in a normal Cold Spatula Test.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman presents with complaints of severe right earache from the past two days. She is in her second trimester of pregnancy. There is no history of fever or upper respiratory tract infection. On examination, the right external ear appears red and swollen, with tenderness on palpation. The left ear is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Otitis externa, also known as "swimmer's ear," is an infection of the external ear canal. It can cause severe ear pain, redness, swelling, and tenderness of the external ear. It is commonly seen in individuals who expose their ears to water frequently, such as swimmers. Pregnancy does not predispose to otitis externa, but increased vascularity and hormonal changes during pregnancy may increase the risk of developing this condition.

Why Others are Wrong:
Acute otitis media (a) is an infection of the middle ear, not the external ear canal, and is less likely in this case as there is no history of fever or upper respiratory tract infection.

Eustachian tube dysfunction (c) is a condition where the Eustachian tube that connects the middle ear to the back of the throat fails to open and close properly, leading to ear blockage and muffled hearing, but it does not typically cause severe ear pain.

Tympanic membrane perforation (d) is a rupture of the eardrum, which can be caused by various factors including infections, trauma, or barotrauma, but it is less likely in this case as the pain is localized to the external ear canal.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with hoarseness of voice and respiratory distress. On examination, multiple papillomatous lesions are visualized in the larynx and trachea. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
The features signify JORRP and the primary treatment for JORRP is surgical excision of the papillomatous lesions. This can be done through various techniques such as microdebrider-assisted removal, laser ablation, or cold instrument excision. It may require multiple procedures over time to manage the recurrent nature of the disease.

Why Others are Wrong:

Option A: Corticosteroids may be used as an adjunctive treatment in some cases, but they are not the primary treatment for JORRP.

Option B: Antibiotics are not effective in treating JORRP as it is not caused by bacterial infection.

Option D: Radiotherapy is not commonly used in the management of JORRP as it may have potential risks and complications in young children.

questions.text: The neural crest is a highly migratory multipotent cell population that forms at the interface between the neuroepithelium and the prospective epidermis of a developing embryo. They result in the formation of various structures within the eye. Which of the following is a neuroectodermal derivative?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Sphincter pupillae:

  • The sphincter pupillae is a structure within the eye that is derived from the neuroectoderm. It is one of the muscles of the iris responsible for constriction of the pupil in response to light stimulation. The neuroectoderm gives rise to various structures in the central nervous system, including the retina and certain components of the iris.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Lens: Derived from the surface ectoderm.

Option B - Lacrimal gland: Derived from the ectoderm of the head.

Options C - Corneal epithelium: Derived from the surface ectoderm.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came to the hospital with high blood sugar levels, worsening vision, patchy vision, and shapes floating in the area of vision, including dots and spots. On medical checkups of blood sugar levels and eyes through the compressive dilated exam, it became a general condition of diabetic retinopathy. What is the most important factor for the development of diabetic retinopathy?
questions.solution:
Option A: Duration of Diabetes

  • Diabetes and prediabetes had an average (standard deviation) duration of 10.7 (5.6) and 9.5 (5.2) years, respectively.

Risk factors:

  • The importance of various risk factors in the development and progression of diabetes has been demonstrated:
  • These factors include diabetes type and duration.
  • Age, gender, glycemic control, hypertension, and body mass index

  • Smoking, serum lipids, and the presence of microalbuminuria

Duration of DM - most important risk factor

  • Poor control of diabetes
  • Pregnancy - causes rapid progression of DR
  • Hypertension
  • Nephropathy 
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Smoking
  • Cataract Surgery
  • Obesity
  • Anaemia
  • Diabetes duration is most likely the best predictor of the development and progression of retinopathy.
  • In the WESDR, the prevalence of any retinopathy was 8% at three years, 25% at five years, 60% at ten years, and 80% at fifteen years.

Option B: Level of diabetes

  • Diabetic retinopathy is a chronic eye disease with four stages. 
  • There are two kinds: non-proliferative and proliferative. 
  • Non-proliferative refers to the disease's early stages, whereas proliferative refers to the disease's advanced stage.
  • It mostly takes several years for diabetic retinopathy to progress to the point where it threatens your vision.

Option C: Type of Diabetes

  • Diabetic retinopathy can affect anyone with diabetes, including those with type 1, type 2, and gestational diabetes (a type of diabetes that can develop during pregnancy). 
  • Diabetic retinopathy affects more than half of all people with diabetes over time.
  • Anyone with type 1 or type 2 diabetes can develop the condition. 
  • The longer you have diabetes and the less well your blood sugar is controlled, the more likely you will develop this eye complication.

Option D: Comorbid conditions like hypertension & hyperlipidemia

  • Comorbidities such as hypertension, diabetes, obesity, hyperlipidemia, and metabolic syndrome are common in heart failure (HF) patients and impact clinical outcomes.
  • In a hyperglycemic environment, hyperlipidemia exacerbates mitochondrial damage and accelerates the development of retinopathy. Controlling dyslipidemia in pre-diabetic patients may help prevent or delay this deadly disease's development and progression.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male football player sustained an injury just above his right ear during a game. He developed a blurring of vision. He was able to see clearly with each eye. However, he experienced diplopia in both eyes, associated with worsening vision while looking downwards. His right eye was higher than his left in the primary position of gaze. Cranial nerve screening reveals a nerve palsy. Which of the following clinical feature can be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Both eyes at the same position

questions.solution:
Option B: Left head tilt

  • The patient sustained an injury after this; he has diplopia, blurring of vision and worsening symptoms on looking downward; all these features suggest the fourth cranial nerve, which supplies the right superior oblique muscle (SOM).
  • The superior oblique muscle of the eye is responsible for intorsion (inward rotation of the eyes):
  • Depression of the eyes
  • Abduction of the eyes
  • Without these functions, the patient's right eye will remain in an upward and outward position in the primary gaze, making the vision blurry. As a result, the patient will tilt his head to the opposite side to remove the need for intorsion and see clearly.
  • Right superior oblique palsy:

  • Figure A shows the elevation and small esotropia on the correct head tilt, which is not seen on the left head tilt. So the patient would prefer to have a left head tilt. So, remember mnemonic BOOT- Better on opposite inclination.
  • Extra edge:
  • Brown syndrome/ superior oblique tendon sheath syndrome is caused by malfunction of the superior oblique muscle, causing the eye to have difficulty moving up, particularly during adduction (when the eye turns towards the nose).

Option A: Both eyes at the same position

  • Without this pull of the superior oblique muscle (SOM), the eyes will be in upwards and outward positions.

Option C: Intorsion 

  • It is also a function of the superior oblique muscle (SOM).
  • It will be absent in case of SOM palsy.

Option D: Hypermetropia 

  • It is usually present in lens disorders.
  • There will be no refractive errors in 4th nerve palsy.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of blurred vision in his left eye. He has a history of cataract surgery in the left eye 3 months ago. On examination, his visual acuity in the left eye is reduced markedly to hand movements. Slit-lamp examination shows an intraocular lens (IOL) in the left eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for Right Choice

Option C: Post operative endophthalmitis: It is the most common complication occuring within 3 months, in which the vision is dramatically reduced to hand movement.


Explanation for Incorrect Choices

Option A: Cataract: This is not the correct diagnosis in this case, as the patient has already undergone cataract surgery and has an IOL in the left eye.

Option B: Cystoid macular edema: can Occur in first month after surgery. It causes slow painless vision while endophtalmitis causes immense pain. So, CME is not the correct diagnosis.

Option D: Posterior capsular opacification: This refers to the clouding of the posterior capsule of the lens, which can occur after cataract surgery. However, in this case, the patient has an IOL in the left eye, indicating pseudophakia, and not posterior capsular opacification.

questions.text: A newborn baby is brought for a routine ophthalmic examination. The baby's eyes appear normal on external examination, but the red reflex test reveals a white reflex in one eye. The most likely refractive condition responsible for this finding is:
questions.solution:
Option B 

  • Myopia, or nearsightedness, is a refractive condition where the eye's focusing power is too strong, causing distant objects to appear blurred. In severe cases, it can result in a white reflex or leukocoria, which can be detected on red reflex examination.

Why Others are Wrong

Option A: Hyperopia, or farsightedness, is a refractive condition where the eye's focusing power is too weak, and it is unlikely to cause a white reflex.

Option C:  Astigmatism is a refractive condition where the cornea or lens has an irregular shape, causing blurred vision at all distances.

Option D; Anisometropia is a condition where there is a significant difference in the refractive error between the two eyes, but it is not likely to cause a white reflex.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with intermittent double vision and occasional eye squint. On examination, the child has well-aligned eyes and good visual acuity in both eyes. Stereopsis is reduced but present. Which grade of binocular vision does the child most likely have?
questions.solution:
Option B 

  • Based on the clinical presentation, the child has subnormal binocular vision with intermittent double vision, reduced stereopsis, and occasional eye squint. These findings are suggestive of Grade II binocular vision, which is characterized by reduced efficiency of binocular vision.

Why Others are Wrong

Option A: Grade I is incorrect as it refers to normal binocular vision with no loss of binocular vision.

Option C: Grade III is incorrect as it refers to abnormal binocular vision with poor or no binocular vision, constant diplopia, suppression, or possible amblyopia, which is not evident in this case.

Option D: Grade IV is incorrect as it refers to absent binocular vision with one eye being functionally dominant while the other eye is suppressed, which is not evident in this case.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with chronic myopia comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of difficulty seeing distant objects, especially at night, despite wearing glasses. Examination shows bilateral narrowing of peripheral visual fields, cupping of the optic discs, and elevated intraocular pressure. The gonioscopy shows no abnormalities. He has been prescribed a drug. At a follow-up examination several months later, intraocular pressure is normal, but the darkening of the iris and an increase in the length of the eyelashes is observed. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Latanoprost:

  • Darkening of the iris, changes in the density, length, and colour of eyelashes, and epithelial keratopathy are known side effects of long-term use of this drug.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Acetazolamide:

  • It is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, can reduce IOP by decreasing aqueous humour synthesis.
  • However, it is not the first-line treatment for open-angle glaucoma.
  • Furthermore, side effects of acetazolamide include hypokalemia, sulfa allergy, and hyperammonemia with paresthesias, none of which are seen in this patient.

Option B - Pilocarpine:

  • It is a cholinomimetic drug that can treat open-angle glaucoma by increasing trabecular aqueous humour outflow.
  • However, it is not the first-line treatment.
  • Moreover, the most common side effects include cholinergic side effects (sweating, rhinorrhea, dizziness, and nausea), none of which are seen in this patient.

Option C - Apraclonidine:

  •  An alpha-2 agonist, can reduce IOP by increasing trabecular aqueous humour outflow and decreasing aqueous humour synthesis.
  • However, it is not the first-line treatment for open-angle glaucoma.
  • Side effects include blurry vision, ocular hyperemia, foreign body sensation, and pruritus, none of which are seen in this patient.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male presents with complaints of pain, photophobia, and decreased vision in his left eye for the past 3 weeks. He has a history of using topical steroid. On examination, there is a large central corneal ulcer with irregular margins and a yellowish-white infiltrate. The anterior chamber is mildly inflamed, and there is a hypopyon. 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A 

  • The most likely diagnosis in this case is fungal keratitis. The history of using topical steroids, large central corneal ulcer with irregular margins and yellowish-white infiltrate, and presence of hypopyon are suggestive of fungal keratitis. Hypopyon, which is an accumulation of pus in the anterior chamber, is a common finding in severe cases of fungal keratitis.
  • Using steroid for the treatment part will worsen the case.

Incorrect options:
Option B: Bacterial keratitis: Bacterial keratitis typically presents with a more defined and less irregular ulcer with purulent discharge. The history of trauma with organic matter and presence of hypopyon are not typical for bacterial keratitis.

Option C: Viral keratitis: Viral keratitis usually presents with a dendritic or geographic pattern of corneal ulceration, and is often associated with a history of recent viral infection.

Option D: Herpetic keratitis: Herpetic keratitis is caused by the herpes simplex virus and typically presents with a dendritic pattern of corneal ulceration with branching and terminal end bulbs, which is not seen in this case.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy who has been on treatment for tuberculous spondylitis is now presenting with low back pain with difficulty walking. The image is given below. Which are the most common sequelae?
questions.solution:
Option B: Bony ankylosis (ankylosing spondylitis)

  • The above-given image shows the fusion of two vertebrae.
  • Bony ankylosis, also known as ankylosing spondylitis, is an inflammatory disease with abnormal stiffening and immobility of a joint due to fusion either by fibrous tissues or bone.
  • The usual outcome of healed tuberculosis in the spine is bony ankylosis, and in contrast to any other site where fibrous ankylosis is the usual outcome, the spine is the only site where tuberculosis heals with bony ankylosis.
  • Physiotherapy and exercise can improve the symptoms of ankylosing spondylitis.
  • The medication to improve the symptoms include:
    • Painkillers
    • Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
    • Ibuprofen

Option A: Fibrous ankylosis

  • Fibrous ankylosis is a disease in which the fibrous tissue intrudes into the condylar bone marrow by degeneration of condylar cartilage.
  • Fibrous ankylosis is seen in rheumatoid arthritis, tuberculosis hip, and tuberculosis knee.
  • Painful (because some movement is present in fibrous).

Option C: Pathological fracture

  • A pathological fracture is a condition in which the continuity of the bone breaks due to any disease.
  • Vertebral bodies (thoracic and lumbar) are the most often affected bones, followed by the neck of the femur and the lower end of the radius (collie's fracture).
  • The most common cause is osteoporosis, followed by metastasis.
  • In developing countries, the commonest cause of pathologic fracture is nutrition.
  • The most common local cause of pathological fracture is secondary to the malignant lesion.
  • The most common site is the thoracic vertebrae.

Option D: Chronic osteomyelitis

  • Chronic osteomyelitis is the infection of the bone that lasts for more than 3 weeks with no response to medication.
  • Above-the-knee amputation is recommended in chronic osteomyelitis with dead bone.
  • Complications: Amyloidosis and squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Paprika sign: While removing the dead bone, there is the presence of bleeding from the live bone underneath the dead bone, known as the paprika sign.
  • Sequestrum (dead bone) is the hallmark of chronic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old postmenopausal woman presents to the emergency department with pain and limitation of right arm movement after a fall on an outstretched hand. On physical examination, there is soft tissue swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness over the right shoulder region. The normal convex contour of the shoulder is maintained. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Proximal humerus fracture

  • Based on the clinical scenario, there is a fracture of the proximal humerus.
  • Fracture of the proximal humerus is usually seen after middle age.
  • Most commonly in osteoporotic, postmenopausal women.
  • The most common mechanism of injury is falling on the outstretched hand.
  • The patient usually presents with localized shoulder pain and limitation of movement in the affected arm.

Option A: Acromio-clavicular dislocation

  • Injury among Athletes ( Painful impairment of shoulder elevation)

Option C: Shoulder dislocation

  • Usually occurs with abduction and external rotation force
  • In Anterior Dislocation: Down/Out (Arm's abducted)
  • In Posterior Dislocation: Up/In (Arm's Adducted)

Option D: Fracture of the clavicle

  • Most common bone to fracture ( Occurs in Middle 1/3rd )
  • Open clavicle fractures are associated with high rates of pulmonary and closed-head injuries

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of windswept deformity?
questions.solution:
Option B) Neuromuscular disorder. Windswept deformity is commonly caused by neuromuscular disorders such as cerebral palsy, spinal cord injury, or muscular dystrophy, which lead to muscle imbalance and joint contractures.

Why other options are incorrect

  • Option A) Congenital limb length discrepancy can cause leg length discrepancy, but it does not typically result in windswept deformity.
  • Option C) Trauma to the lower limbs can cause fractures and dislocations, but it does not usually result in windswept deformity.
  • Option D) Osteomyelitis is a bone infection that can lead to bone destruction, but it does not typically result in windswept deformity

questions.text: A 29-year-old male presents with complaints of severe pain and bony spicule discharge from the right lower limb. On examination, multiple sinus tracts and tissue necrosis is found over the underlying bone. Which of the following organism is the most probable cause of this patient's underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Staphylococcus aureus

This patient with severe pain, bony spicule discharge, multiple sinus tracts, and tissue necrosis involving the right lower limb most likely has chronic Osteomyelitis.

  • Classification of Osteomyelitis:
  • Acute (<2 weeks): Hematogenous (Most common), Pyogenic
  • Subacute (2-3 weeks) : Non-pyogenic
  • Chronic (> 3 weeks) : Direct

Causative organisms:

The following myriad of incriminating organisms is responsible for its causation:

"S" series organisms ("S" denotes severe Osteomyelitis, and those organisms causing it to start with the letter "S")

S series: S aureus, Salmonella

  • Several bones involved
  • Symmetrical involvement of bones
  • Severe Osteomyelitis
  • Spine may be involved
  • Sickle cell anemia present
  • A stool culture may be positive.

P-series organisms (their mode of entry is through punctured wounds)

  • Pseudomonas
  • Pneumococcus.
  • C-series (C denotes compound fractures)
  • Clostridium welchii
  • Coliforms (E. coli).

T-series

  • Treponema pallidum (syphilitic Osteomyelitis)
  • Tubercle bacillus (Mycobacterium).
  • Fungal Osteomyelitis (ABC)
  • Actinomycosis
  • Blastomycosis
  • Cryptococcosis and coccidioidomycosis

 Staphylococcus aureus

  • Staphylococcus aureus (60-85%): This is the most common organism causing acute Osteomyelitis.

Option A: Haemophilus influenzae

  • Haemophilus influenzae (7 months to 4 years): This is known to cause Osteomyelitis in the age group of 7 months to 4 years.

Option B: Brucella bacillus

  • Brucella bacillus can rarely cause Osteomyelitis.

Option C: Streptococcus hemolyticus

  • 8-10% of infection is caused by S.hemolyticus but is rare.

questions.text: A patient made a self-diagnosis of an athlete's foot and began using a product advertised on TV. The condition improved but did not clear, and the patient showed himself to a Dermatologist. A skin scraping was sent for culture, including culture for fungi. The fungal culture yielded a slow-growing colony, which produces abundant microconidia. Which of the following dermatophyte is the causative agent in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Trichophyton  

  • Trichophyton causes superficial mycoses.
  • It mainly affects cutaneous tissues.
  • Humans and animals are natural reservoirs for this fungus.
  • Macroscopic examination of the trichophyton colonies shows powdery, waxy or velvety growths, with pigmentation characteristic of different species of this fungus.
  • Microscopic examination of trichophyton colonies shows microconidia and macroconidia.
  • Microconidia are abundant. They are arranged in clusters along the hyphae or borne on conidiophores.
  • Macroconidia are relatively scant. They are generally thin, elongated with blunt ends and have distinctive shapes in different species.
  •  Trichophyton rubrum is the most common cause of chronic, treatment-resistant lesions in humans.

Microconidia Trichophyton :

 

 

Macroconidia Trichophyton

 

 

 

Option B: Microsporum

  • Microsporum is a superficial dermatophyte.
  • The Microsporum genus has different anthropophilic, zoophilic and geophilic species.
  • Macroscopic examination of Microsporum colonies shows cotton-like, powdery, or velvety growths. Colonies show brown to white pigmentation.
  • Microconidia and macroconidia are seen on microscopic examination of Microsporum growths in a culture media.
  • Microconidia are relatively scanty.
  • Macroconidia of Microsporum fungus are large, multicellular, spindle-shaped structures. They are present singly on the ends of hyphae.

 

Macroconidia Microsporum:

 

Option C: Epidermophyton

  • Epidermophyton causes superficial mycoses of the skin and hair.
  • They are mainly anthropophilic fungi.
  • Epidermophyton colonies are powdery and produce greenish-yellow pigments.
  • This fungus does not produce microconidia.
  • Macroconidia seen on microscopic examination of the cultures are multicellular, pear-shaped, and typically arranged in clusters.

 

Macroconidia Epidermophyton:

Option D: Trichosporon

  • Trichosporon is a genus of anamorphic fungi.
  • This fungus is typically found in the soil.
  • White piedra is a condition caused by the proliferation of trichophyton fungus in the hair.
  • This genus has no sexual states.
  • Microscopically, trichosporon species have characteristic yeast cells germinating to produce hyaline hyphae.
  • Hyaline hyphae disarticulate at the septa. Hyphal compartments act as arthroconidia.

questions.text: A 6-year-old presented to the clinic with scaly patches on the scalp. The hair was fluoresced under Wood's light. Primary smears of skin and hair demonstrated septate hyphae. Growth of the pathogen on a slope of modified Leonian’s agar shows yellow feathery colonies. Spindle-shaped multicellular macroconidia and small single-celled microconidia were seen. On speaking with the parent, it was found that there were several pets in the household. Which of the following is the most likely agent?
questions.solution:
Option C: Microsporum canis

  • Microsporum canis is a zoophilic dermatophyte.
  • It is a causal agent for tinea capitis in humans, children in particular.
  • Pets such as dogs and cats are the reservoirs of this fungus.
  • Growth in a culture medium shows yellow colonies due to the metabolites secreted by the fungus.
  • It forms spindle-shaped, multicelled macroconidia and small, single-celled microconidia.
  • Examination of the infected tissue under Wood’s lamp shows septate hyphae and fluoresce bright green.

Option A: Epidermophyton floccosum

  • Epidermophyton floccosum is an anthropophillic dermatophyte.
  • This species is found more commonly in tropical and subtropical areas.
  • Colonies of epidermophyton floccosum grown on Sabouraud agar forms white pleomorphic tufts. Its colonies also produce reddish-brown pigment.
  • They form smooth, thin-walled and club-shaped macroconidia. This specie does not form microconidia.
  • It most commonly causes tinea pedis and tinea cruris but less commonly tinea capitis because it cannot perforate hair follicles.

Option B: Microsporum audouinii

  • Microsporum audouinii is a geophilic dermatophyte.
  • It causes tinea capitis mostly in prepubescent children (starting at 6 months) and rarely in adults.
  • Microscopy of the infected tissues shows spindle-shaped macroconidia and few microconidia.
  • Racquet-shaped hyphae are characteristic of Microsporum audouinii.
  • On potato dextrose agar, Microsporum audouinii form colonies with a silky texture and a peach-coloured underside.

Option D: Trichophyton rubrum

  • Trichophyton rubrum is an anthropophilic dermatophyte.
  • It causes athlete’s foot, fungal infection of nails, and jock itch. It very rarely causes tinea capitis.
  • It thrives on the dead layer of tissues.
  • Trichophyton rubrum grows slowly on culture medium and forms tear-drop or peg-shaped microconidia.
  • It forms greenish colonies on Littman Oxgall agar.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presented to the medical outpatient department with a complaint o fever, sore throat, and malaise. On throat examination, reddened enlarged tonsils are seen, and the pharynx is inflamed. There is splenomegaly on abdominal examination. The patient also complains of extreme fatigue. What is the best test for confirmation of a causative agent?
questions.solution:
Option B: IgM heterophile antibodies

  • In the above-given case, the symptoms of the inflamed pharynx, splenomegaly, enlarged tonsils, and fever is suggestive of infectious mononucleosis.
  • It is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus or Human herpes virus-4 (HHV-4).
  • It is transmitted via body secretion, especially saliva.
  • It causes fever, malaise, sore throat, anorexia, and myalgias.
  • On examination of bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy (mostly posterior chain), splenomegaly is present.
  • On blood smear, absolute lymphocytosis is seen.
  • The monospot test is used to detect heterophile antibodies.
  • In the acute phase, IgM heterophile antibody is present, and it falls after recovery.
  • Complications include secondary bacterial pharyngitis and splenic rupture.

Option A: A positive Tzanck smear

  • Tzanck giant cells are multinucleated cells.
  • These are seen in the following conditions: Pemphigus Vulgaris, herpes simplex type 1, varicella-zoster virus, and cytomegalovirus.

Option C: Koilocytotic cells

  • These are epithelial cells that have a hyperchromatic nucleus.
  • They are mostly present in HPV-infected epithelial cells. RT

Option D: RT-PCR for Enterovirus

  • This test is used to detect enterovirus in cerebrospinal fluid.
  • Quantitative PCR can also be used for the detection of viral presence.

questions.text: All of the following statements about E. Coli strains are right EXCEPT:

choices.text: Enteroaggregative E. coli is associated with Persistent diarrhoea
Enterohemorrhagic E. coli can cause hemolytic uraemic syndrome
Enteroinvasive E. coli produces a disease similar to salmonellosis
Enterotoxigenic E. coli is a common cause of travelers’ diarrhoea

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C. Enteroinvasive E. coli produces a disease similar to salmonellosis

This statement is wrong, as Enteroinvasive E. coli produces a disease similar to shigellosis, not salmonellosis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the physician with complaints of double vision, difficulty swallowing and difficulty breathing after 40 hours of eating food at the restaurant. The patient has no history of any other chronic illness. He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. The symptoms of the patient are consistent with which of the following?

choices.text: Invasion of the gut epithelium by an organism

questions.solution:
Option C: Ingestion of neurotoxin

  • This is a case of food poisoning in which the patient presents with complaints of double vision, difficulty swallowing and difficulty breathing after 40 hours of eating food at the restaurant.
  • Ingestion of a neurotoxin is responsible for the symptoms mentioned above in the patient.

Food poisonin

  • Ingestion of preformed toxins in food contaminated with C. botulinum.
  • The severity of illness: mild to very serious disease resulting in death within 24 hours.
  • Incubation Period-12 to 36 hours after ingestion of the contaminated food.
  • Clostridium botulinum produces a potent neurotoxin.
  • Clostridium botulinum produces both neurotoxins and enterotoxins.

Option A: Activation of cyclic AMP

  • The activation of cyclic AMP causes diarrhoea.
  • It doesn't cause this type of food poisoning

Option B: Endotoxin shock

  • This clinical condition is not associated with endotoxin shock. It is a case of food poisoning.
  • Symptoms are:
    • Arms and legs are icy and pallid.
    • chills in very high or very low temperatures.
    • Lightheadedness.
    • Almost no urine.
    • Blood pressure that is particularly low when standing.
    • Palpitations.
    • quick heartbeat.
    • Anxiety, lassitude, or confusion

Option D: Invasion of gut epithelium by an organism

  • The invasion of the gut epithelium by microorganisms doesn't usually cause the symptoms mentioned in the case above.

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of an N95 mask?

choices.text: To protect the wearer from all harmful airborne particles
To protect others from the wearer's respiratory droplets
To provide respiratory support for individuals with respiratory distress
To filter out harmful chemicals and toxins in the air

questions.solution:
The primary purpose of an N95 mask is to protect others from the wearer's respiratory droplets, which may contain infectious agents. N95 masks are designed to filter out at least 95% of airborne droplets and particles, including those that are too small to be seen with the naked eye. They are commonly used in healthcare settings to prevent the spread of infectious diseases, such as COVID-19.

Why other options are incorrect:

Option A: To protect the wearer from all harmful airborne particles: While N95 masks do offer some level of protection (close to 95%) to the wearer, their primary purpose is to protect others from the wearer's respiratory droplets.

Option C: To provide respiratory support for individuals with respiratory distress: N95 masks are not designed to provide respiratory support or assist with breathing in any way.

Option D: To filter out harmful chemicals and toxins in the air: While N95 masks can filter out some types of harmful airborne particles, they are not designed to filter out chemicals or toxins in the air.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding innate immunity?

choices.text: It is due to the genetic and constitutional makeup of an individual.
It develops after exposure to a specific pathogen.
It is dependent on the production of antibodies.
It provides long-lasting protection against infections.

questions.solution:
Innate immunity refers to the non-specific defense mechanisms that are present from birth and do not require prior exposure to a specific pathogen. These defense mechanisms are due to the genetic and constitutional makeup of an individual and include physical barriers (e.g. skin, mucous membranes), phagocytic cells (e.g. neutrophils, macrophages), and the complement system. Innate immunity provides rapid but short-lived protection against infections and helps to initiate the adaptive immune response.

Why other options are incorrect

Option B: It develops after exposure to a specific pathogen: This statement is incorrect because this refers to acquired or adaptive immunity, which develops after exposure to a specific pathogen and involves the production of pathogen-specific antibodies and immune cells.

Option C: It is dependent on the production of antibodies: This statement is incorrect because innate immunity does not involve the production of antibodies, which is a hallmark of acquired immunity.

Option D: It provides long-lasting protection against infections: This statement is incorrect because innate immunity provides rapid but short-lived protection against infections, whereas acquired immunity can provide long-lasting protection.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about xenografts is true?

choices.text: Xenografts involve the transfer of tissue from one individual of the same species to another.
Xenografts involve the transfer of tissue from one species to another.
Xenografts are only used for research purposes and not for medical treatments.
Xenografts are only used in veterinary medicine and not in human medicine.

questions.solution:
Xenografts involve the transfer of tissue or cells from one species to another. This is different from allografts, which involve the transfer of tissue or cells from one individual of the same species to another. Xenografts are often used in medical treatments, such as in the case of animal-to-human organ transplants. However, xenografts are associated with a high risk of rejection and other complications, so they are not commonly used in clinical practice. 

Option A: is incorrect because it describes allografts rather than xenografts. 
Option C: is incorrect because xenografts are used in medical treatments as well as research. 
Option D: is incorrect because xenografts are used in both human and veterinary medicine.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective treatment for sporotrichosis?
questions.solution:
Sporotrichosis is a fungal infection caused by the fungus Sporothrix schenckii. Topical antifungal therapy may be effective for localized forms of the infection, but systemic antifungal therapy is considered the most effective treatment for all forms of sporotrichosis, especially for disseminated and severe infections. Surgical excision may be considered in certain cases, but it is not a primary treatment option. Immune therapy is not a recognized treatment for sporotrichosis.

Why are other options incorrect:

Option A: Topical antifungal therapy is incorrect because it is only effective for localized forms of infection.

Option C: Surgical excision is incorrect because it is not a primary treatment option and may only be considered in certain cases.

Option D: Immunotherapy is incorrect because it is not a recognized treatment for sporotrichosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a bacterial infection characterized by the formation of abscesses and draining sinuses, often involving the face and neck?
questions.solution:
Actinomycosis is a rare subacute to chronic bacterial infection caused by the Actinomyces species, which are normal inhabitants of the oral cavity and gastrointestinal tract. It is characterized by the formation of abscesses and draining sinuses, often involving the face and neck. 

Why are other options incorrect:

Option A: Aspergillosis a fungal infection caused by Aspergillus species leads to Allergic Reaction known as Bronchopulmonary aspergillosis. It may further leads to formation of aspergilloma which is a tangled mass of fungus ball in lung cavity.

Option C: Candidiasis is a fungal infection caused by Candida species. It leads to formation of red rashes in case of Cutaneous manifestations. It may lead to Vaginal yeast infection causing a thick white discharge. Oral thrush caused by Candida sp. causes white lesions on the tongue or inner cheeks. 

Option D: Histoplasmosis is a fungal infection caused by Histoplasma capsulatum. Symptoms include fever, cough, muscle aches and chest discomfort. Histoplasmosis mainly affects lungs and leads to pneumonia.

questions.text: A 37-year-old female in OPD complained of discomfort and a palpable mass in her left breast. Physical examination revealed a non-tender, hard, and fixed mass of around 5 to 2.5 cm in the upper outer quadrant of her left breast. Histopathology shows dermal lymphatic invasion by the tumor cells. Which of the following statements is accurate about the patient's condition?

choices.text: It is the most common breast cancer
It is common after the age of 55

questions.solution:
Option C: It has the worst prognosis

  • Inflammatory breast cancer is a rare and very aggressive disease in which cancer cells block lymph vessels in the skin of the breast.
  • This type of breast cancer is called “inflammatory” because the breast often looks swollen and red or inflamed.
  • It is usually confused with breast infection like mastitis/breast abscess, and histopathology confirms the diagnosis.
  • It is the most malignant and has the worst prognosis of all breast cancers.

Option A: It is the most common breast cancer

  • Inflammatory breast cancer is a rare type of breast cancer.(most common breast cancer is ductal or lobular carcinoma).

Option B: It is common after the age 55

  • Inflammatory breast cancer occurs in younger women (younger than 40).

Option D: It is non-invasive

  • Inflammatory breast carcinoma is very invasive.
  • It develops rapidly and spreads to nearby structures

questions.text: A 51-year-old postmenopausal female with infiltrating ductal carcinoma was treated with 20mg of Tamoxifen daily and radiotherapy (as adjuvant therapy). Chronic treatment with Tamoxifen can increase the risk of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Option B: Endometrial carcinoma

  • Tamoxifen is effective in Estrogen Receptor (ER) positive breast carcinoma, but some ER-negative tumours also respond to tamoxifen.
  • The potent antagonist of estrogen in breast cells
  • Partial agonist activity in the bone and the uterus
  • It induces pro-oestrogenic changes in the endometrium resulting in abnormal growth of the endometrium, and therefore, it increases the incidence of endometrial cancer

Option A: Epithelial Ovarian carcinoma

  • This is not associated with chronic use of tamoxifen therapy.

Options C: Cervical carcinoma 

  • Cervical carcinoma is associated with Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, not tamoxifen therapy.

Options D: Vulvar carcinoma

  • This is associated with Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection, not tamoxifen therapy.

questions.text: What formula is used to calculate the Nottingham Prognostic Index for breast cancer in a 47-year-old female with invasive ductal carcinoma who underwent a partial mastectomy?
questions.solution:
Option A: (0.2 x size ) + grade + nodes

Nottingham Prognostic Index (NPI)

  • The Nottingham Prognostic Index (NPI) is used to assess the prognosis of breast cancer patients after surgery. Three pathological factors: tumor grade, number of affected lymph nodes, and tumor size are used to compute its value.
  • NPI =(0.2 x tumor size in cm ) + Tumor grade + lymph node stage
  • NPI less than 3.4 is considered good, and a score >5.4 is considered poor in terms of prognosis
  • Used to select patients for adjuvant treatment

Options B: (0.4 x size ) + grade + nodes

  • These formulas are not correct.
  • NPI is calculated by multiplying tumor size by 0.2

Options C: (0.6 x size ) + grade + nodes

  • These formulas are not correct.
  • NPI is calculated by multiplying tumor size by 0.2

Options D: (0.8 x size ) + grade + nodes

  • These formulas are not correct.
  • NPI is calculated by multiplying tumor size by 0.2

questions.text: A 64-year-old female presents to the OPD for a regular check-up. A physical examination revealed a hard mass of almost 2 cm in diameter. Histopathology is suggestive of ductal carcinoma in situ. A plan is made to get her sentinel lymph node biopsied using a gamma probe. What is the most common complication of this technique?
questions.solution:
Option D: Skin tattooing

  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy is a reliable method for evaluating the axillary lymph node status in early-stage breast cancer patients with non-palpable lymph nodes.
  • Sentinel LN: First LN which receives lymph directly from the tumor
  • Indication of SLN biopsy in breast cancer: Clinically non-palpable axillary LN
  • A gamma probe is used in the given image during a sentinel lymph node biopsy.
  • Skin tattooing is the most common complication of sentinel lymph node biopsy using a gamma probe.

Option A: Intercostobrachial nerve palsy

  • Intercostobrachial nerve palsy can occur during sentinel node biopsy, but it is uncommon.

Option B: Anaphylaxis

  • It occurs due to the contrast agent used in SLN biopsy
  • It can occur during SLN biopsy, but it is still less common than skin tattooing

Option C: Necrosis

  • It is a feared complication of SLN biopsy using a gamma probe, but it is less common than tattooing.

questions.text: Ixabepilone (Ixempra), a semi-synthetic epothilone B analog, is a chemotherapeutic drug given intravenously (IV). It is a microtubule inhibitor and is usually used with capecitabine or alone as a second-line drug for locally advanced or metastatic cancer. Which of the following cancers is it indicated for?
questions.solution:
Option B: Breast carcinoma

  • Ixabepilone (Ixempra) is a microtubule inhibitor most commonly used for locally advanced or metastatic breast cancer.
  • It is a second-line drug in patients resistant to Adriamycin (doxorubicin) or taxanes.

Chemotherapy regimens used in carcinoma Breast

  •  Mnemonic- CMF
    • C: Cyclophosphamide
    • M: Methotrexate
    • F: 5-fluorouracil (5FU)
  • Mnemonic-CAF
    • C: Cyclophosphamide
    • A: Adriamycin (doxorubicin)
    • F: 5FU
  • The preferred form of Chemotherapy for CA breast is CAF, Adriamycin, or Anthracycline-based Chemotherapy.
  • Usually, 6 cycles are given.
  • For Adriamycin-resistant breast cancer - Taxanes are given (Docetaxel, Paclitaxel).
  • Chemotherapy agent is given in Adriamycin & Taxane resistant breast cancer IXABEPILONE.
  • Lapatinib is a 2nd line agent for HER-2-NEU-positive breast cancer
  • Herceptin /Trastuzumab – 1st line agent for HER-2-NEU-positive breast cancer
  • Sunitinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, is a second-line chemotherapeutic drug in metastatic and refractory breast cancer.

Option A: Melanoma

  • Pembrolizumab(Keytruda) is the first-line drug for metastatic or unresectable melanoma
  • Ipilimumab, either alone or in combination with nivolumab, is used as a second-line drug for unresectable or metastatic melanoma.

Option C: Oat cell carcinoma

  • Small cell carcinoma of the lung is also called oat cell carcinoma.
  • Combination therapy with cisplatin, etoposide, and irinotecan or topotecan alone is used as second-line therapy for oat cell carcinoma.

Option D: Prostate cancer

  • Cabazitaxel, abiraterone acetate, and enzalutamide are second-line drugs for metastatic Castration-resistant prostate cancer(mCRPC).

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presents to the surgery OPD with complaints of increased swelling in her neck over the previous 2 years. She has had a medical history of severe hearing loss since early childhood. On examination, she has a large goiter extending retrosternally with small irregular nodules, no audible bruit, and a negative Pemberton's sign. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ANSWER

Option D: Pendred syndrome

  • The patient mentioned above has clinical features of sensory neural hearing loss associated with goitre. This presentation is typical of Pendred syndrome.
  • Presentation of Pendred syndrome:
    • Hearing loss or deafness
    • Speech impairment
    • Electrolyte/homeostasis imbalance
    • Goitre
    • Enlarged vestibular aqueduct
    • Hypothyroidism
  • Pendred Syndrome is the combination of sensorineural hearing loss with dyshormonogenetic goitre.
  • It is autosomal recessive. The affected gene is located on chromosome 7q.
  • There is a mutation of the PDS gene, which encodes for pendrin, the protein that transports iodide to the luminal surface of the follicular cell.

Other options

Option A: Werner syndrome

  • Werner syndrome (MEN1) occurs due to germline mutation in the MEN1 gene located in chromosome 11 that encodes menin. It is autosomal dominant hereditary cancer syndrome.
  • Symptoms and signs are shorter than average height, thin arms and legs, voice changes, thinning and greying hair, skin changes, and unusual facial features.

Option B: Turcot syndrome

  • Turcot syndrome is characterized by the following:
    • Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP).
    • Primary CNS tumors (astrocytoma or medulloblastoma).

Option C: Cowden syndrome

  • Cowden's syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder due to mutations in PTEN.
  • Associated cancers include:
    • Breast carcinoma
    • Thyroid carcinoma
    • Endometrial carcinoma

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to 12 hours of malaise and fever with chills. The patient also has pain in multiple joints. The patient is sexually active. Examination shows several pustules on the chest, forearms, palms, and fingers. The joint examination shows no swelling, but the right wrist and left ankle are tender on palpation, especially with active or passive joint movement. There is no cervical, axillary, or inguinal lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Gonococcal infection

  • This patient’s polyarthralgia, tenosynovitis, and pustular lesions most likely suggest disseminated gonococcal infections. It usually occurs when the primary infection is not adequately treated.
  • Neisseria gonorrhea is one of the most common causes of sexually transmitted diseases in women.
In Males In Females
  • Urethritis
  • Epididymitis
  • Cervicitis
  • Urethritis

Complications

  • Anorectal infection
  • Pharyngeal infection
  • Conjunctivitis
  • Disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI)

Complications

  • Accessory gland infection
    • Bartholin’s glands
    • Skene’s glands
  • Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)
  • Fitz-Hugh-Curtis Syndrome - Perihepatitis
  • Anorectal infection
  • Pharyngeal infection
  • Conjunctivitis
  • Disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI)

Option A: Parvo B 19 infection

  • Parvovirus B19 is associated with fever, rash, and arthritis. However, the rash is usually on the malar surface and is then followed by a lace-like rash on the trunk and extremities. Pustular lesions would be atypical.

Option B: Secondary syphilis

  • Secondary syphilis can present with fever and rash. However, the rash is usually generalized, symmetric, and maculopapular and typically occurs on the trunk, extremities, palms, and soles.

Option D: Rheumatic fever

  • Rheumatic fever can cause migratory polyarthritis and rash; the rash is subcutaneous nodules or erythema marginatum (evanescent, pinkish rash), not pustules.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male patient complains of prolonged bleeding from an ulcer over the right lower limb.  The daily dressings with non-adherent paraffin gas patients have been performed since then, but the ulcer did not heal. Hence, he undergoes debridement and Thiersch grafting of the right leg ulcer under spinal anesthesia. Which of the following is the advantage of the type of graft used in this patient?

choices.text: The graft can not be taken from the upper arm, flexor aspect of the forearm, and abdominal wall
The is not affected by the hematoma

questions.solution:
Option A: Large-size graft can be taken

  • This patient with a chronic non-healing ulcer underwent debridement and Thiersch grafting.
  • Skin reconstruction can be performed using flaps and grafts. A graft is a tissue that contains just the skin without a blood supply.
  • The Thiersch graft is characterised by a partial-thickness skin graft used to re-epithelialize portions of the affected skin.
  • This highly effective technique allows a significantly shorter postoperative recovery time.
  • The advantage of Thiersch grafting is that large-size grafts can be taken.
  • The following table summarises the types of various skin grafts and their advantages and disadvantages:

Type of Graft

Advantages

Disadvantages

Thin Split

Thickness

  • Best Survival
  • Heals Rapidly
  • Least resembles original skin.
  • Least resistance to trauma.
  • Poor Sensation
  • Maximal Secondary Contraction 

Thick Split

Thickness

 
  • More qualifies of normal skin.
  • Less Contraction
  • Looks better
  • Fair Sensation

 
  • Lower graft survival
  • Slower healing.

 

Full Thickness

 
  • Most resembles normal skin.
  • Minimal Secondary contraction
  • Resistant to trauma
  • Good Sensation
  • Aesthetically pleasing
  • Poorest survival.
  • Donor site must be closed surgically.
  • Donor sites are limited.

 

Option B: Consists of the epidermis only.

  • This statement is incorrect, as a Thiersch graft consists of the epidermis and a variable portion of the dermis.

Option C: The graft can be taken from the upper arm, flexor aspect of the forearm, and abdominal wall

  • This statement is incorrect as a Thiersch graft can be taken from the upper arm, flexor aspect of the forearm, and abdominal wall

Option D: The is not affected by the hematoma

  • This statement is incorrect, as hematoma (or seroma), infection, and movement (shear) are among the most common causes of skin graft failure.

questions.text: An 85-year-old woman was brought to the emergency room by her son due to a penetrating stab injury on the anterior neck. A kitchen knife was deeply stuck in the midline of the anterior neck, but there was no active bleeding. The patient was semiconscious; bradycardia and hypotension were noted. Which of the following is the most likely reason?
questions.solution:
Option D: Neurogenic shock 

  • Results from loss or suppression of sympathetic tone resulted in massive vasodilation in venous Vasculature leading to decreased Venous return and decreased cardiac output, which results in impaired tissue perfusion & cellular metabolism.
  • Clinical features
  • Paralysis below the level of the lesion; hypotension
  • Bradycardia due to loss of sympathetic tone → Arterial & venous vasodilation → Warm & dry skin
  • Hypothermia

Option A: Hypovolemic shock

  • Hypovolemic shock results in tachycardia to compensate for cardiac output.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option B: Distributive

  • Distributive shock is also called septic shock.
  • In septic shock, there is a decrease in peripheral vascular resistance, which results in tachycardia and increased cardiac output to maintain peripheral perfusion.

Option C: Hypovolemic + septicemic shock

  • Hypovolemic & septicemia shock both results in tachycardia.
  • Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: What is the most common presenting symptom of anaplastic thyroid carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Option A

  • Anaplastic thyroid carcinoma is a rare and aggressive malignancy that arises from the follicular cells of the thyroid gland. It is often associated with a poor prognosis due to its rapid growth and tendency to metastasize. The most common presenting symptom of anaplastic thyroid carcinoma is hoarseness, which is caused by vocal cord paralysis due to invasion of the recurrent laryngeal nerve. Other common symptoms include difficulty swallowing, neck pain, and dyspnea.

Why other options are incorrect

Option B: Thyroid nodules are a common finding in many types of thyroid cancer, including papillary and follicular thyroid carcinoma, but they are not specific to anaplastic thyroid carcinoma.

Option C: Difficulty swallowing can occur in anaplastic thyroid carcinoma, but it is not the most common presenting symptom.

Option D: Neck pain can occur in anaplastic thyroid carcinoma, but it is not the most common presenting symptom.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes a lateral aberrant thyroid?

choices.text: An ectopic thyroid gland located outside the normal thyroid bed
A thyroid nodule located on the lateral aspect of the thyroid gland
An accessory thyroid gland located adjacent to the normal thyroid gland
A thyroid carcinoma with lateral extension beyond the thyroid capsule

questions.solution:
Option A

  • A lateral aberrant thyroid is a rare congenital anomaly where an ectopic thyroid gland is located outside the normal thyroid bed, usually in the lateral neck region. It can present as a solitary mass or as multiple nodules. Treatment depends on the functional status of the gland and the presence of any associated symptoms.

Why other options are incorrect

  • Option B: is incorrect because a thyroid nodule located on the lateral aspect of the thyroid gland is not an aberrant thyroid, but rather a thyroid nodule located in an abnormal location within the thyroid gland.
  • Option C: is incorrect because an accessory thyroid gland is a normal variant and is located adjacent to the normal thyroid gland.
  • Option D: is incorrect because lateral extension of a thyroid carcinoma beyond the thyroid capsule is not the same as a lateral aberrant thyroid.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Pendred Syndrome?

choices.text: It is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by sensorineural hearing loss, goiter, and abnormal thyroid function tests
It is an X-linked dominant disorder characterized by the development of multiple osteochondromas
It is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the presence of multiple hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract
It is a type of neurofibromatosis characterized by the presence of multiple café-au-lait spots and neurofibromas

questions.solution:
Pendred Syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the development of sensorineural hearing loss, goiter, and abnormal thyroid function tests. It is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, which means both parents must pass on a copy of the mutated gene for a child to be affected.

Why other options are incorrect:
Option B: is incorrect because the described condition is Hereditary Multiple Exostoses, which is characterized by the development of multiple osteochondromas in the bone.

Option C: is incorrect because the described condition is Peutz-Jeghers Syndrome, which is characterized by the presence of multiple hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract.

Option D: is incorrect because the described condition is Neurofibromatosis type 1, which is characterized by the presence of multiple café-au-lait spots and neurofibromas.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with a palpable abdominal mass. CT scan shows a heterogeneous enhancing mass with calcifications. Biopsy confirms neuroblastoma. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Neuroblastoma is a malignancy that arises from neural crest cells and most commonly presents in young children with a palpable abdominal mass. The diagnosis is confirmed with biopsy, and imaging with CT or MRI is used to assess the extent of the disease. Treatment depends on the stage of the tumor and the age of the patient. For high-risk neuroblastoma, treatment usually involves a combination of surgery, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy. In this case, the next best step in management would be chemotherapy, as it is the mainstay of treatment for neuroblastoma.

Why other options are incorrect

Option A: Surgical resection: Surgical resection may be considered as a part of treatment for neuroblastoma, especially for low-risk tumors or those that are localized. However, in this case, chemotherapy would be the next best step before considering surgery.

Option C: Radiation therapy: Radiation therapy may be used as part of treatment for high-risk neuroblastoma, but it is usually given after chemotherapy.

Option D: Observation: Observation alone is not appropriate for the management of neuroblastoma, as it is a highly malignant tumor that requires aggressive treatment.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman underwent transsphenoidal surgery for a pituitary adenoma 5 years ago. She presents with a history of increasing headache, visual field defects, and increasing pigmentation of her skin. MRI reveals a pituitary mass measuring 3 cm. Laboratory studies show elevated ACTH levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Nelson Syndrome is a rare disorder that occurs after bilateral adrenalectomy for Cushing Syndrome. It is characterized by the development of a large, invasive, and aggressive ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma. The adenoma can cause hyperpigmentation of the skin, visual field defects, and headaches. MRI is the diagnostic tool of choice, and treatment usually involves surgical resection followed by radiation therapy.

Why other options are incorrect:
Option B: Acromegaly is caused by a growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenoma, and is characterized by the enlargement of the hands, feet, and facial features. This condition is not associated with pigmentation of the skin or elevated ACTH levels.

Option C: Cushing Syndrome is caused by excessive cortisol production, and can be the result of either an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma or an adrenal tumor. This patient had a history of pituitary adenoma resection, making Cushing Syndrome less likely. Additionally, the pigmentation of the skin is not a typical feature of Cushing Syndrome.

Option D: Pituitary apoplexy is a rare condition that occurs when there is bleeding or infarction of a pituitary adenoma. This can cause sudden headache, visual changes, and hormonal dysfunction. However, the gradual onset of symptoms and the history of previous pituitary adenoma resection make this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with shortness of breath and cough. CT scan shows bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and pulmonary infiltrates. On further evaluation, she is diagnosed with sarcoidosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
The most appropriate initial treatment for sarcoidosis is corticosteroids, typically prednisone. The dose and duration of treatment depend on the severity of symptoms and disease activity. Methotrexate, azathioprine, and cyclophosphamide are used as alternative treatments in cases where corticosteroids are not effective or cannot be used due to side effects.

Why other options are incorrect:

Option B: Methotrexate is used as an alternative treatment for sarcoidosis when corticosteroids are not effective or cannot be used due to side effects. It is not the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient.

Option C: Azathioprine is used as an alternative treatment for sarcoidosis when corticosteroids are not effective or cannot be used due to side effects. It is not the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient.

Option D: Cyclophosphamide is used as an alternative treatment for sarcoidosis when corticosteroids are not effective or cannot be used due to side effects. It is not the most appropriate initial treatment for this patient.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents with Frey's syndrome after a parotidectomy. Which of the following is the best management option for this patient?

choices.text: Revision surgery to create a new flap

questions.solution:
Frey's syndrome is a disorder characterized by gustatory sweating in the preauricular region that occurs after parotidectomy. The mechanism of this syndrome is thought to be the formation of aberrant autonomic nerves that grow into the skin of the surgical bed. Injection of botulinum toxin is an effective treatment option for Frey's syndrome as it blocks the release of acetylcholine from the cholinergic nerve endings responsible for sweating. This can provide long-lasting relief of symptoms.

Why other options are incorrect
Option A: Observation with reassurance is not an effective treatment option for Frey's syndrome as the symptoms are bothersome and can significantly impact quality of life.
Option B: Topical anticholinergic agents are not an effective treatment option for Frey's syndrome as they can cause local skin irritation and may be absorbed systemically, leading to adverse effects.
Option D: Revision surgery to create a new flap is not an effective treatment option for Frey's syndrome as it is an invasive procedure with potential complications, and there is a risk of recurrence.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of swelling and pain in his left leg, which has been worsening for the past few months. On examination, the patient is found to have varicose veins in his left leg, with significant swelling and discoloration of the skin. Doppler ultrasound confirms the presence of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the left leg. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Referral to a vascular surgeon for varicose vein surgery
Immediate surgical intervention with vein ligation and stripping

questions.solution:
The presence of DVT in a patient with varicose veins requires immediate anticoagulation therapy to prevent the progression of thrombosis and the risk of pulmonary embolism. 

Why other options are incorrect
Option B: Conservative management with compression stockings may be useful in mild cases of varicose veins, but is not appropriate in the presence of DVT. 

Option C: Referral to a vascular surgeon for varicose vein surgery may be considered after the resolution of DVT, but is not the immediate priority. 

Option D: Immediate surgical intervention with vein ligation and stripping is not appropriate in the presence of DVT, as it may increase the risk of complications.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male smoker presents with a 2-year history of progressive pain and numbness in his left leg. On physical examination, he has absent pulses in the left foot and calf, and decreased hair growth on the left leg. Which of the following is the best management option for this patient?

choices.text: Angioplasty of the left popliteal artery
Below-knee amputation of the left leg

questions.solution:
Thromboangiitis obliterans (also known as Buerger's disease) is a nonatherosclerotic, segmental inflammatory disease that affects the small- to medium-sized arteries and veins of the extremities, particularly in young male smokers. The classic presentation of Thromboangiitis obliterans includes pain and numbness in the affected limb, absent pulses, and decreased hair growth. The mainstay of treatment is smoking cessation, which is the only effective way to halt disease progression and prevent amputation. Angioplasty, below-knee amputation, and lumbar sympathectomy are not indicated in the treatment of Thromboangiitis obliterans.

Why other options are incorrect

Option A: Angioplasty of the left popliteal artery is not indicated in the treatment of Thromboangiitis obliterans, as the disease affects multiple vessels and is not limited to a single stenotic lesion.

Option B: Below-knee amputation of the left leg is not indicated in the treatment of Thromboangiitis obliterans, as the disease is treatable with smoking cessation and amputation should be reserved for cases of severe limb ischemia or infection.

Option C: Lumbar sympathectomy is not indicated in the treatment of Thromboangiitis obliterans, as it has not been shown to improve limb perfusion or prevent disease progression.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of a pulsatile mass in his left wrist that has been gradually increasing in size over the past few months. On examination, there is a prominent thrill and bruit over the mass. Doppler ultrasound reveals a high flow arteriovenous fistula. What is the most appropriate management option for this patient?

choices.text: Surgical ligation and excision of the fistula

questions.solution:
Surgical ligation and excision of the fistula is the most appropriate management option for a high flow AVF as it involves complete closure of the abnormal connection between the artery and vein. This can be done through a surgical incision and excision of the abnormal connection, or with the use of endovascular techniques.
Arteriovenous fistula (AVF) is an abnormal connection between an artery and a vein that causes abnormal blood flow and pressure in both vessels. It can occur anywhere in the body but is commonly seen in the extremities, particularly the wrist. In the case presented, the patient has a high flow AVF in his left wrist that is causing symptoms and requires treatment.

Why other options are incorrect

Option A: Conservative management with close monitoring is not appropriate in this case as the fistula is symptomatic and has a high flow rate. 

Option B: Endovascular coil embolization is a minimally invasive procedure that can be used to block the blood flow in the fistula but it may not be effective in high flow AVFs. 

Option D: Sclerotherapy with ethanol injection is a treatment option for low flow AVFs but is not appropriate for high flow AVFs.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with a chronic non-healing ulcer on the right lower leg that has been present for several years. Biopsy of the ulcer reveals squamous cell carcinoma. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Wide local excision with 1 cm margins
Amputation of the right lower leg

questions.solution:
Marjolin's ulcer is a rare type of squamous cell carcinoma that arises in a chronic non-healing wound, typically after a burn injury or chronic ulceration. In this patient with a chronic non-healing ulcer on the right lower leg that has been present for several years, biopsy reveals squamous cell carcinoma, which is consistent with Marjolin's ulcer. The most appropriate management for this patient is wide local excision with 1 cm margins. This is based on the principle of complete surgical resection with negative margins to minimize the risk of recurrence and metastasis.

Why other options are incorrect

Option B: Mohs micrographic surgery is a surgical technique that uses microscopic control to minimize the removal of healthy tissue in the treatment of skin cancers. However, this technique is not appropriate for Marjolin's ulcer, which requires wide local excision with 1 cm margins to minimize the risk of recurrence and metastasis.

Option C:  Amputation of the right lower leg is not indicated in this patient with Marjolin's ulcer, as the cancer has not been shown to have spread beyond the ulcer itself.

Option D: Observation with serial imaging is not appropriate for this patient with Marjolin's ulcer, as surgical excision with negative margins is necessary to minimize the risk of recurrence and metastasis.

questions.text: A 73-year-old male presents to the clinic with a history of aortic stenosis and recurrent episodes of gastrointestinal bleeding. Upon further investigation, he is found to have severe von Willebrand disease. Which of the following conditions is most likely causing his recurrent gastrointestinal bleeding?
questions.solution:
Heyde's syndrome is a rare condition where patients with aortic stenosis develop gastrointestinal bleeding due to the degradation of von Willebrand factor (vWF) in the presence of high shear forces. This degradation is caused by the mechanical stress on the vWF molecule as it passes through the stenotic aortic valve. The decreased levels of vWF in turn lead to impaired platelet function and subsequent gastrointestinal bleeding.

Why other options are incorrect

Option A:  Aortic stenosis is a common comorbidity in Heyde's syndrome, but it is not the primary cause of gastrointestinal bleeding.

Option B: Von Willebrand disease is present in this patient, but it is not the primary cause of the gastrointestinal bleeding in the setting of aortic stenosis.

Option C: Gastrointestinal ulcers can cause bleeding, but in this case, Heyde's syndrome is the most likely cause given the patient's history of aortic stenosis and von Willebrand disease.

questions.text: A 79-year-man is brought to the emergency department after feeling lightheadedness and palpitation. The patient’s past medical history is significant for myocardial infarction 2 months back, for which he was treated with stent placement in the left anterior descending artery. He has been non-compliant with his current medications, which include amlodipine, aspirin, propanolol, and rosuvastatin. On examination, his blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg, his pulse is 128 beats/min irregular, and his respiratory rate is 22 breaths/min. The patient appears restless. His ECG reveals irregular rhythm without significant ST or T wave changes, and the echocardiogram reveals an LV aneurysm. Which of the following is an indication of intracardiac defibrillator use?
questions.solution:
Option D: All of the above

Intracardiac defibrillator or implantable cardioverter defibrillator(ICD):

  • An implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) is an electronic device which is connected to the heart. It is used to continuously monitor and help regulate potentially fast and life-threatening arrhythmias.
  • Indications of ICD are as follows:
  1. Ventricular fibrillation(VF) or sustained unstable ventricular tachycardia(VT) not in the setting of a completely reversible cause.
  2. Left ventricular ejection fraction(LVEF) <35%, congestive heart failure NYHA class 2 and 3.
  3. Ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy, LVEF <40%, non-sustained ventricular tachycardia (NSVT) and inducible sustained VT.
  4. Syncope, LV dysfunction, inducible sustained VT.
  5. High-risk patients with: hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, long QT syndrome, RV dysplasia, and Brugada syndrome.
  • Therefore, all the above options, i.e. arrhythmogenic RV dysplasia, Brugada syndrome and LV aneurysm, are indications of an implantable cardiac defibrillator.

 

Option A: Arrhythmogenic RV dysplasia

  • Arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia (ARVD) is a rare type of cardiomyopathy, which occurs when the cardiomyocytes in the right ventricle die and are replaced with scar tissue. This disrupts the heart's electrical signals and causes arrhythmias. Symptoms include palpitations and fainting after physical activity.
  • Arrhythmogenic RV dysplasia is an indication of ICD, but other options B and C are correct too.

Option B: Brugada syndrome

  • Brugada syndrome is an inherited disease that predisposes patients to fatal cardiac arrhythmias.
  • This is an indication of ICD, but arrhythmogenic RV dysplasia and LV aneurysms are indications of ICD as well.

 Option C: LV aneurysm (Post MI)

  • LV aneurysm symptoms can range from thromboembolism and arrhythmias to structural wall abnormalities.
  • Severe LV aneurysm is managed with ICD; however, arrhythmogenic RV dysplasia and Brugada syndrome are strong indications of ICD too.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the clinic complaining of headaches for the last 5 months. Her Blood pressure is 150/95 mmHg. On the electrolyte profile, her potassium is 2.5 (mmol/L). The patient is also taking Spironolactone. Which of the following is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Option A: Saline infusion test

1. Mineralocorticoid excess

Saline infusion test

2. SIADH

Water loading test

3. Hypopituitarism

Arginine challenge test

4. Addison disease

Cosyntropin test
  • The accepted screening test for mineralocorticoid excess is the aldosterone renin ratio.
  • ARR screening is positive if ratio is > 750pmol/L per ng/ml.
  • For obvious reasons, spironolactone should be discontinued for at least 4 weeks before performing this test.
  • This is followed by the performance of the investigation of choice for mineralocorticoid excess, which is the Saline infusion test.
  • Saline infusion test: hypertonic saline is given to patients, and aldosterone levels are checked. If raised  >50 ng/l, it confirms mineralocorticoid excess

Option B:  Cosyntropin test

  • A Cosyntropin test is done for Addison's disease, which is primary adrenal gland insufficiency. Cosyntropin is ACTH, and it is given to patients if, even after administration, the levels of cortisol hormone are less than it is Addison's disease

Option C:  Water loading test

  • For SIADH water loading test is done where water is given to patients, and if after 4 hours osmolality is not less  < than100, then it confirms SIADH

   Option D:  Arginine challenge test

  • Hypopituitarism is confirmed with the arginine challenge test. Where arginine is given to patients, which stimulates the hormones like Growth hormone released from the pituitary gland. If GH levels remain low, it confirms Hypopituitarism

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy comes to the clinic with complaints of fever, night sweats and weight loss for the past two weeks. His examination reveals a firm, mobile and painless masses in his neck. Lymph node biopsy is positive for Reed Sternberg cells. Which of the following conditions is most likely to be associated with this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Minimal Change Disease

  • The patient's condition of fever, night sweats, weight loss with lymphadenopathy, and Reed Sternberg cells is indicative of Hodgkin's lymphoma.
  • Minimal change disease (MCD) is the most common nephrotic syndrome in children and presents with selective proteinuria.
  • It responds well to steroids and can be treated as such.
  • It is usually idiopathic but can be caused by secondary conditions, including immunisations, infections, and malignancies.
  • MCD is the most common nephropathy associated with Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

Option A: Membranous Nephropathy

  • Membranous nephropathy is the most common nephrotic syndrome in adults.
  • In addition to infections and autoimmune conditions, membranous nephropathy is usually associated with solid organ malignancies, including lung, breast, and gastrointestinal adenocarcinoma. It is not associated with Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

Option C: Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis
