  • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is an immune complex/complement deposition mediated condition which can present with either nephritic or nephrotic range proteinuria and hematuria.
  • It is usually associated with autoimmune conditions (e.g. SLE) or infections. (e.g. hepatitis B, hepatitis C)
  • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis may be associated with Nonhodgkin’s lymphoma in certain cases, not Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

Option D: IgA Nephropathy

  • IgA nephropathy occurs after a viral infection and is signified by hematuria and proteinuria.
  • The patient presents with flank pain and hematuria 3-5 days after a respiratory or gastrointestinal infection.
  • It is not associated with any malignancy.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with a fever, fatigue, and headaches. She was recently diagnosed with SLE and has not started any medications for her condition yet. Her examination shows scattered purpura. She has not traveled anywhere recently and has not acquired any infection. Her laboratory results showed Hgb of 9.0 mg/dl, WBCs of 7.2 x 10⁹/L, platelets of 80 x 10³/L, BUN of 60 mg/dl, creatinine of 2.0 mg/dl, PT of 12, and PTT of 30 Which of the following will be seen in this patient's condition?

choices.text: Propagation of coagulation due to the systemic inflammatory response

questions.solution:
Option C:  Deficiency of a metalloprotease

  • The patient with signs of thrombocytopenia (purpura), renal injury, and neurologic symptoms (headache and dizziness) is most likely suffering from Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP).
  • TTP is caused by a deficiency of ADAMTS-13, a metalloprotease that cleaves vWF multimers. It leads to the deposition of vWF multimers in the vessels causing microthrombi formation.
  • This causes the consumption of platelets leading to thrombocytopenia. However, the coagulation cascade is not activated, which means the clotting factors will be normal.
  • Microvessel occlusion usually causes end-organ damage.
  • Kidney and brain are most commonly affected, manifesting as neurologic symptoms and kidney failure.
  • It is usually idiopathic but may occur secondary to AIDS, autoimmune conditions or drugs.

Option A: Hemolytic anaemia by bacterial endotoxin

  • Hemolytic anaemia secondary to bacterial endotoxin occurs in hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS).
  • It develops 5-10 days after a diarrheal illness (usually bloody) caused by E Coli.
  • Bacterial endotoxins cause endothelial damage leading to the formation of microthrombi. As red blood cells pass across these microthrombi, they get lysed, leading to jaundice and the formation of schistocytes.
  • Symptoms of HUS are similar to that of TTP. The major differentiating factor is the aetiology. Since this patient has no history of a recent diarrheal illness, the diagnosis of HUS is unlikely.

Option B: Propagation of coagulation due to the systemic inflammatory response

  • Propagation of coagulation due to a systemic inflammatory response usually occurs in disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
  • In DIC, a systemic inflammatory response leads to the inactivation of anticoagulant mechanisms and impaired fibrin removal, causing microthrombi formation.
  • However, in DIC, coagulation pathways consume, leading to elevated PT and PTT levels.
  • This patient's coagulation studies are normal, making DIC a less likely diagnosis.

Option D: Immune destruction of platelets

  • Immune destruction of platelets occurs in immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)
  • ITP is characterised by a solitary drop in platelet count. The rest of the labs are normal.
  • The patient has complaints of purpura and mucosal bleeding. The patient may develop an intracranial bleed in severe cases.
  • However, our patient also has anaemia and neurologic and renal involvement. This makes this diagnosis less likely.

questions.text: 33 years male presented to the clinic with the complaint of recurrent episodes of abdominal pain. On examination, there is mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation over the lips. Histopathological examination showed arborisation and pseudo invasion. Genetic analysis revealed that the gene responsible for the condition is LKB1/STK11. Colonoscopy revealed multiple polyps. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Peutz – Jeghers syndrome

  • It is an autosomal dominant disease
  • The most com­mon location in the small intestine is the jejunum. Although, it may occur in the stomach or colon & with much lower frequency in the bladder and lungs
  • There is germline loss of function mutations in the LKB1/STK11 gene.
  • There are multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps along with mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation.
  • Grossly the polyps are large and pedunculated with lobulated contour
  • On histopathology, they are characterised by the proliferation of the muscularis mucosae to form branching configurations covered by hypertrophic but normal mucosa

 

Option A: Familial adenomatous polyposis

  • FAP, also known as familial polyposis coli (FPC), is an autosomal dominant polyposis condition with different degrees of penetrance.
  • If left untreated, patients will grow hundreds to thousands of polyps throughout the colon and rectum.
  • Polyps commonly appear in the early adolescent years and, if left untreated, result in a nearly 100% lifetime risk of colorectal cancer by the age of forty.
  • Colectomy is required to significantly reduce the chance of developing colorectal cancer.
  • FAP is linked to various cancers, including gastric and duodenal cancers, hepatoblastomas, and desmoid tumours.

Option B: Hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer

  • Lynch syndrome, commonly known as hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC), is an autosomal dominant trait and the most common cause of inherited colorectal cancer (CRC).
  • It is distinguished by a substantial family history of HNPCC-associated malignancies involving first-degree relatives spanning at least two generations and at least one case identified before age 50.

Option D: Neurofibromatosis

  • Neurofibromatosis is a neurocutaneous condition characterised by nerve system and skin malignancies.
  • Types 1 and 2 neurofibromatoses are the Von Recklinghausen's disease, is an autosomal dominant condition.
  • Type 1 neurofibromatosis is characterised by neurofibromas, cafe-au-lait macules, freckling, and optic gliomas. It is a clinical diagnosis.
  • Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) is distinguished by bilateral vestibular schwannomas (VS) and meningiomas. It is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner.
  • Clinical monitoring and medicinal intervention are the mainstays of treatment.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl from a Punjabi family is brought to the hospital complaining of pale-coloured skin, fatigue and dyspnea. She has a history of repeated hospital admissions for blood transfusions. Physical examination reveals a palpable liver and spleen. Her lab findings include haemoglobin 7.5 g/dl, MCV – 70 fL, RDW – 22 and decreased osmotic fragility. The peripheral smear reveals golf ball inclusion bodies. What is the probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: HbH disease

The history, presenting complaints and lab findings in this patient mostly suggest a diagnosis of HbH disease.

HbH disease:

  • It is the most severe form of alpha thalassemia, mainly caused by the loss of three of the four alpha-globin alleles.
  • Golf ball inclusion bodies are known as HbH bodies and are found in alpha thalassemia.
  • Lab findings include: Decreased haemoglobin, MCV <80, raised RDW, and decreased osmotic fragility of RBC.
  • The peripheral smear stained with supravital stain (brilliant cresyl blue stain) shows multiple inclusions in an evenly distributed panel (see image below).

 

  • The diagnosis is confirmed by genetic testing.
  • Children with mild-to-moderate microcytic hypochromic hemolytic anaemia and hepatosplenomegaly should be evaluated for HbH disease.

Option A: Iron deficiency anaemia

  • It is microcytic hypochromic anaemia resulting from a reduced iron level in the body.
  • It does not cause hepatosplenomegaly, and repeated blood transfusions are usually not required.

Option C: Pernicious anaemia

  • It results from vitamin B12 deficiency in the body due to an autoimmune inflammation of the stomach.

Option D: G6PD deficiency

  • It is an inherited condition caused by deficient glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase enzyme in the body that leads to hemolysis.
  • The peripheral smear will show Heinz bodies (denatured and precipitated haemoglobin) in a supravital stain.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the outpatient department with complaints of pale-coloured skin, bruising, shortness of breath, and extreme fatigue. He also has a history of several episodes of bony pain. On examination, he is found with splenomegaly. His blood picture denotes a variable number of immature cells of the myeloid series and nucleated red cells in circulation. This blood picture may not be seen in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Multiple sclerosis

  • Leukoerythroblastosis refers to the presence of a variable number of immature erythroid and myeloid cells with nucleated RBCs in circulation (see image above).
  • It is seen in primary myelofibrosis and when there is marrow infiltration by a tumour.
  • This disturbs the marrow infrastructure and allows early release of the blood cell precursors in circulation.
  • Multiple sclerosis is a demyelination CNS (central nervous system) disorder; it does not affect the blood cells.

Causes of Leukoerythroblastosis:

Infections Fungal, HIV etc.
Tumours

Metastatic carcinomas.

Lymphomas, e.g., Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Leukemias, e.g., CML, AML, Hairy cell leukaemia.

Plasma cell disorders: Multiple Myeloma.

Polycythemia vera.
Lipid deposition Gaucher's disease.

Option B: Metastatic carcinoma

  • Metastatic bone marrow cancer can cause leukoerythroblastosis.

Option C: Gaucher's disease

  • It is an inherited lysosomal storage disease.
  • It causes a buildup of fatty substances in the bone marrow, resulting in leukoerythroblastosis.

Option D: Myelofibrosis

  • It is a rare cancer of bone marrow that causes extensive scarring and fibrosis of bone marrow, resulting in leukoerythroblastosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to the outpatient clinic with 7 kg weight loss, flatulence and occasional episodes of non-bloody diarrhoea for the past year. On physical examination, he appears thin and pale. Her blood pressure is 100/75 mmHg, pulse is 65 beats/min, and BMI is 17 kg/m². Laboratory investigation showed low serum iron and folate levels. Gastrointestinal endoscopy revealed villous atrophy and positive IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase antibody. Which of the following is the most critical complication of this disease?
questions.solution:
Option A: T-cell lymphoma 

  • This patient’s symptoms and laboratory investigations are suggestive of celiac disease.
  • The celiac disease predominantly involves damage to the small intestine, causing malabsorption and leading to nutrient and vitamin deficiency.

Celiac disease

Aetiology
  • Autoimmune reaction against gliadin (gluten-protein)
  • Genetic predisposition in HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8
  • Associated with other autoimmune diseases

Clinical findings
  • Chronic diarrhoea
  • Steatorrhea
  • Flatulence
  • Bloating
  • Abdominal pain

Extraintestinal

manifestations
  • Iron deficiency anaemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Osteoporosis
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis
  • Peripheral neuropathies
  • Neuropsychiatric problems

Diagnostic tests
  • Antibodies
  • IgA Anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies
  • IgA Anti-endomysial antibodies
  • Confirmatory test: Duodenal biopsy
  • Atrophy of villi
  • Crypt hyperplasia
  • Intraepithelial lymphocytes

Treatment
  • Life-long gluten-free diet
  • Iron, calcium, and vitamin D supplements
  • Dapsone for dermatitis herpetiformis

Complications
  • Enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma
  • Ulcerative jejunitis
  • The most severe complication of celiac sprue is the development of enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma.

Option B: Fistula

  • Fistulas (e.g., enterovesical fistula) is a complication of Crohn’s disease that involves transmural inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract.

Option C: Stricture

  • Strictures are also a complication of Crohn’s disease that can lead to bowel obstruction.

Option D: Hepatocellular carcinoma

  • Hepatocellular carcinoma is a complication of Wilson disease and hemochromatosis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of intermittent pain on the left side of the chest and paraesthesia on the left arm. He also complains of daily mid-chest pain. On examination, S-shaped scoliosis is seen. The physician diagnoses him with the straight back syndrome. The straight back syndrome is associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option A: Mitral valve prolapse

  • MVP is the most common cause of mitral regurgitation (MR).
  • It is also known as systolic click murmur syndrome, Barlow’s syndrome, floppy-valve syndrome, and billowing mitral leaflet syndrome.
  • The loss of normal kyphosis in the upper thoracic spine is the defining characteristic of the straight back syndrome, which is a thoracic deformity.
  • This deformity causes a reduction in the anteroposterior diameter of the chest, which results in the "pancaking" or compression of the heart and the major veins, giving the appearance that they are larger.
  • This is accompanied by a displacement of the heart to the left, which leads to cardiac murmurs, chest pain, and constriction of the trachea. It has been found that 64% of patients who had the straight back syndrome also developed mitral valve prolapse, also known as MVP.
  • Causes of MVP
    • Idiopathic
    • Defect of type 3 collection
    • Connective tissue disorders like Marfan syndrome, osteogenesis imperfecta, Ehler Danlos syndrome
    • ADPKD
    • Straight back syndrome
    • Ostium secundum ASD

Option B: Ankylosing spondylitis

  • Straight back syndrome is not associated with ankylosing spondylitis.

Option C: Osteopetrosis

  • The straight-back syndrome is not associated with osteopetrosis.

Option D: Cor-triatriatum

  • The straight back syndrome is not associated with Cor-triatriatum.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented to the medical OPD complaining of fatigue, weakness and hoarseness of voice for the past few weeks. She also had undocumented weight gain in the past 3 months. On physical examination, she had peri-orbital puffiness, the blood pressure was 100/ 70 mm Hg, the pulse was 56 beats per minute, and positive pedal oedema with dry and coarse skin. ECG was done, which showed an A-V block. Which of the following endocrinopathy is associated with A-V Block?
questions.solution:
Option A: Hypothyroidism

Hypothyroidism

  • Hypothyroidism reduces myocardial contractility and pulse rate. As a result, there is reduced stroke volume and bradycardia. Increased peripheral resistance may be accompanied by diastolic hypertension.
  • Thyroid hormone effects on the heart and peripheral vasculature include decreased systemic vascular resistance, increased resting heart rate, left ventricular contractility, and blood volume.
  • In hypothyroidism, there is a rise in diastolic blood pressure, decreased cardiac output and narrowed pulse pressure.
  • The thyroid hormone affects the action potential duration and repolarisation in the cardiac myocytes. The pacemaker SA node is activated by stimulating beta-adrenergic receptors by thyroid hormones leading to an increased heart rate.
  • In hypothyroidism, myxedema interferes with the AV conduction pathway of the heart. As a result, the pacemaker currents are not effectively transmitted through the pathway. Furthermore, decreased thyroid hormones result in decreased stimulation of beta-adrenergic receptors by thyroid hormones leading to a decreased heart rate.

Option B: Hyperthyroidism

  • In hyperthyroidism, the thyroid hormone-mediated action on the beta-adrenergic receptors is exaggerated due to increased levels of hormones. As a result, the pacemaker current increases, leading to an increased heart rate and sometimes to atrial fibrillation.

Option C: Cushing disease

  • Cushing's disease causes hypertension, tachycardia and weight gain. Hypertension occurs due to cortisol-mediated upregulation of the alpha-1 receptors in the vessels. This patient is not hypertensive and shows bradycardia.

Option D: Pheochromocytoma

  • It results in an increased release of catecholamines, activating the beta-adrenergic and alpha-adrenergic receptors. As a result, there is an increase in the heart rate, cardiac contractility and systemic vascular resistance.

questions.text: A 78-year-old male presents to the emergency department due to the abrupt onset of difficulty in speaking for 1 hour. He has had a history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus for 30 years and coronary artery disease for 10 years, treated with pravastatin, lisinopril, metformin and aspirin. His blood pressure is 165/90mmHg, his pulse is 76 beats/min, and temperature is 37.0°C. On physical examination, the patient speaks in short, simple sentences with difficulty repeating word sequences. He can follow simple instructions. A non-contrast CT scan of the brain shows. Which of the following is least likely to be associated with the patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Abulia

  • Abulia, also known as apathy, psychic akinesia, and athymia, refers to a lack of will, drive, or initiative for action, speech and ,thought is not associated with MCA infarction.
  • Abulia is associated with aging and other brain lesions.
  • The patient presents with clinical symptoms of a stroke.
  • The CT scan shows the involvement of the areas of the cerebral cortex supplied by the middle cerebral artery (MCA).
  • This results in Broca's aphasia (as in this patient) due to an MCA infraction.
  • The MCA is the largest cerebral artery and the vessel most commonly affected by cerebrovascular accidents.
  • Other findings associated with MCA infarction in the dominant lobe include the following:
    • Acalculia is a loss of the ability to perform simple calculations, typically resulting from disease or injury of the brain's parietal lobe.
    • Agraphia is an impairment or loss of a previous ability to write.
    • Finger agnosia is the inability to name, move, or touch specific fingers identified by the examiner.
    • Global aphasia is the ability to speak or comprehend language and severe communication difficulties.
  • Other features associated with MCA infarction in the non-dominant lobe include:
    • Anosognosia is a neurological condition in which the patient is unaware of their neurological deficit or psychiatric condition.
    • Constructional apraxia refers to the inability of patients to copy drawings or three-dimensional constructions accurately.
    • Neglect

Option A: Anosognosia

  • Anosognosia is a feature of MCA infarction in the non-dominant lobe.

Option B: Apraxia

  • Constructional apraxia is associated with MCA infarction.

Option C: Dysarthria

  • Dysarthria is associate with MCA infarction.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old woman presents to her general physician for a follow-up visit after having a high BP on her last visit. She was again found to be hypertensive and was prescribed hydralazine, a β-blocker, and furosemide. The woman takes no additional prescription or over-the-counter medications. She complains of muscle aches, joint pain, and rash. Physical exam reveals a temp. Of 37.7°C (100.0°F) and a scaling erythematous rash on her face. The physician orders an autoantibody panel:

Antinuclear antibodies (ANA): Positive

Anti-histone antibodies: Positive

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Hydralazine-induced lupus erythematosus

Rash, arthralgias, and anti-histone antibodies suggest drug-induced systemic lupus erythematosus (DIL).

  • Drug-induced lupus (DIL) is an autoimmune phenomenon where drug exposure leads to the development of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) like clinical features.
  • DIL is a clear example of an environmental trigger leading to the development of lupus in a genetically susceptible individual. Hydralazine was the first agent to be associated with the development of lupus-like symptoms.
  • Hydralazine is the causative drug in this case.
  • Positive ANA is nonspecific as there are many conditions, mostly infectious and autoimmune, that show positive ANA (RIM pattern is specific for SLE).
  • The sensitivity of ANA for drug-induced SLE is 100%, so if ANA is negative drug-induced SLE can be ruled out.
  • Drugs are known to induce SLE- Procainamide, chlorpromazine, isoniazid, methyldopa, minocycline, penicillamine, and diltiazem.
  • Drug-induced lupus is common in whites and has less female predilection as compared to SLE.

Pathophysiology:

  • Different mechanisms are used for the induction of autoimmunity by lupus-inducing drugs.
  • There are some genetic risk factors, such as HLA-DR0301, HLA-DR4, and complement C4 null allele, which varies between different agents.
  • The acetylators with genetic deficiency of N-acetyltransferase are at a higher risk of DIL, especially Procainamide and hydralazine.

Option A: Systemic lupus erythematosus

  • 95% of patients develop arthralgias or myalgia, or Arthritis in SLE
  • SLE is diagnosed by a physician using symptom assessments, X-rays, physical examinations,  and lab tests. SLE can be difficult to diagnose because its early signs and symptoms are nonspecific and may seem like signs and symptoms of other diseases.

Option C: β-blocker-induced systemic lupus erythematosus

  • Keratinocytes possess adrenergic receptors, which have been reported as being exclusive of the β2-subtype.
  • β2-adrenergic receptors are densest at the basal cells and decrease in number towards the stratum corneum, while intracellular calcium concentrations are lowest at the basal cells, increasing towards the stratum corneum, thus correlating with keratinocyte differentiation.

Option D: Furosemide-induced systemic lupus erythematosus

  • Moderate Potential Hazard, Moderate probability.
  • Furosemide use has been associated with exacerbation or activation of systemic lupus erythematosus.
  • Therapy with furosemide should be administered cautiously in patients with a history of lupus.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male HIV positive presents to the clinic for follow-up after ART therapy. Which of the following statement is true regarding IRIS?

choices.text: Stands for Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome
Usually occurs 6 months after initiation of ART
More common among patients with advanced immunosuppression
Unmasking IRIS develops in patients with undiagnosed subclinical TB after the initiation of ART

questions.solution:
Option B: Usually occurs 6 months after initiation of ART

  • Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) has been associated with administering antiretroviral therapy (ART), usually occurring 6 months after initiation.
  • It is a group of inflammatory conditions that appear after the start of ART in HIV-infected people and paradoxically increase previous infectious illnesses
  • The presumed pathogenesis of IRIS is an immune response elicited by antigens released when bacilli are killed during effective chemotherapy and is associated with improving immune function.

Option A: Stands for Immune Reconstitution inflammatory syndrome

  • IRIS stands for immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome.

Option C: More common among patients with advanced immunosuppression

  • IRIS is common among patients with advanced immunosuppression and extra-pulmonary TB.

Option D: Unmasking IRIS develops in patients with undiagnosed subclinical TB after the initiation of ART

  • “Unmasking IRIS” may also develop after ART initiation in patients with undiagnosed subclinical TB.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with type 2 diabetes presents with elevated fasting blood glucose levels despite adequate glycemic control throughout the day. His bedtime glucose levels are normal, but his fasting glucose levels are consistently elevated. What is the most likely cause of this phenomenon?
questions.solution:
The Dawn phenomenon, also known as the dawn effect, is a phenomenon where there is a natural rise in blood glucose levels in the early morning hours (usually between 2 AM and 8 AM) in individuals with diabetes, despite adequate glycemic control throughout the day. This rise in blood glucose levels is thought to be due to the release of counter-regulatory hormones, such as cortisol and growth hormone, in the early morning hours, which causes increased glucose production by the liver.

Why Other Options are Wrong:

Option A: Somogyi effect is incorrect because it refers to a rebound hyperglycemia that occurs in response to hypoglycemia during the night, usually due to an excessive dose of insulin. This is not the most likely cause in the given case as the patient's bedtime glucose levels are normal.
Option C: Rebound hyperglycemia is incorrect because it refers to a rapid rise in blood glucose levels after an episode of hypoglycemia. This is not the most likely cause in the given case as the patient's bedtime glucose levels are normal.
Option D: Hypoglycemia unawareness is incorrect because it refers to a condition where individuals with diabetes are unable to perceive the symptoms of hypoglycemia. This is not the most likely cause in the given case as the patient's blood glucose levels are elevated, not low.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of type 2 diabetes presents with worsening proteinuria and declining renal function. He also has hypertension and peripheral edema. Renal biopsy reveals thickened glomerular basement membrane with diffuse mesangial expansion and nodular glomerulosclerosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's history of type 2 diabetes, along with the presence of proteinuria, declining renal function, and characteristic findings on renal biopsy such as thickened glomerular basement membrane, diffuse mesangial expansion, and nodular glomerulosclerosis, is consistent with the diagnosis of diabetic nephropathy. These findings are commonly seen in advanced stages of diabetic nephropathy.

Why Other Options are Wrong:

Option B: Membranous nephropathy is unlikely as it is characterized by thickening of the glomerular basement membrane, but not nodular glomerulosclerosis as described in the question stem. Membranous nephropathy is also not typically associated with diabetes.
Option C: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is unlikely as it is a separate entity and not specifically associated with diabetes. It is characterized by segmental sclerosis of glomeruli, not diffuse mesangial expansion and nodular glomerulosclerosis.
Option D: Polycystic kidney disease is unlikely as it is a genetic disorder characterized by the development of multiple renal cysts, and is not specifically associated with diabetes. The renal biopsy findings described in the question stem do not support this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with resistant hypertension, muscle weakness, and polyuria. On laboratory evaluation, he has hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, and an elevated aldosterone to renin ratio. Imaging studies reveal adrenal adenoma. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Surgical removal of the adrenal adenoma

questions.solution:
The patient's clinical presentation of resistant hypertension, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, elevated aldosterone to renin ratio, and imaging findings of an adrenal adenoma are suggestive of Conn syndrome, which is a primary hyperaldosteronism. The most appropriate management for this patient is surgical removal of the adrenal adenoma, as it is the definitive treatment for Conn syndrome.

Why Other Options are Wrong:
Option B: Spironolactone is a mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist and is often used as medical management for Conn syndrome in patients who are not suitable for surgery or have bilateral adrenal hyperplasia. However, in this case, the patient has an adrenal adenoma, which can be surgically removed, making option A the most appropriate choice.
Option C: Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic that promotes the excretion of sodium and water, and it is not the appropriate treatment for Conn syndrome, which is characterized by excess aldosterone production.
Option D: Metoprolol is a beta-blocker, which is not the appropriate treatment for Conn syndrome, as it does not target the underlying cause of excessive aldosterone production.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old female presents with uncontrolled hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. She has no significant past medical history and is not taking any medications. Her blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg, and laboratory investigations reveal a serum potassium level of 2.8 mEq/L, serum sodium level of 142 mEq/L, and arterial blood gas (ABG) showing pH of 7.48 and bicarbonate (HCO3-) level of 30 mEq/L. Her plasma renin activity (PRA) is low, and plasma aldosterone concentration (PAC) is elevated.

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation of uncontrolled hypertension, hypokalemia, metabolic alkalosis, low PRA, and elevated PAC is suggestive of primary hyperaldosteronism, which is caused by excess production of aldosterone from the adrenal glands. This condition results in increased reabsorption of sodium and water and increased excretion of potassium, leading to hypertension and hypokalemia.

Why Others are Incorrect:
Option A: (Essential hypertension) is incorrect because essential hypertension typically does not present with hypokalemia or metabolic alkalosis.

Option B: (Secondary hyperaldosteronism) is incorrect because secondary hyperaldosteronism is usually due to another underlying condition, such as renal artery stenosis or heart failure, and is characterized by elevated PRA and PAC, unlike the case described in the question stem.

Option D: (Cushing's syndrome) is incorrect because Cushing's syndrome is caused by excess production of cortisol, not aldosterone, and does not typically present with hypokalemia or metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters is measured by esophageal manometry?

choices.text: Pressure changes in the lower esophageal sphincter

questions.solution: Esophageal manometry is a diagnostic test that measures various parameters related to esophageal function, including pressure changes in the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), esophageal peristalsis, and coordination of swallowing. It is a valuable tool for evaluating esophageal motility disorders and other conditions affecting esophageal function.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain localized in the left lower quadrant, along with fever and nausea. He has a history of constipation and occasional episodes of abdominal discomfort in the past. On physical examination, there is tenderness and guarding over the left lower quadrant of the abdomen. Laboratory tests show an elevated white blood cell count. CT scan of the abdomen reveals thickening of the sigmoid colon wall with pericolic fat stranding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presentation of severe abdominal pain localized in the left lower quadrant, along with fever, tenderness, and guarding on physical examination, and CT scan findings of thickening of the sigmoid colon wall with pericolic fat stranding, is suggestive of diverticulitis. Diverticulitis is an inflammation or infection of the diverticula, which are small pouches that can develop along the colon wall, usually in the sigmoid colon.

Why Others are Wrong:
Option A: Acute appendicitis - This option is incorrect because the presentation in the case is suggestive of diverticulitis rather than acute appendicitis based on the location of pain, history of constipation, and CT scan findings.

Option C: Ischemic colitis - This option is incorrect because the CT scan findings in the case are not consistent with ischemic colitis, which typically presents with vascular compromise and other risk factors.

Option D: Crohn's disease - This option is incorrect because the presentation in the case is suggestive of diverticulitis rather than Crohn's disease, which requires specific diagnostic criteria.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a long-standing history of dysphagia and regurgitation of undigested food. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals a dilated esophagus with multiple rings and furrows, resembling a "stack of coins" appearance. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Feline esophagus, also known as "ringed esophagus" or "corrugated esophagus," is a condition characterized by multiple rings and furrows in the esophageal mucosa, resembling a "stack of coins" appearance on endoscopic examination. It is typically asymptomatic and considered a benign finding, although it may be associated with mild dysphagia or regurgitation in some cases.

Why other options are wrong:

Option A: Achalasia - This option is incorrect as achalasia is a motor disorder of the esophagus characterized by impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) and absence of peristalsis in the esophageal body, leading to functional obstruction at the gastroesophageal junction.
Option B: Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) - This option is incorrect as GERD is a condition characterized by the reflux of gastric contents into the esophagus, typically causing symptoms such as heartburn, regurgitation, and dysphagia, but not specifically associated with the "stack of coins" appearance seen in feline esophagus.
Option D: Esophageal varices - This option is incorrect as esophageal varices are dilated veins in the esophagus that occur due to portal hypertension, typically seen in patients with advanced liver disease, and not related to the "stack of coins" appearance seen in feline esophagus.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with exertional dyspnea, chest pain, and syncope. Physical examination reveals a harsh systolic ejection murmur best heard at the right upper sternal border. Echocardiography reveals a narrowed aortic valve orifice with increased velocity of blood flow across the valve. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation, physical examination findings, and echocardiographic findings are suggestive of aortic stenosis. Aortic stenosis is a condition characterized by narrowing of the aortic valve orifice, resulting in increased velocity of blood flow across the valve and causing symptoms such as exertional dyspnea, chest pain, and syncope. The harsh systolic ejection murmur heard at the right upper sternal border is characteristic of aortic stenosis.

Why other options are wrong:

Option A: Mitral regurgitation - This option is incorrect as mitral regurgitation is a condition where blood flows backward through the mitral valve, typically causing a systolic murmur heard best at the apex of the heart, not at the right upper sternal border as seen in aortic stenosis.
Option B: Aortic regurgitation - This option is incorrect as aortic regurgitation is a condition where blood flows backward through the aortic valve during diastole, typically causing a diastolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border, not at the right upper sternal border as seen in aortic stenosis.
Option D: Pulmonary stenosis - This option is incorrect as pulmonary stenosis is a condition characterized by narrowing of the pulmonary valve orifice, typically causing a systolic murmur heard best at the left upper sternal border, not at the right upper sternal border as seen in aortic stenosis.

questions.text: A 24 year old woman presents to the physician for grossly irregular cycles. Her cycle length varies from 20 to 40 days and she is unable to plan her long distance travels due to uncertainty of her period dates. All of the following can be used to determine the phase of menstrual cycle in such a patient, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Option D : Estrous cycle does not occur in humans. These occur in most mammalian therian females, start after sexual maturity, and are interrupted by rest/ anestrous phases of variable length. Some animals may display vaginal discharge often mistaken as menstruation.

The menstrual cycle in humans consists of cyclical changes in hormone levels usually at fixed monthly intervals. There are end organ changes in response to rising and falling levels of hormones.

Ovarian cycles consists of the following : recruitment and growth of the follicles, ovulation, corpus luteum formation and finally regression of corpus luteum.

Tests for Ovulation

  1. Cervix mucus changes
  2. Basal body temperature : increases during ovulation by 0.5º F
  3. Vaginal cytology : vaginal smear microscopy for calculating ratio of parabasal, intermediate and superficial cells,
  4. Serum progesterone :a simple blood test done at D21 or 7 days before expected menses. A value of ≥ 3 ng suggests ovulatory cycle
  5. Endometrial biopsy : demonstrate secretory changes in endometrium
  6. TVS - to see follicular rupture monitoring
  7. Urinary LH kit
  8. Diagnostic Laparoscopy

Option A : Along with changes in the ovary there are simultaneous changes in the uterus - the menstrual cycle. Endometrial sampling revealing proliferative or secretory endometrium will tell whether ovulation has occurred or not.

Option B : Vaginal cytology and calculating the maturation index will tell us the phase of the ovarian and menstrual cycle.

Option C : Similarly the hormones FSH, LH, estradiol and progesterone will also correlate with the phase of ovarian cycles.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl with irregular menstrual cycles and anemia is diagnosed to have polymenorrhagia. The menstrual abnormality in the girl is?

choices.text: Increase in frequency of cycle along with excessive or prolonged bleeding
Increase in frequency of cycle with average normal bleeding
Increase in duration of cycle with less bleeding

questions.solution:
Option A : Polymenorrhea is defined as cyclic bleeding where the cycle is reduced to an arbitrary limit of fewer than 21 days and remains constant at that frequency. If the frequent cycle is associated with excessive and or prolonged bleeding, it is called polymenorrhagia.

Basic definitions of Menstrual cycle

  • Length of menstrual cycle : 28 +/- 7 days, polymenorrhea is cycle length less than 21 days, oligomenorrhea is cycle length more than 35 days
  • Duration : 2-7 days : hypomenorrhea is duration of cycle < 2 days, menorrhagia is duration of flow more than 7 days
  • Amount : 20-50 ml per cycle : hypomenorrhea is amount < 20 ml, menorrhagia is amount more than 80 ml
  • polymenorrhagia : cycle length less than 21 days and flow > 80 ml per cycle
  • Metrorrhagia : irregular cycles superimposed on regular cycles or intermenstrual bleeding/ spotting

Option B : Increase in frequency of cycle with average normal bleeding is polymenorrhea

Option C : Increase in duration of cycle with less bleeding is oligomenorrhea

Option D : Regular cycle with less bleeding is hypomenorrhea

questions.text: When planning ART (Artificial Reproductive Techniques) cycles for couples, which factor is not a concern for ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS)?
questions.solution:
Option D: Age > 35 years

  • Ovarian Hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) is a medical complication that is completely iatrogenic and unique to stimulatory infertility treatment. Its symptoms are the result of ovarian enlargement and fragility, extravascular fluid accumulation, and intravascular volume depletion. Advanced age is not a risk factor for OHSS.

Risk factors for OHSS are :

  • Polycystic ovary syndrome
  • Polycystic ovarian morphology with elevated AMH levels (>3.36ng/mL)
  • Previous episodes of OHSS
  • High E2(estradiol) concentrations
  • More than 20 preovulatory follicles
  • Patient factors: Young age, Low BMI
  • High or repeated HCG doses
  • GnRH agonist protocols
  • Pregnancy

OHSS is exclusively seen in infertility-treated patients who have received ovulation induction, with/ without HCG trigger for follicle rupture.

Option A: AMH levels of >3.3 ng/mL

  • Polycystic ovarian morphology with elevated AMH levels of  >3.36ng/mL is a risk factor for the development of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

Option B: Estradiol concentration> 3500 pg/mL

  • High estradiol concentrations > 3500 pg/mL are a risk factor for the development of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome.

Option C: Previous history of OHSS

  • The previous history of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome is one of the most important risk factors for OHSS.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents in the outpatient department with the complaint of a painful menstrual cycle. She further complains that she has raised her body temperature during this period. There are no abnormalities on physical examination. In a woman of reproductive age group with regular menstrual cycles and documented ovulation, which of the following event occurs during the ovulation phase?

choices.text: FSH induced steroidogenesis in granulosa cells
Stimulation of the arrested meiotic division of the oocyte

questions.solution:
Option D: Stimulation of the arrested meiotic division of the oocyte

  • Stimulation of the arrested meiotic division of the oocyte occurs at ovulation; till then, the oocyte is resting in the prophase of the first meiotic division.
  • The oocyte growth occurs with the growth of the follicle, but the oocyte remains arrested at prophase-I.
  • The preovulatory surge of LH stimulates meiotic resumption.
  • The oocytes which are arrested in prophase-I acquire the ability to resume meiosis.
  • Inhibin A level increases in early pregnancy.
  • The 1st polar body is released along with ovulation, while the second polar body is released after fertilization at the time of completion of meiosis II.

Option A: Peak in progesterone levels

  • Progesterone levels start to increase after ovulation and keep increasing throghout luteal phase

Option B: FSH-induced steroidogenesis in granulosa cells

  • FSH induces steroidogenesis in ovarian granulosa cells in early follicular phase and not around ovulation. 

Option C: Activin increases

  • Activin is produced in the pituitary glands, gonads, and placenta. Increasing estrogen in follicular phase increases inhibin and decreases activin levels which consequently act to decrease FSH levels

questions.text: A 37-year-old G2P2 woman presents to the gynecologist with pain in her lower abdomen and dysmenorrhea. On a pelvic scan, a complex ovarian cyst is 4 x 5 cm in size with a ground glass appearance. She is a chronic smoker, using combined contraceptive pills, and menstrual cycles coming at intervals of 20 days since menarche. A cystectomy is done, and histology reveals endometrial glands and hemorrhage. Which of the following in the patient's history is a risk factor for her condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Shorter menstrual cycle length

  • History of congestive dysmenorrhea, ovarian cyst and histopathological examination of endometrial glands is suggestive of endometriosis.
  • A shorter menstrual cycle length implies more menstrual cycles, which means more menstruation and, therefore, more severe endometriosis.
  • Protective factors against the development of endometriosis include:
    • Multiparity
    • Lactation
    • Tobacco exposure in utero
    • Diet high in vegetables and fruits.
  • Risk factors for endometriosis:
    • Infertility
    • Early age at menarche
    • Shorter menstrual cycle length
    • Nulliparity
    • High estrogen exposure
    • Mullerian anomalies
    • Low BMI
    • Family history
  • Prior use of contraception, intrauterine devices (IUD), or smoking is not associated with an increased risk of endometriosis.

Option A: Multiparity

  • Multiparity is protective for endometriosis as pregnancy and lactation imply the absence of periods for the associated period of amenorrhea.

Option B: OCPs use

  • OCPs are not risk factors for endometriosis as they reduce the net amount of estrogen in the body. Since endometriosis is a hyperestrogenic condition, it is not increased with the use of OCPs.

Option C: Smoking

  • Smoking inhibits the aromatase enzyme ( responsible for converting androgens to estrogen in the periphery), thus reducing estrogen and not increasing the risk of endometriosis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents to Gynaecology OPD for a regular check-up. On an ultrasound, she is incidentally found to have an anterior wall cervical fibroid. She is otherwise asymptomatic. She is advised to regular follow-ups. Which of the following could be the most common complaint she is most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Option B: Urinary Frequency

  • Anterior wall cervical fibroid can cause bladder or bladder neck compression, causing urinary symptoms like urinary frequency or retention.
  • Cervical Fibroid is
    • Rare ( 1- 2 % ) in the supramarginal part of the cervix.
    • It may be interstitial or subperitoneal variety and rarely polypoidal.
    • Depending upon the position, it may be anterior, posterior, lateral or central interstitial growths.
  • Anterior wall uterine fibroid is shown below:

  • The above diagram is showing the anterior wall fibroid is compressing the bladder.
  • This compression causes urinary frequency.
  • Management
    • Vaginal polypectomy or myomectomy
    • Myomectomy
    • Lap myomectomy
    • MRI-guided Myolysis
    • Vaginal hysterectomy
    • Total abdominal hysterectomy
  • Please note that although posterior cervical fibroids are associated more commonly with urine retention than anterior cervical fibroids, anterior fibroids can be associated with urgency, frequency and retention due to their position. Urinary symptoms in anterior cervical fibroids are their most common presentation.

Option A: Abdominal lump

  • A cervical fibroid usually does not present as an abdominal lump as the cervix is placed deep in the pelvis, unless it is very large.

Option C: Per vaginal bleeding

  • Bleeding is more commonly associated with uterine fibroids than cervical fibroids

Option D: Constipation

  • Constipation occurs more commonly in posterior wall fibroids.

questions.text: Contraceptive choices are usually personal preferences. However, while counseling the patient about each option, one should always be brief about contraceptive efficacy, and the final decision lies with the patient about which method to adopt. Which of these is used to measure contraceptive efficacy in the patient discussed?
questions.solution:
Option A: Pearl index

  • The Pearl rate expresses the use-effectiveness of the contraceptive method. Raymond Pearl introduced the Pearl rate or Pearl index in 1932. It is calculated as total accidental pregnancies x 1200 / number of women observed x total months of contraceptive use. It is expressed as HWY (hundred women-years).
  • The Pearl Index is described as the number of pregnancies occurring for one method per 100 women over 1 year. For example, the birth control pill has an effectiveness of 93%, and its Pearl Index is 7. So it means 7 women in 1 year will get pregnant even after using the pill.
  • There are various methods of contraception with different efficacy.

 

Option B: William rate

  • The use-effectiveness of the contraceptive method is expressed by Pearl rate, not by William rate.

Option C: Quasi-rate

  • The use-effectiveness of the contraceptive method is expressed by the Pearl rate, not by the quasi rate.
  • Quasi-experimental study designs, often described as nonrandomized, pre-post intervention studies, are common in the medical informatics literature.

Option D: AFS

  • AFS (American Fertility Society) score predicts the severity of endometriosis and the risk of recurrence after surgery.

questions.text: The following four are patient profiles of antenatal women with blood groups along with the blood group of the fetuses. Which of the following cases would have the most severely affected child?

choices.text: Rh negative mother with Rh positive fetus in 2nd pregnancy
Rh positive mother with Rh negative fetus in 2nd pregnancy
Rh positive mother with Rh negative fetus in 1st pregnancy
Rh negative mother with Rh negative fetus in 2nd pregnancy

questions.solution:
Explanation:
Option A: Rh negative mother with Rh positive in 2nd child

Hemolytic disease of the newborn:

  • Some of the mother's antibodies cross the placenta during pregnancy and reach the foetal bloodstream.
  • This is essential because babies have an immature immune system at birth, and the continued presence of maternal antibodies ensures their survival as their immune system develops.
  • Maternal antibodies can cause HDN by specifically targeting foetal RBCs is a drawback to this defence.
  • An important contributing factor to HDN is the mother's and fetus's Rh blood group incompatibility.
  • The D antigen is the one that causes hemolytic illness the most frequently, while other Rh antigens, including c, c, e, and e, can also be problematic.
  • HND-risk pregnancies are ones where the mother has Rh D-negative blood.
  • Pregnancies with an Rh D-positive child from an Rh D-negative mother are at risk for HND (the child has inherited the D antigen from the father), especially in the second pregnancy.
  • The mother's immune system forms antibodies against the foetal D antigen in response to it (anti-D).
  • These antibodies are often of the IgG type, which is given to the foetal blood by crossing the placenta.

Option B: Rh positive mother with Rh negative in 2nd child

  • Rh negative child will not have antigen, so a fetomaternal bleed will not elicit an antibody response in the mother

Option C: Rh positive mother with Rh negative in 1st child

  • Rh-negative  child will never develop antibodies in the mother because of the absence of Rh antigen.

Option D: Rh negative mother with Rh negative in 2nd child

  • Rh incompatibility is not seen when the child is Rh negative.
  • However, there are chances of Rh incompatibility for a Mother who is Rh negative with a child with Rh positive.

questions.text: A primigravida presents in active labor at full-term pregnancy. The pelvic examination reveals a 5 cm dilated cervix, with face presentation such that the chin is placed anteriorly in the pelvis and a clinically adequate pelvis. Electronic fetal monitoring shows reactive fetal tracing. Which of the following is the most appropriate step in managing this patient?

choices.text: Perform forceps rotation in the second stage of labor to convert mentum anterior to mentum posterior and to allow vaginal delivery
Allow to labor spontaneously until complete cervical dilation is achieved, and then perform an internal podalic version with breech extraction

questions.solution:
Option B: Allow spontaneous progress of labour

  • If the face presentation is mento-anterior, then vaginal delivery is possible.
  • Sub-mentovertical (10 cm) or sub-mentobregmatic (9.5 cm) diameters of engagement are suitable for vaginal delivery.
  • The sterno-bregmatic (16–18 cm) is the engaging diameter in the mento-posterior position because the chest and head both attempt to cross the brim simultaneously.
  • For mento-posterior, it is recommended to have an elective caesarean section as the engaging diameter is greater than the pelvic inlet as well as outlet.

 

Option A: Perform immediate cesarean section

  • Face presentation with mento-posterior warrants immediate cesarean.

 

Option C: Perform forceps rotation in the second stage of labour to convert mentum anterior to mentum posterior and to allow vaginal delivery

  • Because the mentum is already anterior and may be delivered vaginally, conversion to mento-posterior is not performed because it would put the face in an unfavourable position.

 

Option D: Allow to labour spontaneously until complete cervical dilation is achieved, and then perform an internal podalic version with breech extraction

  • For face presentation, an internal podalic version is not performed.
  • Transverse lie in the second twin is the only indication of IPV.

questions.text: A woman presents at 39 weeks with complaints of vaginal discharge. On examination, a turbid straw-colored fluid is seen flowing out of the external os and on bimanual examination, membranes are absent. Which of the following is the correct interpretation of these findings?

choices.text: Normal liquor discharge after spontaneous rupture of membranes at term

questions.solution:
Option C : Turbid straw coloured liqour is seen at normally at term.

Color of Amniotic fluid Seen in :
Clear fluid Early pregnancy
Straw colored/ turbid At Term
Green Meconium stained
Red Antepartum hemorrhage(abruption)
Yellowish green Post term pregnancy
Tobacco juice IUD
Golden yellow Rh isoimmunization

Option A : Abruption is associated with a tense tender uterus and liquor is blood stained.

Option B : Chorioamnionitis may be seen with prolonged leaking, which lead to infection of the amniotic membranes causing fever leucocytosis along with foul smelling liqor which may appear purulent.

Option D : Meconium staining is suggestive of fetal distress, however the color is green

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman with P2L2 complains of heavy menstrual cycles with the passage of blood clots for 7 to 10 days each month for the past 1 year. She has only transient relief with medicines (the nature of medicines is unknown). On examination, the uterus is 18 cm in size. A USG shows an intramural fibroid size of 16 x 18 cm and an endometrial thickness of 4mm. Her Hb is 6.7 g/dL. What is the treatment of choice?

choices.text: Hb build-up and medical management with GnRH agonists/ mifepristone and follow-up.
Diagnostic and therapeutic D&C, if biopsy normal, myomectomy after blood transfusion

questions.solution:
Option C: Hb build-up and hysterectomy.

  • Hysterectomy is the definitive treatment of large fibroids. As a patient is aged and her family is also completed, surgery is the best option in this case. Hb build-up is necessary before surgery as low haemoglobin may lead to septic and distributive shock during surgery.
  • The patient has already tried medical treatment and failed; hysterectomy is a permanent solution to the symptomatic fibroid.
  • The treatment plan is mentioned below :

 

Option A: Hb build-up and medical management with GnRH agonists/ mifepristone and follow-up.

  • It is not a treatment option as the patient has already tried a medical treatment, which is not working for her.

Option B: Endometrial ablation.

  • Endometrial ablation is indicated for treating menorrhagia in premenopausal or perimenopausal women with normal endometrial cavities or thickened endometrium

Option D: Diagnostic and therapeutic D&C, myomectomy after blood transfusion, if biopsy normal.

  • D &C is done to determine the cause of abnormal or excessive uterine bleeding and would be therapeutic if the cause was endometrial hyperplasia
  • However myomectomy is not suitable here as the fibroid is extremely large and hysterectomy is also more suitable as her family is complete

questions.text: A primigravida at full-term pregnancy with no high-risk factors is in the third stage of labor. All of the following are components of active management of 3rd stage of Labour, except?
questions.solution:
Option A: Early cord clamping

  • Recently, delayed cord clamping has been advocated for all deliveries to ensure the fetus gets maximum blood from the placenta (except in cases like R. isoimmunization and fetal distress, see table below).

Clinical Situations in which Immediate Umbilical Cord Clamping should be considered

Maternal

Hemorrhage, hemodynamic instability, or both Abnormal placentation (previa, abruption)

Fetal/neonatal

Need for immediate resuscitation
Placental circulation not intact (abruption, previa, cord avulsion, IUGR with abnormal cord Doppler evaluation)
  • Active management of the third stage of labour:
  • The aim is to reduce the chances of PPH, to be done in all patients in the third stage of labour, irrespective of the presence or absence of risk factors
    • (1) Administer a uterotonic (oxytocin IV or IM)
    • (2) Controlled cord traction
    • (3) Uterine massage
  • Early cord clamping is not a component of the Active management of the Third stage of labour.
  • It is done for indications given below:
  1. Newborn needs resuscitation
  2. HIV + mother
  3. Rh -ve pregnancy
  4. Baby is a known case of heart disease

The American College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists Committee on Obstetric Practice, 2017 January report, makes the following recommendations regarding the timing of umbilical cord clamping after birth:

  • In term infants, delayed umbilical cord clamping increases haemoglobin levels at birth. It improves iron stores in the first several months of life, which may have a favourable effect on developmental outcomes.
  • Delayed umbilical cord clamping is associated with significant neonatal benefits in preterm infants, including improved transitional circulation, better establishment of red blood cell volume, decreased need for blood transfusion, and lower incidence of necrotizing enterocolitis intraventricular haemorrhage.
  • Given the benefits to most newborns and concordant with other professional organizations, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists now recommends a delay in umbilical cord clamping in vigorous term and preterm infants for at least 30–60 seconds after birth.
  • A small increase in the incidence of jaundice requires phototherapy in term infants undergoing delayed umbilical cord clamping. Consequently, obstetrician-gynaecologists and other obstetric care providers adopting delayed umbilical cord clamping in term infants should ensure that mechanisms are in place to monitor and treat neonatal jaundice.
  • Delayed umbilical cord clamping does not increase the risk of postpartum haemorrhage. That's why oy is preferred.

Option B: Uterine massage

  • This is one component of management of the active stage of labour.

Option C: Controlled Cord traction

  • Controlled cord traction should be done to remove the placenta effectively.

Option D: Oxytocin infusion

  • Giving IV or IM oxytocin is one of the components of management of the third stage of labour.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, who achieved pregnancy through in vitro fertilization (IVF), undergoes a bedside transvaginal ultrasound at 7 weeks gestation. The ultrasound reveals the presence of twins at 7 weeks with two normal heartbeats. What is the most likely type of twin pregnancy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D : Most common twins after assisted reproduction are dizygotic twins. For increasing the success of IVF and the expenses involved, it’s a norm to transfer 2-3 embryos of day 3 or 1-2 embryos of Day 5. For women lesser than 35 years, the implantation rate is better and hence these are the ones who have more multiple pregnancies. Please note that dizygotic twins are always diamniotic and dichorionic.

 

In the given USG image, twin peak/lambda sign is seen which is characteristic of DCDA placenta

 

Option A, B, C : In monozygotic twins, chorionicity depends upon time of cell division. Monozygotic twins are rarely seen in IVF pregnancies.

Time of cell division Chorionicity of placenta
First 72 hours post fertilization(morula stage) DCDA
4-8th day(blastocyst stage) MCDA(MC type of monozygotic twins)
8-12th day MCMA
>12th day Conjoined/Siamese twins, type of MCMA (Formation of embryonic plate occurs)

questions.text: A 37-year-old multipara construction laborer presents to the emergency department with fatigue and generalized body weakness. Upon enquiringabout her nutritional status, she revealed that she has not eaten well well-balanced diet lately. Her blood picture shows hypochromic microcytosis. This is most likely indicative of which one of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Option D: Combined iron and folic acid deficiency

  • There is a presence of Iron deficiency anaemia in almost 70-75% of Indian women, but usually in malnourished women, along with iron, there is a deficiency of essential vitamins and proteins as well.
  • The commonest anaemia thus seen in our women is Dimorphic anaemia rather than isolated iron deficiency anaemia.
  • In dimorphic anaemia, along with iron, there is a deficiency of folic acid as well. Iron is crucial to the structure of haemoglobin in RBCs. It is needed to transport oxygen to the tissues for their oxygenation.
  • Folic acid is crucial for RBC formation and healthy cell growth. The deficiency of folic acid in pregnancy can result in birth defects.
  • The deficiency of iron can result in microcytic RBCs with low haemoglobin, and that of folic acid can result in the improper shape of RBCs, making them macrocytic.
  • Here anisocytosis means a combination of microcytes and macrocytes. Microcytes are seen in iron deficiency, and macrocytes are seen in folic acid and B12 deficiency, hence a dimorphic picture.

Option A: Iron deficiency

  • Only iron deficiency leads to microcytic anaemia.

Option B: Folic acid deficiency

  • Folic acid deficiency leads to macrocytic RBCs.
  • There is no anisocytosis.

Option C: Physiological anemia

  • Physiological anemia is due to hemodilution and shows a normocytic normochromic picture

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents to Gynecology OPD with complaints of abdominal distention and pain over the previous 3 months. Her physical examination reveals an abdominal mass without shifting dullness and bilateral adnexal masses. Her digital rectal examination reveals the presence of induration in the rectal pouch. Her breast examination and recent mammogram are normal. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Option A: Serous cystadenocarcinomas of both ovaries

  • The patient is a 68-year-old woman with abdominal distention, pain with bilateral adnexal masses, and induration in the rectal pouch. Bilateral adnexal masses in postmenopausal must raise suspicion of epithelial ovarian cancers. Most common of which are serous cystadenomas/ carcinomas. Induration in the rectal pouch suggests locally advanced disease and favors a malignancy.
  • The picture below shows the Serous cystadenocarcinoma.

  • Serous cystadenocarcinomas are the most common malignant tumors of ovaries and the most common tumors associated with a bilateral origin.
  • The peak incidence of invasive epithelial ovarian cancer is about 60. About 30% of ovarian neoplasms in postmenopausal women are malignant.
  • Mostly unilocular
  • Bilateral in >50%
  • Mostly malignant
  • Surface growth present
  • Psammoma Bodies are present in 40-45%

​​​​​​​

Option B: Krukenberg’s tumors of the ovaries

  • Krukenberg’s tumors are also bilateral but are associated with another primary malignancy (most commonly gastric carcinoma) and are less common than epithelial tumors.
  • Hence, it is not the correct option.

Option C: Malignant ascites

  • It is ruled out as there is no shifting dullness. Please note that serous cystadenocarcinomas do present with ascites quite commonly.
  • So, it is a false statement.

Option D: Meig's syndrome

  • Meig's syndrome is ascites and pleural effusion associated with fibroma of the ovary, which is again ruled out due to the absence of ascites.
  • So, it is not a true option.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female accompanied by her husband presents to Gynaecology OPD for contraceptive counselling. She has been married for 6 years, and her last childbirth was 1 year ago. She has 4 live children with one abortion. Also, she was concerned about limiting her family from having no contraindications for oral contraceptive pills. It has been explained that the failure rate of contraceptive pills is less than 1 per Hundred Woman Years. How can the failure rate be calculated?

choices.text: Total accidental pregnancies × 1200 / number of women observed x Total months of contraceptive use.
Total months of exposure to unintended pregnancy X 1200 / Accidental pregnancies.
Total months of exposure to unintended pregnancy X 1200 / Accidental pregnancies.
Total accidental pregnancies / Total months of exposure to unintended pregnancy.

questions.solution:
Option A : The use-effectiveness of contraceptive method is expressed as Pearl rate . Pearl rate or pearl index was introduced by Raymond Pearl in 1932 The rate is expressed as pregnancy rate per 100 women years (HWY) & calculated as

Pregnancy rate per HWY = Total accidental pregnancies × 1200/ Number of women observed x Total months of use of contraceptive

(1200 is the number of months in 100 years).

Another technique is the life-table method. It calculates the probability of pregnancy in successive months, which are then added over in a given interval.

Option B, C, D : These are all incorrect formulas.

questions.text: A 23-year-old primigravida presents to the OPD for her first prenatal check-up at 8 weeks of gestation. She has had a history of nodular cystic acne for 2 years for which she had been taking an oral drug prescribed by her dermatologist. The drug used by the patient is a category X drug. Which of the following drugs is the patient most likely taking?
questions.solution:
Option B: Isotretinoin

FDA (Food and Drug Administration) Pregnancy Categories:

  • FDA has categorised the drugs used in pregnancy into the following categories based on their risk of teratogenicity. 
  • Category A: Safe in pregnancy, e.g., thyroxine, multivitamins
  • Category B: Animal studies have shown adverse effects. All studies on humans are safe, e.g., penicillins, most cephalosporins and macrolides.
  • Category C: Teratogenic in animals. Inadequate human studies available, e.g., mebendazole, albendazole and acyclovir.
  • Category D: Known human teratogens. These medicines can cause fetal harm when administered to a pregnant woman. Given to a pregnant woman only when their benefits are more than their risks, e.g., anti-epileptics and quinine.
  • Category X: Medications are contraindicated in women who are or may become pregnant. These may cause fetal harm.
  • Examples of category X drugs include:
  • Isotretinoin
  • Androgens
  • ACE inhibitors
  •  Vitamin A
  • Tetracycline
  • Lithium
  • Methotrexate
  • Valproic acid
  • Mifepristone
  •  Danazol
  • Alcohol
  • Radioactive iodine 

 

Option A: Clindamycin

  • Clindamycin is a drug used for the treatment of acne.
  • It is a topical drug.
  • It belongs to category B

 

Option C: Erythromycin

  • Erythromycin is a macrolide used for acne treatment.
  • It is used orally.
  • It belongs to category B.

 

Option D: Azithromycin

  • Azithromycin is also a macrolide. 
  • It belongs to category B.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is responsible for converting androgens to estrogens in the ovarian follicle?
questions.solution:
Option C: Aromatase is an enzyme responsible for the conversion of androgens to estrogens in the ovarian follicle.

Why other options are incorrect

Option A: 17-alpha hydroxylase is an enzyme responsible for converting progesterone to 17-hydroxyprogesterone in the ovary and adrenal gland.

Option B: 21-beta hydroxylase is an enzyme involved in the production of aldosterone and cortisol in the adrenal gland.

Option D: 3-beta hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase is an enzyme responsible for the conversion of pregnenolone to progesterone and also plays a role in androgen synthesis.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is a rare congenital disorder that affects the female reproductive system and is characterized by the absence or underdevelopment of the uterus and the upper two-thirds of the vagina?
questions.solution:
Option C: Mayer Rokitansky Kuster Hauser (MRKH) syndrome is a congenital disorder that affects females, in which the vagina, cervix, and uterus either fail to develop or are underdeveloped. This condition usually becomes apparent during puberty when a girl does not begin menstruating, and the diagnosis is made through medical imaging and physical examination. MRKH syndrome can be emotionally challenging, as it may impact fertility and sexual function, but there are treatments available to address these issues.

Why Others are Incorrect

Option A: Turner syndrome: A genetic condition that affects females, caused by missing or partially missing X chromosome, resulting in short stature, infertility, and other health issues. Does not affect the development of the uterus and vagina.

Option B: Klinefelter syndrome: A genetic condition that affects males, caused by having an extra X chromosome, resulting in small testes, infertility, and other health issues. Does not affect the development of the female reproductive system.

Option D: Androgen insensitivity syndrome: A genetic condition that affects the development of the male reproductive system, where the body does not respond to male hormones, resulting in female physical traits. Does not affect the development of the female reproductive system.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is characterized by an abnormal communication between the bladder and vagina?
questions.solution:
Option C: Vesico-vaginal fistula is an abnormal communication between the bladder and vagina, leading to continuous leakage of urine through the vagina. 

Why other options are incorrect

Option A: Urethrovaginal fistula: communication between the urethra and vagina

Option B: Vesicouterine fistula: communication between the bladder and uterus

Option D: Colovaginal fistula: communication between the vagina and colon

questions.text: The strength of association can be defined as the degree to which the values of two variables vary or change together. Strength of association is given by which of the following?
questions.solution:
ANSWEROption D: Odds ratio

  • The strength of association can be defined as the degree to which the values of two variables vary or change together.
  • The strength of association is given by the Odd's ratio or Cross product ratio in a Case-control study.
  • Odds ratio = ad/bc
  • OR > 1 - Positive association, OR = 1 - No association, OR < 1 - Inverse/ negative association.

Option A: p-value

  • The Chi-square test or t-test can only tell whether an association is statistically significant based on p-value, but doesn’t give the magnitude of strength of the association.

Option B: Coefficient of regression

  • The coefficient of regression doesn’t give the magnitude of the strength of the association.

Option C: Alpha value

  • The alpha value doesn’t give the magnitude of the strength of the association.

questions.text: A community medicine student was asked to draw some study designs. Identify the study design given in the image below?
questions.solution:
Option D - Nested case-control study

  • The given image depicts a Nested case-control study.
  • Nested case-control study:
  • - Type of cohort Study
  • Temporality → forward-looking study
  • Only done in
    • New & Rare diseases
    • If Diagnostic tests are very Expensive.
  • It is a small case-control study that is nested in a big cohort study.

Other options

Option A - Cross-sectional study

  • Cross-sectional study:
    • Aka Snapshot study/ Prevalence study (as prevalence is calculated).
    • Done at point of time (neither forward, nor backward).
    • Based on primary data.
    • Can't calculate the strength of association.

Option B - Retrospective cohort study

  • Retrospective Cohort Study
    • The combination of a prospective cohort study and case-control study is known as a retrospective cohort study.
    • This study gives Incidence, RR, AR, PAR, and this study also saves time.

Option C - Case-control, study

  • Case-control study is better for rare diseases.
  • Case-control study has 2 groups
    1. Cases: Having the disease
    2. Controls: They are comparison groups not having the disease
  • We ask about the history of the same exposure in both groups & then compare both groups.

questions.text: Disability-adjusted life expectancy (DALE) has been replaced by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option C: HALE

  • The indicator used to measure healthy life expectancy has been changed from DALE(disability-adjusted life expectancy) to health-adjusted life expectancy (HALE).
  • It also includes the life spent in poor health.

Option A: DALY

  • Years lost due to disability / premature death.
  • It is the best indicator of the burden in society.

Option B: QALY

  • The quality-adjusted life year is a general indicator of illness burden that takes into account both the quantity and quality of life.

Option D: DFLE

  • DFLE- Disability Free Life Expectancy.
  • It is the average number of years an individual is expected to live free of disability.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of disability limitation?
questions.solution:
Option D: Physiotherapy in polio

  • This is an example of disability limitation.

  • Tertiary level of prevention

    · Disease in progression or over

    · Modes

    ○ Disability limitation

    ○ Rehabilitation

Other options

Option A: Combined OCPs in PCOD

  • Combined OCP in PCOD is a secondary level of prevention.
  • Early diagnosis and adequate treatment come under secondary prevention.

Option B: DDT

  • The use of DDT is Primary level-specific protection.
  • Dichloro Diphenyl Trichloroethane is an insecticide, almost colorless, and odorless used in agriculture.

Option C: BCG vaccine

  • BCG vaccine is Primary level-specific protection.
  • As the action (vaccine) is taken prior to the onset of the disease. It is an example of primary prevention.

questions.text: In a given population, the total number of births in a year is 4050. There are 50 stillbirths. 50 neonates die within the first 7 days of life whereas the number of deaths within 8-28 days of life is 150. What is the Neonatal mortality rate in the population?
questions.solution:
Option B: 50

Neonatal mortality rate

  • Neonatal deaths are deaths occurring during the neonatal period, commencing at birth and ending 28 completed days after birth.
  • The neonatal mortality rate is the number of neonatal deaths in a given year per 1000 live births in that year.

In the given case,

  • Total neonatal deaths = Total early neonatal deaths + Total late neonatal deaths = 50 + 150 = 200
  • Total live births = Total births – Total stillbirths = 4050 – 50 = 4000
  • NMR = Neonatal death / Live births × 1000
  • Thus, the Neonatal mortality rate, NMR = 200/4000 × 1000 = 50 per 1000 live births.

Other options are incorrect

questions.text: If birth rate of a sub-centre of population 5000 is 25/1000 then expected no. of pregnancies in a year will be:
questions.solution:
Option C: 138

  • Expected number of live births (Y)/year = Birth rate (per 1000 population) x population of the area /1000
  • As some pregnancies may not result in a live birth (i.e., abortions and stillbirths may occur), the expected number of live births would be an under-estimation of the total number of pregnancies.
  • Hence, a correction factor of 10% is required, i.e., add 10% to the figure obtained above. So, the total number of expected pregnancies.

Based on data provided,

  • Given Birth rate is 25/1000 population.
  • Population under the sub-center 5000.

Expected number of live births (Y) = (25 x 5000)/1000 = 125 births

Correction factor (pregnancy wastage) = 10% of 125 = 12.5

(Z) = Y + 10% of Y

  • Therefore, total no. of expected 125 + 13 = 138 pregnancies in a year.

Learning Objective

  • Expected number of live births (Y)/year = Birth rate (per 1000 population) x population of the area /1000
  • As some pregnancies may not result in a live birth (i.e., abortions and stillbirths may occur).
  • Hence, a correction factor of 10% is required.
